IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Wound healing is a complex process that involves thousands of genes and a large number of cells. The studies proposed in this application will use quantitative models and analysis to study complicated interactions in wounds. The results will help us understand wound healing in both health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Atherosclerosis/Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death in the US, and therefore creates a significant burden to the national health system and despite lipid lowering treatments adverse events continue to rise. Our discovery that altering bile acid amount and/or composition regulates the selective absorption of lipids and extent of atherosclerotic disease will advance our fundamental understanding of how absorption regulates atherosclerosis progression and may reveal novel opportunities for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A non-human primate (macaque) brain resource (MacBrainResource, MBR) has been established from slides, tissue and EM blocks generated in the laboratories of Drs. Pasko Rakic and Patricia Goldman-Rakic. This resource will enable scientists worldwide to conduct de novo analyses of the macaque brain at a minimal cost to them and without the sacrifice of any additional animals. To renew MBR for another 5 years would permit the completion of ongoing scientific studies and the initiation of new ones while honoring the public call and scientific commitment to data and resource sharing and a responsible use of animals in research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance Statement: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the second most common childhood leukemia and has a dismal prognosis. For over 40 years AML chemotherapy has changed little with the continued reliance on ara-C, daunorubicin and etoposide as frontline agents. The proposed research seeks to define the impact of proteomic and metabolomics landscape of leukemic cells on patient risk stratification and revealing additional layers of the molecular basis of AML prognosis to guide the development of more effective treatments for AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Enzyme catalysts are one of the principal components of all living systems and there are many diseases that may be cured by inhibition of a single enzyme. Advances in the understanding of enzyme catalysis from studies of enzymatic reaction mechanisms may prove critical for drug design, to the understanding of metabolic pathways and diseases, and to the resolution of other health-related issues. This proposal describes fundamental experimental and computational studies of the origins of rate accelerations for enzyme catalysts, and for the development of novel inhibitors of metabolic enzymes from pathogenic organisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Sleep problems may be one mechanism through which young children may be at risk for developing ADHD, although first line ADHD interventions, including parent behavioral interventions (PBIs), do not address sleep. We propose to use parenting strategies from the COPEing with ADHD PBI to target sleep disrupting behaviors for children 3-5 years old at elevated risk for ADHD, which will be delivered by behavioral health therapists embedded in pediatric primary care to increase families’ access to intervention. This pilot effectiveness trial is the first step towards developing an early intervention targeting sleep as a mechanism to reduce the prevalence, symptoms, and impairments associated with childhood ADHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Hypomyelinating leukodystrophy (HLD) is a genetically heterogeneous group of neurodegenerative diseases characterized by reduced cerebral myelin formation, as well as cognitive and motor impairment appearing in childhood. In a pair of siblings with HLD, we have discovered a Pro-to-Thr mutation in the coding sequence of the EPRS1 gene that encodes a bifunctional tRNA synthetase (glutamyl-prolyl tRNA synthetase) and leads to its reduced expression without altering its activity. Here, we will investigate in detail the mechanism of reduced expression of EPRS1 in cells and in a novel mouse model of HLD generated by the CRISPR/Cas9 system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite the increasing number of surgical pulmonary resections performed annually the effects of detrimental post-operative inflammation associated with these procedures are poorly understood. We now make a discovery that a proinflammatory cell population, known as the eosinophil, is detrimental to recovery post-lung resection in a translational animal model. Here we explore the physiology of this cell population in a small animal model with the hope of improving both long and short-term post-operative outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Distinct groups of eukaryotic DNA mismatch repair (MMR) family proteins facilitate crossing over between homologs to ensure proper Meiosis I chromosome segregation, and act to prevent recombination between divergent DNA sequences that can lead to chromosomal rearrangements associated with diseases such as cancer. In humans, failures in meiotic chromosome segregation result in aneuploidy syndromes (at least 10% of human pregnancies), which are thought to occur as the result of Meiosis I and II errors, defective or inappropriate recombination, premature homolog separation, and defects in sister chromatid cohesion. Importantly, mutations in MMR genes have been found in about half of hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (2-7% of all colon cancers) patients, and are thought be linked to infertility, underscoring the importance of obtaining new mechanistic understandings and molecular tools to establish allele pathogenicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Diabetes mellitus (DM) is associated with significant co-morbidities, specifically those associated with nervous system dysfunction, including increased risk for peripheral artery disease (PAD), and cardiovascular complications. This project will optimize and apply dual isotope hybrid non-invasive imaging approach for evaluation of lower extremity flow, peripheral nerve activity, and vascular calcification in pre-clinical models of PAD and in patients with DM and a spectrum of PAD severity. The proposed multi-isotope imaging of lower extremity flow and nerve activity developed and applied in this project in conjunction with imaging of calcifications of the arteries will characterize the pathophysiology of nerve dysfunction in PAD and this information may lead to a paradigm change in the evaluation and long-term management of patients with DM and PAD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pregnancy promotes remarkable changes in maternal metabolism and physiology. To ensure appropriate delivery of oxygen and nutrients to the fetus and maternal organs, the maternal heart undergoes a physiological form of hypertrophy; however, the mechanisms that contribute to this adaptive remodeling are unknown. This project will examine how the maternal heart adapts to the demands of pregnancy, with the goal of understanding how changes in cardiac metabolism influence pregnancy-induced cardiac growth as well as reversal of cardiac growth following pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Pancreas agenesis is a developmental disorder characterized by either a reduction or complete lack of pancreatic mass and heterozygous loss of GATA6 accounts for >60% of all human pancreas agenesis cases. The primary goals of this renewal application are to use complementary mouse and human genetic model systems to better define the mechanisms by which the intersection of RA signaling and GATA6 regulate pancreas development. Furthermore, we will explore how human mutations in GATA6 disrupt this interaction to influence disease severity.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Osteosarcoma is the most common primary bone cancer in humans and survival improvements have not been attained in over three decades; the majority of patients will succumb to metastatic spread. Identification of novel targets in osteosarcoma will be required to advance treatment of this ultimately fatal disease. This project aims to interrogate and define the non-canonical role of the Core Binding Factor Beta (CBFβ) protein in the initiation of protein translation, a process critical for tumor cell survival, thereby improving our understanding of the biology of osteosarcoma and providing a knowledge base for identification of novel targets and therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Hyperactivity of the cardiac ryanodine receptor/Ca2+ release channel of the sarcoplasmic reticulum (RyR2) may lead to ventricular fibrillation and other lethal cardiac arrhythmias, such as occurs in the arrhythmogenic syndrome catecholaminergic polymorphyc ventricular tachycardia (CPVT), a congenital disease affecting children and young adults with an apparently normal heart. β-blockers are the standard therapy for CPVT, but it often results in incomplete protection. We discovered that selected scorpion venoms contain calcins, a family of peptide ligands of RyR2 that are able to penetrate cellular membranes and mitigate Ca2+-dependent arrhythmias due to RyR2 hyperactivity. In this study, we will develop a rationalized and novel paradigm for the treatment of CPVT based on calcins. These results may be applied to other cardiomyopathies where controlled unloading of intracellular Ca2+ may be desirable.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH A woman's supply of eggs (oocytes), which are present in her ovary from birth, are essential for her fertility, and for her long-term health, as loss of the oocyte pool leads to menopause, with increase risks of osteoporosis, cardiovascular disease and muscle atrophy. Mutations in human Nemp1 are associated with early menopause, and loss of Nemp1 in mouse models leads to infertility. By studying how Nemp1 functions using mouse models, we can better understand how we can support a woman's fertility and her health, and diagnose some causes of infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although one in every three U.S. high school seniors used e-cigarettes in the past year, the long-term trajectories and consequences of e-cigarette use, and longitudinal associations with other nicotine/tobacco use, tobacco cessation, tobacco use disorder symptoms, and other health consequences beyond 1-3 years remain largely unknown, especially among vulnerable populations. This study will address these critical gaps in public health knowledge by improving estimates of e-cigarette use trajectories, investigating the long-term health consequences associated with trajectories of e-cigarette use among adolescents and young adults, and identifying important risk and protective factors and subpopulations most vulnerable to e-cigarette use and its consequences. Findings from the proposed longitudinal study will be widely disseminated to help guide clinical practice, inform public health policies, and enhance future longitudinal research to reduce tobacco-related harms.

ORG_NAME: NATHAN S. KLINE INSTITUTE FOR PSYCH RES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) is a disorder with persistent, severe seizures as well as changes in behavior. We will selectively excite or silence a specific type of nerve cell that is implicated in TLE, mossy cells (MCs), and ask if the seizures and behavioral comorbidities are improved, using experimental mice that simulate TLE. The hypotheses to be tested are novel, will address the epilepsy as well as comorbidities, and will investigate underlying mechanisms so new treatments can be developed in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Large scale proteomic profiling of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) patients has identified an interconnected network of proteins that change in levels as the disease advances. To determine the function of these proteins in the brain and link them to specific causes of AD, this project will dissect the role of SMOC1, a key protein predicted to drive changes in the network as a whole, and link individual network components to specific triggers that cause AD. The completion of this study will identify targets for drug development, uncover biological processes underlying AD, and elucidate the role of a predicted AD protein network with high translational potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Since Extracellular Vesicles (EVs) are shed by virtually all cells into bodily fluids, they are relatively easy to collect, and might be considered the ultimate source of biomarkers for disease diagnostics. However, the clinical utility of EVs is limited by a lack of reliable and reproducible methods to identify and evaluate EV-associated biomarkers. This proposal will utilize a flexible platform based on detection of an innovative EV-marker, which will be combined with mouse models to rigorously validate the potential of EVs as biomarkers for the detection and staging of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Tau pathology accumulates in a progressive pattern that is consistent with propagation along synaptically connected brain circuits. However, it is unknown how they enter neurons and replicate. I propose to use 3D correlative light and electron microscopy combined with fluorescent biosensor systems and novel conformational tau antibodies in human neurons to test how tau seeds access the cytoplasm, and with which cellular sub-components they amplify.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathology is characterized by the build-up of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles in the brain. While these cardinal pathological hallmarks have been recognized for more than one hundred years, there is much about them and their relationship which we still do not understand. The goal of this research is to obtain a deeper understanding of amyloid plaque diversity and the relationship between plaques and tangles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a global, multi-phenotypic disease associated with lung damage from repeated external inflammatory insults such as smoke, vaping, forest fires, pollution, chemical exposure, and occupational hazards faced by 1st responders, the military, agricultural workers etc.. There are currently no treatments available for COPD patients that can halt or reverse the course of this disease. A protein has been identified which is responsible for key clinical outcomes in COPD and Verra Therapeutics aims to leverage this protein as a novel target to dramatically impact lung function in these patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative The project will contribute to public health by (1) evaluating the long-term impact and mechanisms of Community Navigation (CN), a community-affordable universal early childhood system of psychosocial care that aims to improve population rates of parent mental health, positive parenting behaviors, child maltreatment rates, and child cognitive and behavioral development; 2) evaluating the impact of CN on reducing disparities in these outcomes across race and income groups; and (3) testing pathways of how access to community resources and parenting efficacy can reduce child maltreatment and improve healthy child development, as well as reduce disparities in these outcomes across race and income groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mechanism by which the incidence of cardiovascular events is increased in premature senescence- triggered vascular diseases (PmSVD) induced by ionizing radiation (IR) and in patients with Hutchinson- Gilford progeria syndrome (HGPS) remains largely unknown; hence, there is an urgent need to correct this gap. PmSVD promotes the pro-inflammatory senescent phenotype in endothelial cells, leading to increased cardiovascular disease, but the molecular mechanisms remain largely unknown. Our proposed studies will provide insights into how PmSVD promotes cardiovascular dysfunction and facilitates the development of new therapeutic approaches for PmSVD-induced atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extensive health disparities exist in Alzheimer's disease (AD) and AD research for the Black community in that rates of AD are higher among Black individuals, yet there is a lack of research, and hence understanding, of their experience of this disease. Women show a more aggressive profile of AD than men with higher levels of the Alzheimer's causing pathological tau and a faster rate of clinical decline; inflammation and insulin resistance represent potential mechanisms for these differences given their sex disparities and ties to tau. Through a longitudinal observational study using blood-based markers of inflammation, insulin resistance, pathological tau, and measures of physical activity, we aim to answer the following questions in Black women: 1) How do levels of inflammatory markers and insulin resistance relate to changes in tau deposition and cognitive performance over time? 2) Does physical activity represent a protective factor against tau spread and cognitive decline, possibly through its beneficial effects on inflammation and insulin resistance? 3) How do social determinants of health impact these relationships?

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is a major public health concern that continues to increase in severity given the aging population. It is also a condition that disproportionately affects minority populations, who have reduced access to healthcare and may have distinguishable risk factors including cerebrovascular risk. The goal of this project is to establish the role of cerebrovascular injury and dysfunction in the pathophysiology of preclinical Alzheimer’s and develop individualized imaging-based cerebrovascular profiles that predict memory decline across racially and ethnically diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Environmental disruption of circadian rhythms caused by altered timing of light exposure as occurs in shift work increases the risk of several types of cancer, including lung cancer. We found that an altered lighting schedule that mimics the circadian disruption experienced by shift workers enhances tumor formation in a mouse model of KRAS-driven lung adenocarcinoma. This project tests the hypothesis that increased tumor formation in response to chronic circadian disruption is caused by perturbation of normal daily cycles in signaling through the transcription factor heat shock factor 1 (HSF1), which leads to chronic activation of a molecular proteotoxic stress response pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This study will use newly developed person-centered and multidimensional approaches to identify which parentally bereaved children experience problems in grief, mental health or development of competencies over six years and could benefit from an effective program. The study also tests the effects of the Family Bereavement Program (FBP) to reduce those problems in childhood and how reducing problems in childhood leads to reduced mental health problems in adulthood. The findings will have implications for who should receive services and how to optimize the FBP for dissemination to the public.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Skeletal muscle satellite cells (MuSCs) are tissue stem cells responsible for muscle repair in response to injury and degenerative diseases. This project aims to investigate the novel role played by lipid droplets and lipid metabolism in satellite cell biology. Knowledge from the proposed work will lead to better understanding of the cellular and molecular regulation of MuSC function in the context of muscle regeneration under pathological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontitis is chronic gum inflammation leading to systemic inflammation and neuroinflammation and may subsequently promote the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease. The proposed study will identify a novel mechanism by which periodontitis increases succinate in cerebrospinal fluid and activates succinate receptor in microglia to induce neuroinflammation and neurodegeneration. The study will provide a potential therapeutic strategy by targeting succinate receptor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Corneal blindness affects millions worldwide, with less than 2% of patients having access to donor corneal tissue required for a sight-restoring transplant. A way to transparently restore scarred stromal tissue and support epithelial re-growth without the need for sutures or graft tissue would be of great benefit to patients suffering from the blinding consequences of corneal injury and disease. To this end, this research seeks to develop a novel therapy that suturelessly removes and replaces corneal scars with mesenchymal stromal cells encapsulated within an in situ-forming, transparent gel designed to regenerate healthy corneal tissue and potentially stave off the need for traditional transplant surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Germinal matrix intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) occurs in 15-20% of babies born before 32 weeks of pregnancy. Lifelong consequences may include post-hemorrhagic hydrocephalus (PHH), developmental delay, and cerebral palsy. We propose to use cutting-edge optical, genetic, molecular, and clinically informed approaches in our mouse model of neonatal IVH to test if two distinct and complementary endogenous responses to intraventricular blood can be harnessed to mitigate IVH sequelae: (1) ChP-NKCC1 gene therapy to remove excess CSF, and (2) macrophage clearance of ventricular blood. Our findings will give insight into the sequence and causality of events following IVH, unveil new therapeutic targets, and test the first potential gene therapy for PHH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Rapid progress in experimental neuroscience techniques and machine learning-based models for the brain presents a common challenge in understanding high-dimensional (many neurons) neural representations in an interpretable and quantifiable way. This proposal represents a path to a multi-level framework for connecting neural representational geometry to multiple scales (neurons to regions) and levels of computational abstraction, such as (i) the effect of single neuron tuning properties on neural representations, (ii) the role of region-to-region transformations and task-learning, and (iii) new algorithms for training neural network models of the brain via geometry and machine learning. The synergy between two modern approaches – task-efficient representational geometry and machine learning – will lead to new fundamental principles and methods in computational neuroscience and enable multi-level, multi-scale theory of neural representations and discover common principles of neural computation across different brain regions and multiple modalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Preeclamptic women, women with newly developed hypertension during pregnancy, have elevated autoantibodies and inflammatory markers and cells programmed to kill virus infected cells or tumor cells. However, the exact pathway linking the pregnancy and the activation of these specialized cells, autoantibodies or inflammatory factors with the increase in blood pressure and intrauterine growth restriction associated with preeclampsia has yet to be clearly defined. This proposal focuses on determining specific cellular interactions that lead to the production of autoantibodies and other factors that cause increased blood pressure and decreased fetal growth during pregnancy and hypertension in the offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS) is an idiopathic age-related disease that impacts 10 million people per year in the US alone. This age-related disease presents at middle-age and results in significant quality of life and work force issues for patients. The experiments outlined in this proposal are designed to validate the role of cellular senescence in CTS and determine the efficacy of targeting cellular senescence in CTS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Late recurrence stemming from acquired therapy resistance is a persistent clinical problem for patients with estrogen receptor (ER)+ breast cancer. We propose that steroid receptor (SR) co-activators, PELP1 and SRC- 3, cooperate as key inputs to oncogenic signaling pathways that mediate therapy resistance mechanisms, such as the survival of cancer stem cells (CSC). Identifying and targeting reversible events that drive metastatic ER+ tumor cells is an unmet need that has the potential to extend patient lives and improve well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Recurrent seizures are the most common manifestation of an acute brain insult in neonates and children and are often resistant to antiepileptic drugs that target inhibitory chloride permeable GABAA receptors. It is well established that hypoxia-ischemia (HI) induces neuronal chloride elevation resulting in cytotoxic edema and recurrent seizures. Emergent prevention of neuronal chloride influx might reduce cell swelling, restore GABAergic inhibition, improve treatment and prevent seizures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Epithelial polarization – an essential biological process serving many physiological roles including tissue morphogenesis and wound healing – relies on the separation of the cell plasma membrane into distinct apical and basolateral domains with unique lipid and membrane-protein constituents. Despite the critical nature of polarization, the fundamental determinants of the composition, structure, and function of apical and basolateral membrane domains remain unknown. I will examine the lipid components of the membrane and the consequent biophysical membrane properties, investigate the structural determinants of polarized protein sorting, and explore the role of apical plasma membrane elements on determining membrane structure, namely the formation of epithelial tubules such as cilia or microvilli.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE These studies will contribute to our understanding of cellular stress responses regulated by the EGF receptor using a host-virus approach. These are fundamental processes in mammalian cells, and as such these studies will have broad medical implications. We propose that many common human disorders such as cancer and a range of inflammatory diseases employ the same cellular stress pathways as infectious agents. Our studies will therefore lead to identification of common biological pathways and new drug targets for multiple human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/ PROJECT NARRATIVE: Functional protein production necessitates highly stable and processive RNA polymerase II (RNAPII) elongation, with synthesis of the average human messenger RNA (mRNA) requiring RNAPII to transcribe over 30 kilobases of genomic sequence without dissociating from the DNA template. In contrast, promiscuous transcription by RNAPII of enhancers and other regulatory elements is typically terminated within several hundred bases. Here we will study this dichotomy, elucidating the nucleic acid sequences and protein factors that selectively promote productive elongation of mRNAs, and those that drive efficient termination of unwanted RNA species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This study sets out to investigate the role of microglia and the neurotrophin receptor p75NTR on neuronal degeneration in frontotemporal dementia. We combine molecular analyses including single-nucleus RNA sequencing in postmortem brain tissue with a dynamic human stem cell model of frontotemporal dementia using patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cells. Co-culture assays, overexpression and knockdown of p75NTR as well as cell transplantation and single cell analyses will be performed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Craniomaxillofacial (CMF) injuries need to be treated for protection of the brain as well as aesthetic and functional restoration of the calvaria and the skin but there are no satisfactory treatments available to aid in reconstructing large composite tissues to an acceptable level, much less to natural form and function. The proposed work will investigate the intraoperative bioprinting of composite tissue (bone and skin) constructs with localized delivery of differentiation factors such as miRNA mimics and decellularized tissue components to repair CMF defects on a rat model. Successful completion of the proposed work will have a great potential to pioneer the translation of advanced bioprinting technologies from bench to bedside, which will have incredible advantages in operations for CMF repair in surgical settings for humans in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is an increasingly prevalent disease characterized by chronic inflammatory immune responses directed against the gut microbiota (the collection of microbes and viruses that inhabit the intestine), and severely impedes the health of its sufferers. A major unmet clinical need entails development of improved therapeutic regimens that quell ongoing inflammation while sparing protective immunity. We propose to leverage strain-level variation in a model gut bacterium that is associated with imparting distinct immune phenotypes to identify health-promoting anti-inflammatory pathways to treat IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As an orally transmitted pathogen, Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) spreads through saliva, infects tonsil B-cells, and establishes latency in the B-cell compartment in over 95% of the global adult human population. While the balance between latency and lytic reactivation underlies the pathogenesis of EBV-associated diseases, including infectious mononucleosis and nasopharyngeal carcinomas and lymphomas, the mechanisms that mediate this switch remain incompletely understood. The overall goal of this study is to elucidate the role of the protein SFPQ in suppressing EBV lytic reactivation so that these findings can be leveraged for development of lytic induction therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Organelle tethering and mitochondrial membrane contact sites plays a central role in regulating the function and distribution of the mitochondrial network. Identifying the physiological functions of mitochondrial membrane contact sites and how they are regulated in space and time is relevant to public health as dysregulation of mitochondrial function plays key roles in human disease, such as neurodegeneration and cancer. Thus, the proposed research on mitochondrial membrane contact sites is relevant to the part of the NIH mission that seeks to advance fundamental knowledge that will lead to improvements in human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Mutations in the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) are a frequent cause of lung cancer. We are working to develop a new class of drugs that selectively target the mutant receptor by binding in a site that is different from existing drugs. In the long term these “allosteric” inhibitors, used alone or in combination with other EGFR- targeted drugs, should lead to more effective and better tolerated treatments for lung cancers caused by certain EGFR mutations.

PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section  We are proposing to define immunologic mechanisms responsible for glycoconjugate vaccine processing and presentation leading to optimal T helper–cell reactivity. Our basic discoveries will lead to new, more effective glycoconjugate vaccines against important pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multidrug-resistant (MDR) pathogens result in over 2.8 million potentially life-threatening infections in the United States annually. This proposal aims to establish how the microbes naturally associated with our bodies (i.e. our microbiome) protect against difficult-to-treat MDR pathogens. From this work, we will gain a clearer understanding of the factors that render the oral microbiome vulnerable to invading pathogens and will identify promising lead molecules for antibiotic drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Many animals exist in two different sexes which perform different behaviors. The sex of the brain and behavior are defined during development through discrete changes to neurons and circuit between the two sexes. Here, we will investigate how and when the brain-masculinizing transcription factor Fruitless acts on genes to establish the sex of the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: NARRATIVE We plan to develop a radically new technology for molecular computation, whereby molecules themselves respond to external stimuli and produce output at the level of cellular phenotype, serving as nanocomputing agents (NCAs). Advent of such NCAs would revolutionize the interrogation of biological systems, enable a deeper understanding of human biology and disease, and facilitate development of in situ precision therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) is an efficacious treatment for patients with depression and those at risk for depression relapse, though the processes through which MBCT achieves its outcomes are not well understood. By bringing together two parallel research literatures on basic cognition and cognitive biases in depression, this project aims to examine whether affective executive functioning serves as a mechanism of action of MBCT via a pilot randomized controlled trial. Better understanding how MBCT works will help us to better identify individuals who may benefit from MBCT and further personalize MBCT to target such processes directly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative About 15% of Americans have hearing loss due to noise exposure. Here, we propose to use in vivo imaging of the mouse cochlea to determine how auditory nerves are damaged by loud sounds. The findings of this research may ultimately support a clinical trial in human subjects that attempts to treat hearing loss during the few hours after blast or noise trauma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Menisci of the knee cushion our joints during normal loading, but are commonly injured. Unfortunately, healing of the meniscus in adults is limited, and current treatment options do not restore function, resulting in degeneration of the underlying cartilage. To address this, we engineer fibrous scaffolds with tailored release of factors that sequentially promote endogenous cell migration from the surrounding tissue and direct differentiation upon arrival at the wound site, and test these in a large animal model of meniscus repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African Americans and Latinos carry a disproportionate burden of glaucoma, a blinding eye disease that can lead to severely decreased quality of life. Promoting adherence with topical medications that lower intraocular pressure, the primary therapeutic target for reducing the risk of glaucoma progression, represents a critical opportunity for technology-driven interventions. The iGLAMOUR (innovations in GLaucoma Adherence and Monitoring Of Under-Represented minorities) Study aims to develop and evaluate a health information technology framework incorporating flexible sensor electronics, machine learning-based predictive models, a patient- facing mobile interface, and a clinician-facing clinical dashboard to facilitate early identification and intervention for high-risk patients in order to narrow these racial disparities and improve vision outcomes in these minority populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Food allergy is a disease with no known cure, high economic burden, and increasing prevalence. Oral immunotherapy (OIT) has shown effectiveness in increasing desensitization and remission in allergic individuals; however gastrointestinal complications commonly limit clinical utility. Studying the mechanisms by which mast cells elicit gastrointestinal anaphylaxis will enable novel therapies to prevent undesirable symptoms during OIT and to alleviate suffering in patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arboviruses represent a serious global public health threat. The infection of arthropod vectors and humans by these viruses is an essential step in the viral life cycle and one that can be targeted to stop viral spread. Here, we delineate the mechanisms promoting arbovirus infectivity in insects and mammals, and begin to elucidate what drives the adaptation of the viral glycoproteins in the hopes of targeting this critical step to stop arbovirus disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We use a multidiscipline approach to study the neural mechanism whereby the human genetic variant OtpQ153R/+ causes obesity and glucose intolerance. To this end, we have generated new mouse genetic tools to probe the roles of Otp in two populations of hypothalamic neurons that are critical for energy and glucose balance. The overarching goal is to develop mechanism-based therapeutics to mitigate metabolic syndrome in human OtpQ153R/+ subjects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Local blood flow is critical to supply neurons in the brain with a continuous supply of nutrients. We now describe a novel communication network through capillaries and arterioles that signal blood vessels to relax and increase blood supply to active neurons, and provide new insights into small vessel disease of the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Cytochrome b5 reductase 3 (CYB5R3) serves as a critical redox switch for substrates such as heme and coenzyme Q that are needed for controlling of biogas molecules such as nitric oxide and oxygen. Building on our currently funded NHLBI studies and published results, we aim to 1) improve our understanding of basic redox biology through work involving other CYB5R family members, 2) gain insight into unidentified and novel redox partners and substrates of CYB5R enzymes, 3) uncover the translational impact of CYB5R enzymes in human disease and 4) discover new small molecule drugs that restore redox signaling and reverse cardiovascular disease. As such, this proposal may lend critical new insight into novel targets, better strategies, and new drugs to improve the health of people living with cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb)- the causative agent of tuberculosis (TB)- kills more people than any other bacteria. Macrophages normally play the first line of defense against microbes, but in the case of Mtb, they provide a site in which the bacteria can grow. We will elucidate how a protein and a lipid from Mtb, CpsA and phthiocerol dimycocerosate, respectively, enable the bacteria to evade killing by host macrophages and establish an infection. Our studies will yield important insights into why humans fail to sterilize Mtb and advance innovative therapies and vaccines for TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a common condition and is a critical risk factor for the development of cardiovascular disorders in children and adults. The current proposal investigates candidate microbial strains and metabolites that are important in OSA-induced cardiovascular disease. The knowledge obtained from this study will provide valuable information for identifying novel therapeutic targets and developing effective strategies for OSA-induced cardiovascular disorders in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Membrane biogenesis is an essential process for all living cells and defects in this process underlies many of the most common human diseases. Moreover, the majority of drugs in the market target membrane proteins or membrane-associated processes. This research will improve our understanding of how biological membranes are assembled and how they achieve their precise composition of lipid and protein molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis, a dysregulated response to infection, is the leading cause of acute kidney injury impacting millions of patients every year and has no proven therapy aside from supportive care. The proposed research will investigate the role of a complex biologic system, the renin-angiotensin system, and its relationship with kidney injury in sepsis. By increasing our understanding, future therapies may be developed that help treat patients with this condition and improve meaningful short- and long-term patient outcomes.

PHR: AFDOSS PROJECT NARRATIVE AFDOSS Annual Educational Conferences provide information on current and emerging food, drug, and medical device topics impacting health and safety and helps build consensus among the states on regulatory approaches to address them. Grant funding for travel costs enables participation of individuals that otherwise might not attend due to economic constraints.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Co-Principal Investigators/ProgramDirectors (Last, First, Middle): Shekhar, Anantha; Johnson, Philip L.  Panic disorder (PD) is a severe anxiety disorder characterized by recurrent panic attacks affecting about 2- 5% of the population and resulting in severe disability in about a third of those patients. Using our well established animal model, we identified that a specific set of brain cells called orexin (hypocretin) neurons are a key regulators of panic attacks, which are inhibited by a subset of midbrain serotonergic neurons. Therefore, we will determine how interactions between these two chemical pathways regulate normal panic and how they are impacted in PD pathology. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac outflow tract (OFT) defects, including aortic valves and the greater arteries, are estimated to cause approximately 30% of these congenital heart diseases, and they are treated with surgical correction and/or replacement. It remains unclear what would be the consequences of reduced cardiac contractility or altered intracardiac flow dynamics on valve morphogenesis, including aortic stenosis, bicuspid or tricuspid aortic valves. To understand the mechanotransduction causation downstream of blood flow and shear stress sensing, we have assembled a multi-disciplinary team to integrate advanced laser optics, imaging computation, and genetic models to decouple intracardiac flow dynamics from myocardial contractility that modulates Notch1b-mediated endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EndoMT) with translational implication to aortic valve disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Immunotherapies have revolutionized the treatment of cancer by improving survival benefit for patients in a number of cancer types, however, with increasingly complex treatment strategies being deployed in a variety of combinations, the risk for developing severe side-effects in the form of immunotoxicities is heightened. Through improved preclinical models, such as generating tumors in autoimmune-prone mice, we can better study the influence of immunotherapies on both tumor immunity and autoimmunity. This will address a growing need to provide accurate safety profiling and mechanistic interrogation of both combinatorial and single-agent therapies to determine optimal therapeutic regimens to improve cancer care with mimimal immune-related adverse-events.

PHR: The proteins synaptobrevin, SNAP25, syntaxin, Munc18 and Munc13 play a central role in the membrane fusion process that mediates neurotransmitter release. Similar proteins mediate release of hormones, histamines and various other compounds form cells of the immune system. This project is aimed at determining the precise nanomechanicxal interactions and structural changes of these proteins associated with their function, which is widespread medical significance from neurodegenerative diseases to the function of the immune system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative (Metabolomics and Clinical Assay Center, MCAC) The Metabolomics and Clinical Assay Center (MCAC) will perform targeted and untargeted metabolomics assays, and clinical assays in blood, urine, and stool biospecimens as part of the NIH Common Fund Nutrition for Precision Health (NPH) Consortium. Clinical Centers, funded under a companion mechanism, will conduct dietary intervention studies, and collect the biospecimens from participants in the All of Us Research Program. The MCAC will collaborate with all awarded components (Clinical Centers, Dietary Assessment Center, Microbiome and Metagenomics Center, Research Coordinating Center, Artificial Intelligence for Multimodal Data Modeling and Bioinformatics Center) to derive consensus on appropriate study designs, tools, assays, and the interpretations that will reveal how human biological systems and molecular pathways interact with or mediate the relationships among dietary patterns, environmental, social, and behavioral factors to influence health status.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For Black cisgender women living in New Orleans, Louisiana, the rate of new HIV diagnosis is almost 7 times higher than that of White women; uptake of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) has been limited. In our previous research, we found that Black cisgender women do not know of other Black cisgender women taking PrEP, and Black women are not offered PrEP during routine medical care. Therefore, we will develop and pilot implementation strategies at the patient- and provider-levels that are designed to increase PrEP uptake and retention in PrEP care among Black cisgender women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are a major source of morbidity, mortality, and healthcare costs. Bacterial infections are a common cause of exacerbations, however it is not known whether individuals with frequent exacerbations have specific defects in antibody function against bacteria. Investigating antibody-mediated immune function in COPD could lead to the recognition of novel risk factors for exacerbations, newly recognized sub-populations, and targeted therapeutic interventions for individuals with immune dysfunction, with potential for broader application to other pathogen types and disease processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Itch is a common sensory experience that allows for the detection of noxious substances and incites their removal by scratching that can be debilitating if not properly controlled. Advances in our understanding of the itch-specific neural pathway have highlighted many G protein-coupled receptors needed to transmit itch, and new discoveries in sensory neurons have emphasized the importance of G protein-coupled receptor signaling from subcellular domains to convey sensory stimuli. This research project seeks to link these new discoveries, to determine the importance of endosomal signaling of GPCRs in itch and to characterize new targets for improved therapeutics to treat pruritus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis treatment is difficult, requiring multidrug treatment for many months. To more effectively treat tuberculosis, including drug resistant disease, we must develop new combination therapies that are effective against bacteria in different types of lesions. In this project, we will develop an efficient, lesion-centric pipeline for data-driven optimization of multi-drug regimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Overuse of blood cultures to evaluate critically ill children for bacteremia can lead to a cascade of harm in the form of false positive results, unnecessary antibiotics, increased cost, and longer length of stay. The patient- level, clinician-level, and organizational-level determinants of overuse of diagnostic tests such as blood cultures are poorly understood, and no work has evaluated overuse reduction strategies. I will use implementation and behavioral science to define those determinants, and then develop and test strategies to safely reduce blood culture overuse in critically ill children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  The neural mechanisms of reward seeking and punishment avoidance remain unclear. In the proposed research program, we will determine how the central amygdala participates in such behaviors and in the generation of anxiety state. Findings from this project will have important clinical implications, as dysfunctions in the central amygdala have been implicated in anxiety disorders, depression and drug addition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric sports medicine is a rapidly evolving field that contains many unique elements within clinical care and research, given that many pediatric sports injuries and conditions are unique to young athletes and do not occur in other age groups. The Pediatric Research in Sports Medicine (PRiSM) Society is dedicated to the care of pediatric and adolescent athletes, and our annual meeting provides a unique space for researchers, clinicians, and trainees from a variety of different backgrounds to gather and discuss barriers to clinical practice and ways to best address them. Through our unique approach to understanding condition-specific injuries and conditions within youth athletes and developing collaborative multi-site research projects (Research Interest Groups), the PRiSM annual meeting is a forum where interdisciplinary collaborations begin, grow, and produce meaningful advancements in the field.

PHR: Na+ channels are clustered at the neuromuscular junction (NMJ) and are responsible for generation of the muscle action potential. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Light-mediated relaxation of airway smooth muscle is a novel discovery by our laboratory but the cellular signaling mechanisms of opsin receptor activation have yet to be determined. We will identify the receptor signaling pathways by using synthetic retinal derivatives and the transfection of opsin receptors to change wavelength sensitivity of airway smooth muscle. We will also explore the mechanism of endogenous activation of opsin receptors with a naturally occurring direct agonist, β-ionone, that has the ability to activate opsin receptors in the absence of light.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it utilizes a new approach to advance understanding of how the brain regulates behavioral states transitions associated with fear and panic, and will thereby provide vital information about the root cause of debilitating psychiatric illnesses, such as post-traumatic stress, panic, and specific phobia. This is directly relevant to the NIH’s mission pertaining to reducing illness and disability and of laying the foundation for ad- vances in disease treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposal examines how a particular type of immune cell responds to its environment during the development of human inflammatory bowel disease by using animal models and different forms of this immune cell to treat this disease in animals. The goal of our research is to understand how this immune cell, termed “regulatory T cells,” in the intestine can be optimized to better suppress the disease. Information gained from this study will help identify approaches to inhibit excessive inflammation and provide treatment strategies for stopping this debilitating condition that destroys bowel.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Physical activity has numerous health benefits. Physical activity behaviors develop from very early childhood. This proposed project aims to develop an analytic tool to recognize the activity types of toddlers, such as walking/running, standing, sitting, and being carried by an adult. The analytic tool developed will be useful to accurately evaluate physical activity levels among toddlers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Alzheimer Disease (AD) brains show severe defects in the vascular system, causing ischemia, a condition known to induce reparative angiogenesis, and neuronal dysfunction. There is also evidence that reparative angiogenesis is impaired in AD brains. We discovered that a mouse model expressing Presenilin1 Familial AD (FAD) mutant shows decreased ischemia-induced angiogenesis and angiogenic protein complexes and increased neuronal death in the brain. Furthermore, endothelial cells (ECs) of these mutant brains have decreased response to angiogenic factor EphB4. Successful completion of this project will identify novel molecular mechanisms of toxicity-induced brain angiogenesis and will test whether these mechanisms are impaired in AD. In addition, the project will test whether a novel pro-angiogenic peptide that rescues angiogenic functions of FAD ECs, promotes brain neovascularization and increases neuronal survival against toxic insults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In the course of development, epithelial tissues must be able to dynamically remodel their dimensions to generate adult tissue morphologies, as well as permit new cells to replace aging cells. The intention of the proposed study is to examine the processes that permit directed cell movements within an epithelial context. We are using a combination of computational and cell biological approaches to determine how membrane ratcheting mechanisms permit the processive contraction of individual cellular surfaces.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance: Atherosclerosis is a progressive inflammatory cardiovascular disease that remains the leading cause of death in the USA and worldwide in spite of widespread use of statins, other lipid lowering strategies, and life-style modifications. Remarkably, despite decades of research, little is known about late stage lesion development and mechanisms that result in the rupture or erosion of the protective fibrous cap overlying advanced atherosclerotic lesions leading to catastrophic thrombotic events including a heart attack (i.e. myocardial infarction) or stroke. Studies in this proposal will define the cell types and mechanisms that form the fibrous cap with the goal of identifying novel therapeutic approaches for promoting formation of a thicker and mechanically more robust fibrous cap (i.e. analogous to a patch on a tire) thereby reducing the probability of lesion rupture or erosion with a possible heart attack or stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is an aggressive form of the disease with few treatment options, high recurrence rates and disproportionately higher mortality rates. This proposal involves elucidating the mechanisms by which estrogen receptor beta (ERβ) elicits potent anti-cancer effects in TNBC and determining the utility of specifically targeting this receptor, alone and in combination with established chemotherapy regimens, for therapeutic purposes. Results of the proposed study are expected to contribute to the development of a new class of therapies, and allow for better stratification of patients to specific forms of chemotherapy, ultimately resulting in improved outcomes for thousands of patients each year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: In patients with urinary stone disease, several knowledge gaps persist regarding the impact of fluid therapy in preventing stone recurrence, and the optimal care after insertion of a ureteral stent (a thin tube inserted into the ureter to prevent obstruction of the urine flow from the kidney). This application will address these gaps by assessing the effectiveness and safety of new behavioral strategies to increase urine fluid intake, and evaluating factors contributing to discomfort following stent insertion, with the ultimate goal of improving patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative In response to large numbers of senior center clients who suffer untreated depression and the dearth of geriatric mental health providers, we have simplified Behavioral Activation to be delivered by lay volunteers (“Do More, Feel Better”; DMFB). The focus of Behavioral Activation is to guide clients to reengage in daily pleasant and rewarding activities, and reduce depressive symptoms. If we can show that the lay delivery model has positive impact in comparison to MSW-delivered Behavioral Activation, we will have identified an effective intervention that can be used by a large untapped workforce of older adult volunteers across the nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: New targeted drugs have dramatically improved cancer survival however, many such cancer treatments have cardiovascular side effects. Specifically, new drugs for leukemia have improved life expectancy to match people without cancer but a higher than normal risk of heart attack and stroke has emerged in these leukemia survivors. This proposal uses multiple innovative technologies to understand how these new cancer drugs may contribute to heart attack and stroke and to develop ways to predict those side effects before exposing patients to the risk. In addition, we test new methods to identify co-treatments that might alleviate the heart disease risk in these cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Endometriosis is a clinically significant but poorly understood condition that affects the productivity and well- being of millions of women in their reproductive years. Our proposed research project will define a new Estrogen Receptor β-mediated gene network to understand the molecular mechanism of the inception and progression of endometriosis. This new conceptual advancement should provide new druggable targets to inhibit the survival and progression of endometriosis and reduce the side effects of current endometriosis treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Regions in the genome that are intolerant to new variation indicate potential functional importance and provide insights into genetic variation and disease. Despite the fact that clinical exome sequencing is increasingly used for diagnostic evaluation of patients with suspected Mendelian disorders and that rare variation has been shown to confer substantial disease risk in complex traits as well, a large percentage of Mendelian disorders remains unresolved and diagnostic rates of exome sequencing remains low. With the proposal of new statistical methods and user-friendly software implementations, this K01 aims to better account for ancestry and tissue-specific transcriptional intolerance to genetic variation in order to improve association mapping between genetic variation and disease and to ultimately advance precision medicine diagnostics and variant interpretation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Chronic kidney disease is a major public health concern, affecting over 37 million people in the US. In this project, we will study how mutations in myosin, a molecular motor protein, affect the ability of the kidneys to selectively filter out waste products. We will aim to identify approaches for activating myosin that can be used to preserve renal function or treat kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Potentially inappropriate medications (PIMs) among older adults (age ≥65 years) result in preventable adverse health events. This proposal seeks to describe the epidemiology of PIM use in multiple multi-ethnic study populations, factors associated with PIM use, and assess whether PIM use is associated with incident mild cognitive impairment or dementia and brain pathology. Successful completion of this proposed research will identify a potential modifiable exposure antecedent to Alzheimer’s disease and other related dementias (AD/RD). We believe that the identification of such an exposure will support interventions to reduce PIM use and prevent AD/RD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Smoking tobacco shortens the lifespan of adults with serious mental illness by 25 years and contributes to $317 billion in healthcare expenditures and indirect loss of earnings and disability benefits. This project proposes to test the efficacy of this new model in a multi-site randomized controlled trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Relevance to the mission of NIH The relevance of the current proposal to public health is based on extending and refining the knowledge of how the mammalian cortex works: understanding how specialized circuits in the brain are constructed and wired together provides the basis for understanding cortical function in general. Understanding the basic cortical organization of the normal brain is essential, as it provides the standard against which it can be judged which processes can be seen to be altered or damaged and subsequently treated in disorders that affect the cerebral cortex as in schizophrenia and dyslexia or sensory disorders such as central auditory processing disorders, amblyopia and neurodevelopmental disorders that impact somatosensory processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (3 SENTENCES) We are in dire need to determine if higher protein intake, above the current recommendation (0.8/kg/d), can produce long-lasting beneficial effects to prevent age-related loss of muscle mass and function in older adults. This proposal determines the long-term effects of higher protein intake on prevention of age-related mobility disability; and identifies if dietary proteins enhance mobility function by improving the gut bacterial composition and reducing inflammation in the body. Findings from this K01 can drive age-specific dietary recommendations, replacing the current one-size-fits-all approach, to enhance mobility function in older adults by improving gut health and inflammation; and the acquired skills will help the Principal Investigator to integrate omics (gut microbiome) and non-omics (dietary intake) data towards a long-term career goal to develop “Precision Nutrition” strategies and age-specific dietary advice to promote healthy aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cigarette smoking-related lung diseases like chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) remain a leading cause of death worldwide. We believe Lyve-1 positive peribronchial interstitial macrophages play a key role in promoting the pathologic thickening of the small airway walls in response to cigarette smoke and may be a potential therapeutic target to intervene in COPD pathogenesis. We will test the hypothesis that matrix metalloprotein 9 production in response to Lyve-1 on the IM surface binding to hyaluronic acid promotes airway wall remodeling and fibrosis after prolonged cigarette smoke exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Recovery from acute kidney injury (AKI) is often incomplete and leaves behind a kidney that is prone to develop chronic kidney disease (CKD). The proposed research will explore how various functions of the kidney are regulated and evolve as the kidney recovers from AKI and how the evolution and ultimate outcome are affected by pre-existing CKD, standard medical treatments including angiotensin blockade, changes in dietary NaCl, and inhibitors of the principle kidney glucose transporter, SGLT2. Experiments will employ standard rat models of AKI where key variables can be measured that cannot be measured in human subjects.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell competition, the process of eliminating viable but “less fit” neighbor cells, has been proposed as a surveillance mechanism to ensure normal development and also has been suggested to act as a barrier to interspecies chimerism. We uncovered a previously unknown mode of cell competition between pluripotent stem cells from different species. This project aims to decipher the underlying molecular mechanisms and develop effective strategy to enable interspecies organogenesis by suppressing interspecies cell competition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An unmet clinical need exists for new therapeutic concepts in lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD), the most common subtype of lung cancer. We hypothesize that progression, phenotypic heterogeneity, proliferative potential and treatment resistance in LUAD arise from a subset of cancer cells that acquire a high-plasticity cell state (HPCS). In this study we interrogate the function and molecular drivers of the HPCS in LUAD tumors, which may inform future therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We propose the development of a new non-invasive method that may be used to optimize and monitor treatment responses in patients that are receiving CAR-T cell therapy. The approach is relatively simple and the instrumentation amenable to miniaturization. Thus, if successful, it should be possible to translate the technology to the clinic or as point of care device for monitoring human patients with the frequency that is needed to optimize therapeutic outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Up to 70% of the 650,000 of cancer patients treated with chemotherapy will develop chemotherapy induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) that results in poor compliance, decreased quality of life, higher recurrence rates, and increased healthcare costs. Despite advances in therapeutic agents, paclitaxel remains one of the primary treatments of choice in hormone resistant breast cancer yet it continues to induce one of the highest incidences of CIPN. As there are currently no effective treatments for CIPN, the over-arching hypothesis of this proposal is that we have discovered that an existing drug used in treatment of other conditions, can be used to decrease or prevent CIPN caused by treatment with paclitaxel.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We discovered the ability of urinary tract pathogen Proteus mirabilis to rapidly kill competitors like Escherichia coli in a previously unknown contact-dependent manner. We propose to identify the killing system and its regulation, define the mechanism of action, and elucidate its role for competition with E. coli during polymicrobial infections of the urinary tract in vivo. Results of this proposal will add an additional mechanism of how P. mirabilis is able to establish dominance in the urinary tract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The kidney local microenvironment comprises diverse cell types, factors, and structural components—certain to be instrumental for kidney maintenance and repair—yet very little is known about how these components affect acute kidney injury (AKI). We have determined that a protein expressed soon after AKI organizes a favorable microenvironment to facilitate cell-matrix interactions and repair injured kidneys by recruiting a powerful growth factor. Deeply exploring these and other features of cell-matrix interactions in AKI will be greatly beneficial for constructing an AKI early warning system and designing novel therapeutic strategies to prevent or mitigate AKI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The benefits of kidney and liver transplantation should be available to all Americans, but geographic, racial/ethnic, gender, and other disparities, plus a shortage of transplantable organs, have frustrated that promise. The Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network has resolved to eliminate geographic boundaries to reduce geographic disparity through implementation of a continuous allocation score (CAS), but choosing weights indiscriminately in a CAS system could easily introduce unintended consequences. We propose to use iterated simulations to: 1) design CAS weights to increase transplant benefit without creating unintended new disparities; 2) modify the CAS to achieve the greatest possible equity in allocation; and 3) modify the CAS to decrease discard of transplantable organs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States and especially in Southern California, new cases of HIV continue to accrue, especially among those who identify as having minority racial/ethnic and/or sexual/gender status. New approaches that integrate combination biomedical, behavioral, technological and structural interventions offer exciting possibilities to significantly reduce HIV transmission, especially in key populations of people living with HIV or at risk with co-occurring mental health and substance use disorders and/or barriers in access to social and structural determinants of health. The Center for HIV Identification, Prevention, and Treatment Services (CHIPTS) mobilizes world class leaders and affected communities in the areas of science, networking and capacity building to lead the HIV prevention agenda both in the U.S. and internationally, particularly in addressing these comorbidities among those living with or at risk for HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE An ideal therapeutic for chronic wounds must address the impairment of the host immune response while also possessing antibacterial activity whereby due to the high prevalence of chronic wound-related amputations and mortality, the need for this dual-action therapeutic is urgent. We have recently begun to develope NO-releasing glycosaminoglycan biopolymers whose multi-faceted roles will allow for a wound healing therapeutic that: 1) eradicates common wound pathogens with minimal toxicity to cells and tissues; 2) modulates wound-related inflammation; and, 3) promotes re-epithelialization to facilitate wound closure. Here we will build upon our previous successes in developing NO-releasing therapeutics and understanding their benefits in wound healing to help populations afflicted by non-healing chronic wounds, including those with type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The fact that two different cancer patients can respond differently to the same therapy represents an important problem in cancer treatment. Using in depth analysis of responsive and unresponsive tumors, we have identified a novel target with the potential to help those with non-responsive tumors. We use unique and high quality preclinical models to evaluate the impact of this target on outcome, and use advanced analysis of tumors to understand the molecular regulation of the target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Failure of pancreatic β cells underlies the progression of all forms of diabetes. We investigate critical functions of the transcription factor and diabetes gene PDX1 through intra-molecular regulation of protein stability, and inter-molecular interactions regulating subcellular/subnuclear localization, in part through phase separation. The results from these studies will deepen our fundamental understanding of Pdx1 and help to design better strategies to generate and expand β cells in vitro and in vivo, with the potential to identify new nodes for intervention to prevent or delay the onset of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: Tumor cells rely upon glutamine-dependent metabolic pathways as well as serine/glycine/methionine-driven one-carbon metabolic pathway for their proliferation and growth; the amino acid transporter SLC38A5 supplies these four amino acids to triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells. As TNBC has no effective targeted therapy, our goal is to show using in vitro studies with cell lines and in vivo studies with appropriate preclinical mouse models that pharmacologic blockade of SLC38A5 is a logical approach for targeted treatment of TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Lung cancer is a global scourge responsible for 1.5 million patient deaths worldwide, and ~130,000 patient deaths in the USA this year alone. Despite these grim statistics, lung cancer treatment has been revolutionized by the fundamental scientific understanding that lung cancers can be genetically subdivided based on the presence of specific proto-oncogene mutations that, in turn, predict for responsiveness to FDA-approved pathway-targeted therapies. Here, we propose the use of experimental/preclinical models of KRAS- or BRAF-driven lung cancer in combination with inhibitors of cellular signaling pathways to define the importance of key pathways in lung cancer initiation, progression and therapy, with the overarching goal of developing a rational scientific foundation for the development of new combination therapy strategies to more effectively treat lung cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Many patients do not respond to immunotherapies, including immune checkpoint blockade (ICB), because their tumors are not sufficiently immunogenic, and thus go undetected by their immune systems. In this proposal, we outline a new small-molecule approach to increasing the immunogenicity of tumors by harnessing a recently-discovered inflammatory cell death modality, which we term nuclear necroptosis. The successful completion of the proposed research will outline an entirely new strategy to activate a highly inflammatory form of necroptosis and potentiate ICB-based immunotherapies, with important clinical ramifications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes mellitus occurs when pancreatic beta cells fail. We have discovered that the Atf6 transcription factor, which is activated by endoplasmic reticulum stress and has been linked to human diabetes risk, increases beta cell proliferation in mouse and human beta cells. However, Atf6 activation also has harmful effects under certain conditions; this project will explore the molecular mechanisms driving benefits and harms of Atf6 activation, which we hope will form the basis for new approaches to keep beta cells thriving to prevent diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac sympathetic structural and functional changes are associated with cardiac sympathetic overactivity and arrhythmia during the progression of heart failure. This proposal will determine activation of satellite glial cells and macrophage in cardiac sympathetic ganglia and their role in cardiac sympathetic structural and functional alterations, and test the therapeutic effects of light stimulation-triggered satellite glial silencing and macrophage- related immunomodulation on ventricular arrhythmias and cardiac abnormalities in chronic heart failure. The significance of this research program is to provide the potential targets for improving cardiac sympathetic function and prognosis in patients with advanced heart failure.
