IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Fragile X Syndrome (FXS), the most frequent monogenic cause of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), results from deficiency in the Fragile X Mental Retardation Protein (FMRP) which alters cellular protein synthesis and produces an overgrowth of neurons and synaptic connections accompanied by cognitive and behavioral phenotypes. Molecular mechanisms coupling the FMRP protein to specific programs of protein synthesis which could underlie FXS-associated deficits are incompletely understood. In this proposal, we use mouse and human models to conduct a genome-wide investigation of post-transcriptional gene regulation by small RNA pathways which serve as network regulators of specificity in protein synthesis, and seek to define the potential for manipulation of these pathways to impact phenotypes resulting from the loss of FMRP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative This proposal will study the molecular mechanisms that connect neurons together to form synapses. We will focus on how specific molecules direct the assembly of pain-processing circuits in the spinal cord to better understand how these processes are altered in neurodevelopmental disorders and go awry during the development chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The proposed research uses computational modeling and neuroimaging to examine how episodic memory and reinforcement learning contribute to decision-making and choice behavior across the lifespan. In doing so, this research can inform development of targeted interventions that can improve age-related declines in learning and decision making behaviors for healthy older adults and various clinical populations. Findings from this research will provide important insights into helping older adults and individuals with learning and memory impairments due to neurological disorders or age-related cognitive dysfunction such as stroke, Alzheimers disease, and related dementias by identifying specific areas in memory and reinforcement learning that can be improved.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African American women are two to three times more likely than European American women to get the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer, but the reasons for this disparity are not well understood. This project investigates how chemical exposures to which African American women are disproportionately exposed may promote the development of aggressive breast cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In order to meet the growing demands for organs suitable for kidney transplantation, novel methods are needed to assess the quality donor kidneys. This project aims to bring new tools to transplant professionals to improve our ability to evaluate donor kidneys, reduce organ discard of suitable kidneys and increase deceased donor kidney transplantation. Additionally, we will advance our understanding of donor kidney biology from a more genetically and racially diverse patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Asthma exacerbations are responsible for the major health impacts associated with the disease, and increased air pollution from wildfire smoke is a major contributor to exacerbations. Patients with asthma experience variable sensitivity to air pollution, and public health recommendations fail to appropriately target high risk patients. Using primary human tissue culture, next-generation sequencing-based techniques and bioinformatic tools, we will characterize genetic risk factors that connect wildfire air pollution with asthma exacerbations and identify mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets for pollution-associated asthma exacerbations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The kidney has a limited ability to repair that primarily relies on scattered tubular-like cells (STCs), which can proliferate and their progeny re-differentiate into tubular epithelial cells to replace lost neighboring injured tubular cells. Experimental RAS impairs the reparative capacity of swine STCs by damaging their mitochondria, but the processes underpinning RAS-induced STC mitochondrial damage remain unclear. The proposed studies will determine the mechanisms by which increased expression of the mitochondria-related microRNA miR-181c in RAS-STCs compromises STC mitochondrial structure and function, and their contribution to STC function and reparative capacity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: NARRATIVE Analysis of multiple myeloma (MM) patients (n=815) from across the disease spectrum reveals Unc-51 Like Kinase-3 (ULK3) as being significantly expressed in newly diagnosed and refractory MM and, our emerging studies define ULK3 as a key regulator of autophagy and MM cell viability in vitro. Excitingly, our team has developed novel ULK3 inhibitors (SG3/MA9) that rapidly inhibit autophagy and can also block the activity of the bromodomain containing protein 4 (BRD4), which is also expressed in refractory MM and is an important driver of the MYC oncogenic program. Based on preliminary in vitro and in vivo studies demonstrating the efficacy of SG3/MA9 for the treatment of naïve and refractory MM, the proposed studies herein for the first time will define the role of ULK3 in MM progression and test the efficacy of novel dual BRD4/ULK3 inhibitors in treating MM and resensitizing resistant disease to standard of care therapies using in vitro and in vivo approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The residual inflammatory risk for atherothrombotic events is common even in people with well-controlled cholesterol levels. Therefore, the identification of novel targets that control chronic inflammation is of critical importance in the cardiovascular research field. Emerging evidence shows that failed resolution of chronic inflammation is an important driving force for atherosclerotic plaque progression; hence, the goal of our proposed study is to uncover novel mechanisms that contribute to impaired resolution of inflammation as well as strengthened inflammation in progressing plaques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Difficulties in managing emotions contribute to the development and maintenance of affective and stress disorders, and, therefore, constitute a significant public health problem in need of novel, rapid interventions. To address this transdiagnostic need, we plan to characterize neural changes that result from practice of emotion regulation skills enhanced with neurostimulation targeted towards the emotion regulation network. The findings of this study will be used to refine a combined psychotherapy and brain stimulation intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative This project aims to improve understanding of the impacts of the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) on the provision and utilization of formal care for older adults with and without Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias (AD/ADRD). It uses advanced empirical methods and two large, nationally representative data sets and leverage a large number of plausibly exogeneous policy changes in the EITC at the federal and state levels in the past two decades that may induce changes in formal care for older adults. The findings from this project will provide valuable information to policymakers interested in designing effective population-level policies to support formal care providers, especially the most vulnerable low-income care providers who bear the heaviest burdens of caregiving but have not been a focus of research in the past.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic HIV infection causes T cell exhaustion resulting in impaired control of the ongoing viral infection as well as increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections. Mechanisms that regulate exhaustion are not yet fully characterize. In this study, we will determine pathways involved in energy metabolism in T cells during chronic HIV and reveal their role in T cell exhaustion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: Project Narrative There is a growing interest in the different types of non-canonical translation, including repeat associated non- AUG translation which is associated with RNA structure, translation in multiple frames and microsatellite expansion diseases. Having identified other forms of multi-frame non-canonical translation outside of RAN translation, the overarching goal of this proposal is to determine the RNA structures, protein networks and therapeutically relevant modifiers that govern different types of multi-frame translation. Together this information will provide a deeper understanding of the mechanism of multi-frame translation and the processes that govern human cellular proteome diversity, which in turn will enable informed therapy development across multiple microsatellite expansion diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative A deficit in cerebral blood flow hemodynamics is an early feature of cerebral small vessel disease—a leading cause of stroke and age-related cognitive decline—which suggests that cerebrovascular dysfunction has a key role in disease pathogenesis. Here we describe how some pericytes (cells that wrap around the capillaries) constrict in response to blood pressure to adjust blood flow through the dense capillary network, and demonstrate that this mechanism is disrupted in a mouse model of small vessel disease, leading to loss of blood flow control. Therefore, this work may identify novel targets on pericytes for therapies aimed at protecting or restoring blood flow in small vessel disease conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The next generation of genetically engineered T cell therapies for cancers will depend on synthetic programs that enhance their potency and persistence. We recently performed high-throughput studies to discover genes that enhance T cell stimulation-dependent responses and enhance their functional persistence. Here, we will use a systematic approach to evaluate how these genes – and synthetic DNA constructs that integrate them into novel circuits that respond to stimulation by cancer targets – alter the ability of engineered T cells to treat cancer in multiple preclinical models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The long-term goal of this research is to elucidate the mechanisms by which cardiovascular risk factors lead to increased risk for dementia with aging. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE  A muscle’s internal structure is an important determinant of its function. Advanced magnetic resonance imaging methods offer the potential for assessing these functions, but require development. We will create new capabilities for studying muscle structure and function non-invasively, in health and disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a debilitating chronic gastrointestinal disease for which there is a large unmet clinical need. The enzyme glutamate carboxypeptidase II (GCPII) is robustly overexpressed in IBD and its inhibition is therapeutic in multiple preclinical animal models. The work in this proposal will improve our understanding of GCPII dysregulation and function in human and mouse IBD and will inform efforts to develop targeted GCPII inhibitors for clinical IBD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Periodontal disease affects millions of individuals in the US alone and is known to greatly increase susceptibility to many other systemic diseases. Oral bacterial pathogens are clearly involved in their pathogenesis, but the role of systemic master regulators, such as microRNAs, and the innate immune pathway are not completely known. This proposal works with selected dominant microRNAs as important biomarkers in periodontal disease with the long term goal in guiding therapeutic interventions and moving toward better disease management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Metalloenzymes are the worker bees for energy generation, metabolism, signaling and pharmaceutical processing in all cells and often their misfunction can be the cause of human disease. Despite the prevalence and importance of metalloproteins, our level of understanding of the relationship between protein structure and efficient metal ion catalysis is still badly lacking. This proposal uses the innovative technique of de novo metalloprotein design to unravel the key factors that are essential to defining and controlling metal based biological catalysis, with the long term goals of understanding human disease better and providing bioinspired water soluble catalysts for chemical and pharmaceutical industries.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The purpose of this award is to support the research, training and service activities of Dr. Courtney Van Houtven, who is an experienced Department of Veterans Affairs investigator. Dr. Van Houtven leads research studies that test care models to improve the function and independence of older adults with functional limitations and the function of their informal caregivers. The overarching goal of her research agenda is to enable at-risk Veterans to remain at home as safely as possible and for as long as possible. This research is important because there are 9.8 million Veterans over age 65 and 5.5 million Veterans receive informal care in order to remain at home. Dr. Van Houtven’s research will continue to study how we can best provide care for Veterans at risk of permanent nursing home entry, including the best means of supporting their caregivers.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is prevalent among Veterans and effective evidence-based psychotherapies (EBPs) for PTSD have been implemented within the Veterans Health Administration (VHA). However, retention in PTSD EBPs is poor. Premature dropout is associated with worse clinical outcomes and greater healthcare utilization. Delivery of PTSD EBPs in a massed format, typically three or more days per week delivered within a month, have shown promise for increasing retention. This CDA-2 proposal is highly relevant because PTSD is a VA and HSR&D priority. Additionally, if effective, massed treatment delivery would offer another option for Veterans to access PTSD treatment, which would increase patient-centered care. Increased retention in PTSD EBPs would also better utilize provider and system resources by increasing the number of Veterans who receive an adequate dose of a PTSD EBP.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Seriously-ill veterans rely on spiritual and existential beliefs to cope with their illness, support their quality of life, and make critical decisions about their care. VHA Directive 1111mandates that assessment must identify the importance of spirituality and religion for the patient, how it affects care, and comprehensive follow up, when needed. To assist in compliance with this mandate our research team developed and validated the first quantifiable spiritual screening tool (VET-Spirit) designed specifically for seriously-ill veterans. It offers the means to identify needs, resources and the impact of beliefs on care and decision-making. The proposed study develops and evaluates the feasibility and acceptability of integrating VET-Spirit into care. While our ultimate goal is to improve unmet veteran spiritual needs, this proposal focuses on provider outcomes (physicians and advanced practice providers) of those with advanced serious illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chemoenzymatic synthesis of bacterial nonulosonic acids and glycans The efficient chemoenzymatic methods developed in this proposal will allow the access of bacterial nonulosonic acids and glycans which are virulence factors of pathogenic bacteria. The glycans produced can be anti-bacteria vaccine candidates and essential probes to identify the corresponding antibodies and protein binders. Information will also be learned regarding biosynthesis of these important bacterial virulence factors and facilitate in the future development of inhibitors as potential antibiotics.

PHR: Narrative: In order to gain insight into the mechanistic underpinnings of diseases at a molecular level, deciphering structure/function relationships of biological molecules encompasses one of the key objectives of biomedical research. The compelling need for greater chemical insight has motivated my group’s effort to develop innovative mass spectrometry methods to characterize structures of biological molecules, particularly lipids, proteins, and macromolecular assemblies, in unprecedented detail.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Over 100 million Americans and approximately 50% of U.S. military Veterans suffer from chronic pain. Research indicates a strong, bidirectional link between chronic pain conditions and internalizing psychiatric disorders and individuals with both chronic pain conditions and internalizing disorders show worse treatment prognosis, increased impairment, and greater use of opioid medication. While the association between chronic pain and internalizing disorders is well documented, the underlying mechanisms that drive the association remain elusive. This CDA-2 project will use electronic health record and genetic data from the Million Veterans Program to identify the genetic factors common to the development of these conditions and sets the stage for progression from genetic epidemiology to precision medicine. Improved understanding of the mechanism underlying this relationship can reduce negative consequences such as opiate use, healthcare costs and societal burden, and improve access to care for Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Visual object motion often guides the movements of humans and insects alike. However, sensorimotor integration is a computationally challenging task, as it requires the brain to transform its representation of space from visual-centric coordinates to body-centric coordinates. My work aims to shed light on this fundamental mechanism by studying a neural network in the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster that is well-positioned to perform such an inference during object chasing behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related death across all major populations in the U.S.; however, risk of lung cancer is not the same across racial/ethnic groups. To better understand the underlying mechanisms contributing to lung cancer racial/ethnic disparities, we will conduct a molecular profiling study of lung adenocarcinoma tissue from five major racial/ethnic groups. Our findings will help identify personalized treatment targets and strategies to mitigate these disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disparities in cardiovascular diseases (CVD) abound. There is growing evidence that social determinants of health across several domains and levels of influence over the life course can play a role in producing such disparities in CVD. We propose to apply several analytic approaches including key informant interviews, the synthetic control method and systems science to evaluate the impact and costs of intervention strategies that have the potential to efficiently reduce CVD health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary goal of this proposal is to identify the activity-dependent mechanisms mediating memory formation in the CA3 region of the hippocampus. Learning and memory is driven by activity-induced changes in neurons and circuits, and the CA3 region of the hippocampus is particularly important in linking sensory experiences to the context in which they occur. Understanding how CA3 neurons change during the formation of a contextual memory will provide us with valuable foundational knowledge of proper cognitive function, and will allow us to further investigate cases of cognitive disorders.

PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic Kidney Disease is a global health epidemic and is associated with increased mortality, but we do not have a detailed understanding of why this disease progresses. Identifying sub-types of patients who progress by the same molecular mechanism is important to identify patients for future clinical trials. This project aims to use gene expression data from kidney biopsies to identify patients who will respond differently to medications that increase the expression of Hypoxia Inducible Factor-1 alpha.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative The U.S. is in the midst of a psychostimulant epidemic. Drug-craving is a diagnostic criterion of Psychostimulant Use Disorder for which there exists no clinically effective intervention. This project examines disrupted glutamate- dopamine interactions within prefrontal cortex as a core neuropathology driving drug-craving.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance  Dioxygen binding and activation by metalloproteins are processes that are directly  linked to the maintenance of human health and aging. The protein-induced  microenvironments surrounding the active metal center(s) are instrumental in  regulating these functions, and the function and dysfunction of health-related  metalloproteins can therefore be understood in the context of changes in their  microenvironments. Non-covalent interactions, including hydrogen bonds, are  acknowledged as the major forces that control microenvironmental effects, but it is still  unclear how they are able to influence metal-mediated processes. Thus, understanding  the influence of these effects requires fundamental reactivity and mechanistic studies in  which the contributions of single components can be analyzed individually, as described  in this research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic, inflammatory disease of the central nervous system that produces disabil- ity through immune-mediated demyelination and subsequent neuro-axonal injury. Neuroprotective therapies that prevent neuro-axonal loss independent of peripheral immune effects are a major goal of current research, both to complement current therapies and to slow disability in the progressive phase of MS, which is no longer driven by peripheral immune activation. This proposal evaluates a candidate signaling pathway that may pro- mote neuro-axonal injury in neuroinflammation, while establishing the pre-clinical potential of a brain-penetrant drug that selectively blocks this pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal offers an unparalleled opportunity to characterize the biological impact of aspirin, perhaps the most promising widely available chemopreventive agent, and the gut microbiome on the normal colon by leveraging the uniquely valuable resources of a randomized clinical trial. To accomplish this objective, we will advance novel patient-derived modeling systems to rigorously investigate putative chemopreventive mechanisms and refine causal relationships between aspirin, the gut microbiome, and intestinal epithelial cells. Ultimately, this work may lead to novel chemoprevention targets and the development of precision prevention strategies for chronic digestive diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because fibrosis (the scarring of injured tissue) plays a major role in the development and progression of heart disease – the leading cause of death among Americans. PHR: Project Narrative: Endothelial cell dysfunction occurs early during aneurysm formation and may contribute to the failure of aneurysm treatment. Upon conclusion of this study, we will have an understanding of the role of IL-2 activated mTOR in endothelial cell dysfunction leading to aneurysm formation, progression and rupture. The expected positive impact of this multi-disciplinary research is that by enhancing our understanding and prevention of endothelial cell dysfunction in aneurysm pathogenesis, clinicians will have novel medical therapies, imaging modalities, and minimally invasive endovascular devices for the successful treatment of cerebral aneurysms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to develop and validate a core echocardiography artificial intelligence platform designed to extract the full density of information present in a standard echocardiogram. Echocardiography is a ubiquitous imaging modality, and such a system has an immediate impact on how we manage heart failure – a disease that affects an estimated 6.5 million people in the United States alone. Using our ECHO AI platform, we propose to build tools for surgical decision support and survival forecasting in patients with heart failure, and early screening tools to identify individuals at high risk of developing heart failure in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Women of reproductive age experience rhythmic changes in sex hormone levels over the monthly menstrual cycles. These hormonal changes impact female brain structure and function and are likely to confer female- specific risks for neuropsychiatric disorders such as anxiety and depression, which are more prevalent in women than in men. This project uses an animal model to reveal molecular (epigenetic) mechanisms through which sex hormones dynamically affect female brain and behavior, facilitating the development of sex-specific treatments for mental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Currently, more than 15 million people in North America suffer from age-related macular degeneration (AMD), and the overall prevalence of this disease is projected to increase by over 50% by the end of 2020. The pathogenesis of AMD causes irreversible blindness, and there are currently no effective treatment options for the most common (nonexudative or “dry”) form of the disease. Therefore, this proposal aims to open new therapeutic avenues for the treatment of AMD, by identifying novel phosphodiesterase-modulating compounds and characterizing the signaling pathways through which they exert their cytoprotective effects in the context of retinal degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Extracellular vesicles (EVs) are present in circulation at a relatively early stage of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The long-term goal of this R01 proposal is to develop a new HCC EV digital scoring assay for non- invasively detecting early-stage HCC. The successful development of the proposed assay will be rapidly translatable and reproducible, enabling a sensitive and biologically relevant EV-based quantitative assay for detecting HCC at an early stage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The microbiota of cancer patients is correlated with their response to immunotherapy drugs, but the mechanisms of specific commensal bacteria strains have not been elucidated and limit their translation into new therapeutics. The Hang laboratory recently discovered that beneficial Enterococci strains have unique peptidoglycan composition and remodeling enzymes. These exciting findings reveal fundamental microbiota mechanisms in cancer immunotherapy and afford new opportunities to engineer probiotic bacteria and synthesize immunomodulatory metabolite analogs to improve cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Flu infection claims thousands of lives every year despite the currently available treatments and vaccinations. We have identified a host cellular protein that facilitates viral replication and contributes flu severity. The proposed studies will elucidate the role of this host protein in viral replication, which can lead to new therapeutic targets to reduce influenza A virus (IAV) infection and disease progression in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative We will develop and disseminate innovative new technology for measuring precise 3D kinematics in freely moving animals over long time-periods. Our proposed experimental platform will illuminate how natural behaviors are organized and help us understand how they are controlled by the nervous system, and how this control goes awry in disease. The technological leap made possible by this grant will catalyze a host of studies on the neural mechanisms underlying motor control, learning, and mental disorders, and thus help in the discovery of new diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for afflicted patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a major concern in our communities, with an annual incidence of clinically significant TBI at 2-3 millions. The commonest neuropathology encountered across various types and degrees of severity of TBI is diffuse or traumatic axonal injury, i.e. deformation of axons caused by the mechanical forces of injury. Subsequent to this, many axons turn on a self-destruction program that takes apart brain connections and systems. Here we propose that blocking molecules that drive this program saves axons and protects brain connections and functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to use transgenic Drosophila melanogaster (fruit flies) and mice, to define the mechanisms by which post-translational modifications to actin modulate thin filament and cardiac contractile regulation. We will also scrutinize new fly models of actin and troponin-T-based cardiomyopathies to determine the molecular defects that drive distinct forms of adverse myocardial remodeling. Finally, we will ascertain if specific actin post- translational modifications improve or exacerbate heart muscle diseases caused by an array of mutations in the contractile machinery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In studies involving the Medalist cohort, composed of people with insulin-dependent diabetes for ≥50 years, as well as their donated retinal tissues, we have identified a retina-specific protein, retinol binding protein 3 (RBP3), which can neutralize the toxic effects of hyperglycemia and diabetes on the retinal tissues and blood vessels. In this application, we will evaluate whether retinal and serum RBP3 levels correlate with severity of diabetic retinopathy in a wide range of patients, and investigate the regulation of its expression and its protective mechanisms on retinal cells. These findings have identified RBP3 as a potential new therapeutic agent for diabetic retinopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuroplasticity is an essential characteristic of the respiratory neural control system; imparting flexibility in respiratory responses to internal physiological changes or external environmental challenges across the lifespan. Yet, despite considerable research defining the cellular and molecular mechanisms of respiratory neuroplasticity over the past three decades, we still know very little about sex differences or the specific role of sex hormones in the development of respiratory neuroplasticity. To address this gap in basic biological knowledge and support on-going translational studies devising novel ways to manipulate mechanisms of neuroplasticity for therapeutic benefit, our project investigates the mechanisms by which sex hormones, and specifically 17β-estradiol (the most abundant and neuroactive sex hormone in females), enable the development of respiratory motor plasticity in both females and males.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The opioid epidemic continues despite the availability of medications that substitute for (methadone and buprenorphine) or block (naltrexone) most of the abuse-related effects of opioids, underscoring the need for new and better treatments. We hypothesize that the nonpsychoactive cannabinoid, cannabidiol (CBD) will be effective in treating various dimensions of opioid use disorder, including drug taking, relapse, and emergence of withdrawal. These studies in nonhuman primates complement and expand significantly recent promising results with CBD in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells store lipids in specialized compartments called lipid droplets (LDs), which have numerous roles including energy reservoirs and platforms for metabolic reactions. LDs are made at specific sub-regions within the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), the metabolic center of cells, but how LDs and the ER network organize themselves to achieve all of their diverse functions is mechanistically unclear. This work will dissect how LDs and the ER network spatially compartmentalize their metabolic reactions, and achieve the functional diversity necessary for cells to maintain homeostasis, which is defective in disease states such as heart disease and atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The estimated effectiveness of the influenza vaccine in the U.S. for the 2018-2019 influenza season in older adults (≥65 years) was only 12-13%, demonstrating an urgent need to develop new approaches to improve influenza vaccine responsiveness in this high-risk population who constitute 90% of the 36,000+ annual U.S. influenza deaths. In this project, we will recruit and longitudinally follow a cohort of 60 older adults, who will receive 3 different influenza vaccines over 3 subsequent influenza seasons, including the most commonly used vaccine Fluzone® High-Dose and the first FDA-approved adjuvanted influenza vaccine, FLUAD®. By performing comprehensive profiling of their blood antibodies and immune cells over time, we will be able to associate specific age-related immune alterations with vaccine responder or non-responder status, thus allowing us to pinpoint biological pathways that can be targeted to enhance vaccine efficacy and that can also help us to progress towards developing a universal influenza vaccine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Through the proposed study we hope to identify epigenomic markers of a dangerous and relatively common pregnancy-related condition called preeclampsia. During a preeclampsia pregnancy, babies are at risk for preterm delivery and low birthweight while mothers can suffer cardiovascular problems and even death. Finding genomic markers could allow doctors to diagnose preeclampsia early in pregnancy so they can treat the symptoms of the condition before long-term adverse effects occur to the mother and/or baby.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adherence to prescribed medication regimens is critical to optimize both cognitive and physical health among older adults with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) and other comorbid conditions, but is especially difficult in the context of multidrug regimens. Little is known about how older adults with ADRD self- manage their medications, how these responsibilities transition to caregivers as the disease progresses, how capable caregivers are to fulfill these responsibilities, and how ambulatory care practices support patients and caregivers to ensure safe medication use and adherence. This study will examine medication self-management behaviors among older adults with ADRD and multiple chronic conditions and their caregivers to inform patient- centered interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kidney birth defects, which account for 25% of all birth defects in humans, are the leading cause of chronic renal disease in children and young adults. In the absence of curative treatment, patients rely on dialysis and kidney transplantation and consequently have significant shorter lifespan. In this project, we will model kidney birth defects to study the mechanisms that cause abnormal differentiation of renal cells, with the intention that this knowledge will advance the application of therapeutic strategies that depends on stem cell regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no available cures. The intestine contains trillions of bacteria that influence many aspects of health and disease, and we have found that by affecting the bacteria in the gut in models of ALS, can alter disease progression. We will identify potential protective factors provided by the microbiota and investigate the immune mechanisms by which they act in hopes of identifying new therapeutic targets for treatment of ALS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative During the development, mammalian cells undergo a series of cellular and molecular events that lead to the erasure and re-establishment of epigenetic programs. It is postulated that the active erasure and the re- establishment of DNA methylation marks during germ line differentiation, T-cell differentiation and brain development from fetus to young adult involve dynamic changes of methylated cytsoine into oxidative marks, and that these modified cytosine residues in DNA are recognized by specific transcription factors with distinct roles in the maintenance of epigenetic memory. A detailed biochemical and structural analyses of generation, recognition, alteration and erasure of these marks should shed light on this issue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Liver metastases are common in colorectal cancer and knowledge of number, location and size impacts precision of therapy, survival and overall costs. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is commonly used for evaluating liver metastases but detection and diagnosis of small tumors remains challenging. Our proposal is based on a collaborative integrated team of university scientists, clinician-scientists and industry engineers to develop and clinically trial new MRI technology that overcomes limitations related to imaging small liver tumors in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Pain and sickle cell disease are so intimately intertwined, that African tribal words for the disease, spoken centuries before Herrick described sickle cell disease (SCD) in the western literature, are onomatopoeic for pain. In spite of it being almost one hundred years since Herrick's seminal report, the neurobiology of chronic pain in SCD is poorly understood. This program will apply cutting edge molecular, epigenetics and therapeutic tools for the study of mechanism and pharmacological treatment in well-characterized transgenic mouse models of sickle cell disease. Our long-term goal is to advance knowledge of the neurobiological mechanisms of chronic sickle cell pain and develop an effective pharmacologic treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Recent human studies report an emerging, novel relationship between the gut microbiome and its metabolites with the development of heart attacks and strokes. This application will determine whether these favorable effects are seen in individuals with type 2 diabetes who have a significantly different gut microbiota and microbiota metabolism than those without type 2 diabetes. Additionally, this application will serve as an excellent platform for mentoring post-doctoral fellows and junior faculty to learn how to conduct impactful patient-oriented human clinical translation research related to vascular biology.

PHR: Proposal Narrative Sighs are long, deep breaths essential for life by preventing lung collapse, and are regulated by hypoxia and sleep-wake states. The proposed studies will reveal the neural mechanisms of sighing in response to physiological conditions, and how these inputs are integrated. This work will provide novel insights on the neural basis of breathing pattern generation, and pave the way for developing targeted pharmacological treatments for breathing abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Allogeneic stem cell transplant (SCT) is a life-saving treatment for children with leukemia, immunodeficiencies, and other disorders of the hematopoietic system, yet its success is limited by aberrant or delayed development of the new immune system. The gastrointestinal tract microbiota, and microbiome disruption that occurs over the course of SCT, may predict or even contribute to the pathogenesis of these immune-related outcomes, including graft-versus-host disease and time to immune cell recovery. This study will further define the relationship between microbiome disruption and immunologic outcomes of SCT, laying the foundation to develop new biomarkers and therapeutic approaches to improve the success of this treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Anxiety disorders and ADHD are two of the most common forms of childhood mental illness, can be highly impairing, and both include disruptions in attention. The goal of this study is to provide an in-depth characterization of how attention-related brain networks operate differently in children with anxiety disorders, ADHD, and both anxiety and ADHD compared to children with neither of these disorders. The results of this study are likely to assist in developing new treatments for pediatric anxiety and ADHD based on targeting these network-level disruptions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer metastases to the leptomeninges (LM) are difficult to treat, create significant morbidity, and portend extremely poor survival. Our proposed work will define how malignant cells hijack developmental neuronal pathfinding mechanisms to enter the central nervous system. Our studies will provide new mechanistic insight into a poorly understood biologic phenomenon and a therapeutic approach to an area of high unmet clinical need.

PHR: Project Narrative  Identification of bacteria from intra-abdominal infections is needed to enable selection of an appropriate antibiotic, ideally within the first hour following diagnosis, but current methods impose long diagnostic delays that prevent effective drug selection. We propose a simple, inexpensive, and automated microwell array technology that will identify and quantify bacteria directly from intra- abdominal fluids within 10 min, meeting a critical unmet need for improving patient outcomes and reducing the spread of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Use of androgen deprivation therapy (ADT), which causes near-total loss of testosterone, has increased dramatically in elderly prostate cancer patients over the last decade. ADT is associated with a 2% to 5% loss of bone mineral density, which is accompanied by significant increases in falls, fractures, and sarcopenia with significant decreases in balance and muscle strength compared to prostate cancer patients not on ADT and age- matched men without cancer. High-dose vitamin D is a promising intervention that may prevent these ADT- related consequences; if found to be efficacious, it would be a safe, low-cost, widely available, non- pharmacologic treatment that could drastically improve the prevention of ADT-induced bone loss and change clinical practice paradigms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Consumption of sweetened beverages, media-viewing, and physical activity patterns are often established during early childhood, and family-based obesity interventions show effectiveness in shaping healthy behaviors and weight outcomes for young children, including Latino children. Missing from these interventions, however, are methods to increase accessibility and dissemination to multiple family caregivers. The proposed work will use a randomized study design to evaluate the impact a family-based early childhood obesity intervention for Latino families that incorporates evidence-based strategies of in-person childhood obesity interventions, mobile phones, and leverages important determinants of Latino health (e.g. familism, language) in order to decrease ethnic disparities in childhood obesity and cardiovascular risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metallosis is a condition where the tissue around implanted metal orthopedic devices is stained black by the metal released from the implants due to corrosion and can cause severe pain, tumor growth, and even heart issues. We will see if bacteria that live in the tissues cause this corrosion. The impact of this will be to give insight to how corrosion occurs in patients, thus leading to possible changes in clinical treatments, the necessity of new or modified materials, or changes to surgical procedures to reduce the risk of metallosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is the first known effort in Sub-Saharan Africa to examine modifiable risk and protective biobehavioral mechanisms driving the intergenerational effects of war on the mental health of offspring aged 7–24. This intergenerational research of child and youth mental health will have both domestic and global public health significance given current estimates of approximately 79.5 million forcibly displaced people including refugees, internally displaced persons, and asylum seekers worldwide; an estimated 30–34 million (38–43%) are children under age 18. Many populations remain in proximity (within 31 miles) to war with approximately 368 million children and 265 million women living in areas affected by armed conflict. Potential findings may be valuable to United States Government efforts to improve security, human rights, and economic development in regions affected by armed conflict; and have implications for U.S. military personnel and their families as well as migrants and refugees from a variety of backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Intrathecal oxytocin is in clinical trials as an opioid alternative for chronic pain treatment. Our work in mice suggests that coupling intrathecal oxytocin with manual therapies (i.e. massage) optimizes the analgesic properties of oxytocin. This project provides the framework to support this combination therapy by concentrating on the spinal cord circuit mechanisms by which oxytocin alleviates pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Combination MEK/autophagy inhibition has shown promise in some pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma patients, but responses have been variable and of limited duration. Using single cell RNA sequencing and an advanced computational framework, we have identified three predominant cell types in pancreatic tumors that respond to MEK/autophagy inhibition. We propose to study the mechanisms of these responses and evaluate potential combination agents that will potentiate the anticancer effects of this regimen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arboviruses, including alphaviruses, are major public health concerns, and the capacity of an arbovirus to be transmitted in a human-mosquito-human transmission cycle has fueled outbreaks worldwide and is dependent on both the magnitude and duration of viremia. The host protein MARCO is a determinant of viremia by removing arthritogenic alphaviruses, for example chikungunya virus, from circulation. This project aims to determine molecular mechanisms of interaction between MARCO and arthritogenic alphaviruses, define viral features required for MARCO recognition, and elucidate the precise role of MARCO in alphaviral pathogenesis, ultimately expanding our knowledge about the innate immune system and building a foundation for potential therapies targeting alphaviral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 10% of the U.S. population is using e-cigarettes and vaping devices, with upwards of 25% of middle- schoolers and 50% of high-schoolers vaping regularly. A new generation of patient oriented researchers are needed to define and treat the health problems that will occur due to the use of these drug delivery devices. As a successful mid-career clinician, researcher and dedicated mentor, I request K24 support to protect my time such that I may expand my patient oriented research, develop my research expertise in new ways and increase my mentorship of outstanding junior investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The least understood parts of the striated muscle sarcomere are the thick filament, connecting filament and the Z-disk. Almost 40% of myopathy mutations occur in the thick filament backbone in which the coiled-coil myosin tails pack in order to bear the force produced by the myosin heads while another group of disease-causing mutations occur among proteins of the Z-disk, which anchors thin filaments into a bipolar array. This project seeks to understand through 3-D imaging of these three muscle components how mutations alter their structures resulting in defects of muscle function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Neurons are highly polarized cells with a cell body, neuronal processes, and specialized sub-cellular structures. This polarity is essential for neuronal function, and requires the precise localization of RNA, proteins, and lipids to discrete neuronal compartments to ensure compartment-specific functions. This application will investigate mechanisms by which proteins are localized and enriched in axonal compartments to allow dynamic and compartmentalized responses to external growth-promoting signals. An improved knowledge of spatial modes of signaling in neurons is critical for a fundamental understanding of axon development and maintenance, and will guide new therapeutic measures for nerve repair after injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Overall Program The central theme of our PPG is that high-density lipoprotein (HDL) function is a critical determinant of atherosclerosis (plaque buildup in arteries) in chronic human diseases associated with increased risk of heart attack and stroke. Specifically, this Program will study diverse detrimental changes to HDL cargo and function, including 1) reactive dicarbonyl modifications to HDL lipids and proteins, 2) pro-inflammatory microbial small RNAs on HDL, and 3) molecular networks within a novel kidney-intestine-artery axis. In addition, we explore new therapeutic strategies to improve HDL function and reduce atherosclerosis using dicarbonyl scavengers and non-targeting locked-nucleic acids (ntLNA).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Leveraging the rich Boston Lung Cancer Survival Cohort (BLCSC) database with 11,164 lung cancer cases, we aim to develop new statistical methods to identify novel biomarkers linked to lung cancer. The BLCSC was the first study that discovered the relevance of EGFR mutations to treatment response in 2004, starting the era of targeted therapy. The findings from the proposal will potentially further impact the medical practice, with our strong collaborative team, rich databases and sound statistical methodologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and intellectual disability are pervasive and debilitating disorders of childhood, with no targeted treatments. MEF2C Haploinsufficiency Syndrome (MHS) or 5q14.3 microdeletion syndrome are severe neurodevelopmental disorders with autism like features and destructive outcomes in affected children that result from loss of expression of the transcription factor MEF2C. This project is relevant to the NIH’s mission to enhance life and reduce disability, with a goal of understanding the role and regulation of intellectual disability and autism-linked genes like MEF2C in microglia and their resulting contribution to ASD pathology to identify novel potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: MDMX is a key regulator of p53 DNA binding and transcriptional activity. Elucidating the structure and regulation of MDMX is essential for development of novel cancer therapeutics. Our recent work revealed that phosphorylation sites in intrinsically disordered regions of MDMX play important roles in regulating MDMX interaction with p53 and other cellular proteins, and are important for efficient activation of p53 during DNA damage response. This proposal will further investigate how MDMX phosphorylation sites in disordered regions regulate its structure and function using molecular biology and NMR spectrometry. These experiments will advance the understanding of how stress signals activate p53 by regulating MDMX-p53 interaction, and may reveal novel strategy for targeting MDMX.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In all life forms on earth, DNA carries the hereditary genetic information. Transcription copies DNA into RNA, a key process that permits gene expression. On occasion, the nascent RNA can become entangled with the DNA, resulting in an alternative three-stranded nucleic acid structure called an R-loop. R-loops form universally under normal conditions and are thought to play physiological roles in cells, including human cells. Studies have suggested, however, that under conditions where transcription is perturbed, harmful R-loops are created, leading to DNA breaks and chromosome anomalies. What distinguishes “good” from “harmful” R-loops remains unknown. Similarly, how harmful R-loops arise as a result of perturbed transcription is unclear. Using innovative technologies developed by my group, we will characterize the formation of so-called harmful R- loops under conditions of perturbed transcription in human cells. We will also determine whether harmful R- loops, or perturbed transcription itself, are the cause of the DNA breaks. Finally, we will determine if an enzyme known to relieve the DNA break problem is acting by resolving harmful R-loops or remediating the altered transcription. This work will benefit our understanding of fundamental cellular processes acting in our genome and will provide insights into a range of human disorders linked to perturbed transcription.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will use two of the largest datasets on child and adolescent neurodevelopment in existence to inform how puberty influences the development of the brain and emerging risk for mental illness. Using measures of puberty and hormones, paired with multiple metrics of brain development, we will disentangle the relationship between age, puberty, and hormone concentrations and brain development, and establish how different measures of brain development interrelate across puberty. In addition, we will examine the neurodevelopmental mechanisms that help explain why early puberty increases an individual’s risk for mental health problems including depression and anxiety.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One type of phospholipase A2 controls the biosynthesis of eicosanoids central to inflammation, another type controls incorporation of polyunsaturated fats (PUFAs) into phospholipids, one acts to remove oxidized lipids, and another is critical to the functioning of macrophage cells, while a triacylglycerol lipase plays a critical role in fatty liver disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) stands out as an example where clinicians can observe weakness begin in a hand or foot, before progressively spreading to adjacent limbs and beyond to produce generalized paralysis. In the initial funding period of this award, our laboratory has uncovered evidence that this defining progressive phenotypic feature of SOD1-ALS may be explained by prion-like characteristics of mutant SOD1 as it spreads along neuroanatomically connected pathways. In the renewal application, we will focus on determining the contribution of intrinsic strain-like attributes of SOD1 mutants and extrinsic non-cell autonomous processes that may govern the prion-like spread of disease-causing SOD1 conformations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The signaling pathways that are activated by the pro-inflammatory cytokine TNFa and by the EGFR, a tyrosine kinase receptor with important roles in development and diseases such as cancer, are controlled through a pair of signaling scissors called ADAM17 (a disintegrin and metalloprotease 17) and its regulators, iRhom1 and iRhom2. In this proposal, we will use cell-based assays to perform structure/function analyses and will study genetically modified mice to discover how exactly the maturation and function of ADAM17, including its remarkable on/off switch and its substrate selectivity, are controlled by the iRhoms. We hope that our results will provide a better understanding of these vital signaling pathways and will uncover new targets for treatment of TNFa- and EGFR-dependent pathologies, such as autoimmune disease and cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Hinck, Lindsay, E.): This research addresses the public health concern of lactation insufficiency: a substantial problem impacting women's and children's health worldwide. Even though mother's milk is optimal nutrition for infants, there is a gap in understanding how the milk supply is generated during pregnancy and there are few medical inventions to support women who experience lactation insufficiency. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to the cell and developmental biology of somatic stem/progenitor cells, organ development, pregnancy and pediatric growth and nutrition. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative Discogenic pain is a major contributor to back pain and a leading cause of global disability with few effective treatments. This project determines inflammatory factors, specifically the role of tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNFα) in the onset and progression of discogenic pain including identifying neuroinflammatory interactions and cross-talk between intervertebral discs and dorsal root ganglia in rat and human model systems. We also apply cell and animal models and use next generation sequencing analyses to identify mechanisms and screen novel targets for efficacy in treating chronic discogenic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation is crucial for the host defense response, but unregulated inflammation is a key promoter of cardiovascular events including heart attacks and stroke. Specialized pro-resolving mediators (SPMs) are derived from naturally occurring essential polyunsaturated fatty acids and support the body’s innate immune response to actively downregulate inflammation without suppressing immune system function. The proposed research project aims to identify which specific SPMs may be beneficial for preventing cardiovascular events and reducing inflammation in humans, and what clinical and genetic factors determine their circulating levels in blood, with the goal of accelerating the development of new SPM-targeted therapeutics for disease prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The work we have proposed has a direct impact on the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer with chemoradiation and immunotherapy. As resistance mechanisms of chemoradiation with immunotherapy are not being intensely studied using relevant preclinical cancer models, our findings can have an immediate and large impact on the field. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain injury is the leading cause of death and disability worldwide. Motor Vehicle Crashes account for 50% of all TBIs. The leading causes of TBI vary by age: falls are the leading cause of TBI among persons aged 65 years and older; transportation is the leading cause of TBI among persons under the age of 65 years. Estimates suggest that sports-related brain injury accounts for close to 300,000 injuries each year. Currently, there are no established successful therapies treating acute TBI and there is a critical need to develop new strategies for assessing injury severity as well as guiding therapeutic interventions. The proposed research seeks to reduce cell death by inflammation that occurs in the brain and peripheral organs within days of TBI, and to devise therapies to treat TBI-related comorbidities and help in long-term recovery of function. The development of new treatments that can be given in the first hours after TBI may prevent or reverse much of the brain and peripheral organ damage resulting from TBI with a goal of restoring normal function and behavior.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the present proposal, we will continue to procure and process temporal bones, promote and share human ear tissue with basic inner ear researchers and create an uploaded digital library of temporal bone images. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (PROJECT NARRATIVE) The efficiency with which messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are recruited to the ribosome for translation intro proteins is a carefully controlled aspect of gene expression in eukaryotes whose dysregulation has been causally linked to tumorigenesis, tumor growth, drug resistance, and metastasis in many human cancers. Using a powerful combination of reagents and experimental approaches that are unique to the principal investigator’s and collaborator’s laboratories, this project will elucidate the molecular mechanisms that drive and control mRNA recruitment during eukaryotic translation initiation. The results of these studies will deepen our understanding of the mechanisms that control gene expression and the molecular pathogenesis of various cancers as well as identify targets for the development of anticancer therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The major mode of metabolism of NNK, a major contributor to the induction of lung cancer in smokers, is via the formation of its pro-carcinogenic metabolite, NNAL. Two enantiomers of NNAL are formed -- (R)-NNAL and (S)-NNAL, with (R)-NNAL the major isoform formed in the lung and both enantiomers detoxified by glucuronidation. We provide novel preliminary data demonstrating a strong and statistically significant inverse association between the ratio of urinary (R)-NNAL-glucuronide (Gluc)/(S)-NNAL-Gluc and lung cancer risk in smokers from two independent large cohort studies, and this novel, stable biomarker of lung cancer risk reflects the potential importance of (R)-NNAL in the carcinogenicity of NNK and strongly supports the goals of this proposal which is to evaluate the importance of different NNAL enantiomers and glucuronides in lung cancer carcinogenesis and to elucidate novel urinary biomarkers of lung cancer risk focusing on the NNAL formation and elimination pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While immunotherapy for cancer can have remarkable effects at prolonging patients' lives, it only is successful in a minority of patients. This is because patients need functional immune cells within their tumors to respond to these immune boosting therapies. We and others have shown that the capacity of tumor cells to consume metabolites can starve infiltrating immune cells, although the mechanisms are unclear. We will use preclinical models to understand how cancer immunity is regulated by metabolism, as well as analyze immune cells from patients treated with immunotherapy in combination with metabolism altering drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Directed evolution has proven to be a valuable technique for adapting enzymes to do elaborate chemistries that would otherwise be synthetically challenging. A major bottleneck to evaluating the hundreds to thousands of individually mutated library members involves the screening of products using colorimetric reporter or bioactivity assays, or time-consuming chromatography-based analyses on the experiments themselves. We propose to combine our respective strengths in biochemistry and mass spectrometry to develop a sensitive, accurate high throughput mass spectrometry based workflow to expedite the screening of a directed evolution library without the reliance on chromatography techniques in order to identify significant biocatalytic transformations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cardiovascular disease (CVD)—a leading cause of death as well as a leading driver of health care costs— disproportionately effects certain demographic and socioeconomic groups; under-resourced neighborhoods may be partially to blame. Resources may improve with “neighborhood redevelopment”, but whether redevelopment improvements translate to better health for all is not clear. To examine the relationship between neighborhood redevelopment and CVD-related health/health disparities, the proposed study will use three complementary approaches: (1) a natural experiment, (2) qualitative analysis, and (3) micro-simulation and system dynamics modeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Daily experience, such as stress and exercise, shapes various brain functions, including the capacity to learn environmental stimuli associated with rewards, such as addictive drugs or palatable foods. Maladaptive assignment of incentive-motivational value to environmental stimuli is thought to drive craving and relapse when exposed to those stimuli. The goal of this project is to determine the influence of stress and exercise on reward learning mechanisms in the brain dopaminergic system, thereby providing mechanistic insights into the effects of daily experience on vulnerability to addictive disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this research is to create a quantitative mass spectrometry platform for effective analysis of isomeric species of lipids and saccharides, which are important in metabolism, protein structure, and cell-to-cell signaling. The novelty of the proposed approach lies in the use of accelerated droplet chemistry to enhance analyte signal and confer unique fragmentation patterns to differentiate isomers when analyzed in tandem MS. The significance is that we achieve femtomole level sensitivity by coupling the droplet reaction platform to separation techniques allowing analysis of <1 µL samples of complex mixtures in a high throughput fashion, a process that is of great importance in many other fields including combinatorial chemistry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Major research efforts have been devoted to the development of nonlinear reconstruction algorithms – from model-based reconstruction to deep learning, these algorithms have demonstrated many advantages such as improved image quality, reduced radiation dose, and additional diagnostic information that are not achievable with traditional linear reconstructions. However, only a disproportionately small number has reach the clinic due to the lack of a predictive image quality analysis framework to quantify diagnostic performance, control algorithm behavior, and ensure consistent performance for robust clinical deployment. The propose effort use a combination of analytic and machine learning approaches to drive much-needed quantitative assessment standards that directly relate image quality to diagnostic performance and establish optimal strategies for robust, reliable clinical deployment of nonlinear algorithms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis the leading cause of death among critically ill patients in the United States. Despite decades of research on sepsis, there still remains much to be learned regarding the underlying mechanisms of disease. Biorepositories of human biospecimens provide us with the opportunity to better understand sepsis. This application is aimed at developing a screening algorithm and novel consent approach in order to support existing and novel methods of biospecimen collection in sepsis patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Stress is a major risk factor for physical and psychological health problems, and has been strongly linked with anhedonic symptoms in major depressive disorder (i.e., “Stress-induced anhedonia”). The goals of the current proposal are to characterize the brain networks associated with a recently identified glutamatergic stress- response profile in medial prefrontal cortex that has been found to be impaired in patients with major depressive disorder, and determine whether it can be restored using the glutamate receptor antagonist ketamine. By establishing the glutamate stress response as a mechanism for anhedonic effects of chronic stress and its reversal by ketamine, these data will be able to serve as a drug discovery platform for other pharmacologic agents targeting the glutamate system that may be useful in treating stress-induced anhedonia

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Recent experimental discoveries demonstrate that Irg-1/itaconate might be a novel therapeutic targeting molecule for preventing secondary brain damage after traumatic brain injury (TBI). This project will pursue three specific aims to test our central hypothesis: Irg-1/itaconate modulates multiple bioenergetics and neurovascular inflammatory signaling pathways of microglia and cerebrovascular endothelium, including preserving mitochondria oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS), while suppressing hyperglycolysis/NFκB activation, but activating Nrf2 signaling pathway, which results in inhibition of microglia activation-associated neuroinflammation (Aim-1), and BBB integrity disruption (Aim-2). These actions interactively prevent secondary brain damage and ultimately improve long-term neurological outcomes of TBI (Aim-3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application proposes the first ever in-human test of a neurosurgical treatment called high intensity focused ultrasound to see if it is safe and tolerated, and if it can reduce anxiety and brain response to threat in patients with partial epilepsy that is resistant to medications. Current treatments for anxiety disorders, the most prevalent mental illness, are limited by modest efficacy and require strict adherence and continuation to work. By studying this new treatment comprehensively, this study will examine if and how focused ultrasound works and provide insights that will guide best practices and reduce risk for future clinical trials in anxiety and other psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative There are no treatments to prevent or slow progression of disease in patients with Usher syndrome, the leading cause of combined deafness, imbalance, and retinitis pigmentosa. Studies proposed in this application will use multidisplinary approaches to define the progression of vestibular dysfunction in an Usher syndrome type 1C mouse model and in patients, and continue to assess the efficacy of two novel treatments (antisense and gene replacement) that restore balance in the mouse model. Results from this project will provide the foundation for translation of the treatments in the mouse into clinical trials in patients with Usher syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative This project aims to examine the effects of the new Home Care Rule (HCR) by the Department of Labor which allowed certain types of home care services to be protected by federal minimum wage and overtime rules in 2015, using advanced empirical methods and two large, nationally representative data sets. This new HCR could substantially change the utilization of and the spending on home care service for older adults with and without Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias (AD/ADRD). Findings from this study will have significant policy implications, as the size and the life expectancy of the older adult population, especially the population with AD/ADRD, and the costs of health care continue to rise, putting unprecedented pressure on the health care system.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triple-negative breast cancer disproportionately affects Black/African American women, is difficult to treat and is the deadliest type of breast cancer. This study will identify the factors that make a triple-negative breast cancer cell dependent on this protein and identify a small molecule inhibitor of the protein.

PHR: Project Narrative A central goal of toxicology is to predict the clinical effects that can result from specific toxic exposures, especially for chemicals with incomplete or insufficient experimental data. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Allorecognition and altruism are important abilities in biomedicine and social evolution, and the intersection between them has been described as a greenbeard system. Dictyostelium discoideum is one of the best model systems for studies in this field and our recent findings show that it employs a bona fide greenbeard mechanism that confers the ability to display and recognize a kinship signal and to act altruistically toward related individuals. We will study how altruism is executed, how cheaters and falsebeards are avoided, and how these processes can change the way we think about interactions between social organisms, cells within multicellular organisms, and some of the microbial parasites that infect and harm humans.

PROJECT_TITLE: Mechanistic analysis of a pathway that integrates allorecognition and altruism in Dictyostelium
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Maximizing Investigators' Research Award - D Study Section[MRAD]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Selective autophagy pathways use receptors to fragment and load membrane domains into autophagosomes that are targeted for degradation. Our studies are focused on understanding how endoplasmic reticulum (ER)- Golgi trafficking machinery and lipid droplets mediate these events during ER autophagy. This work is likely to advance our understanding of quality control in the ER and will have significant medical implications for the study of diabetes and other metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Integrating cryo-EM techniques into the P450 field will open new horizons in understanding molecular dynamics and evolution (with the prospect of rational reprogramming) of this catalyst, including its interactions with the electron donor partner proteins and biological membranes. For CYP51 in particular, such knowledge is essential in developing new therapeutics that benefit human health, in addressing the escalating problem of drug resistance in the clinic and will help validate the proximal P450 surface as a new target for inhibition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with a condition called ischemia with no obstructive coronary artery disease (INOCA) have symptoms including chest pain, fatigue, and depression, and there are currently few effective treatment options and women are more commonly and severely affected than men. Cardiac rehabilitation, which is an organized way to deliver exercise and lifestyle counseling, has the potential to work for these patients but there are many barriers (for example, if there are no facilities nearby); barriers related to gender have been described, making it harder for women to receive this treatment. Our study will test whether a new platform for cardiac rehabilitation, delivered by an electronic tablet device paired with weekly remote counseling (known as mobile health cardiac rehabilitation), will improve how INOCA patients feel after 3, 6, and 12 months; all analyses will take sex at birth and gender-related variables into account.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Complex neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs) are characterized by cognitive impairment, maladaptive behaviors, and disrupted sensory processing, though it remains unclear how these distinct manifestations are mechanistically (neurobiologically) related. Using animal models of causal NDD genetic risk, this project will define how cortical circuitry required for sensory processing causes cognitive impairment that leads to maladaptive behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Liver cancer is a deadly form of malignancy with limited treatment options. This project seeks to understand how different mutations in Wnt/β-Catenin pathway contribute to liver cancer development. The results will elucidate the distinct signaling pathways induced by β-catenin activation due to distinct mechanisms; and will pave a way for precision medicine for liver cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional genomic technologies have been developed primary in cultured cells making it difficult to address the complex phenotypes, such as spatial-temporal, and tissue/cell type specificity and interactions that occur in organisms. In this proposal, I will combine zygote manipulation methods and functional genomics technologies to develop novel high-throughput assays in mice, including MPRA and large-scale CRISPR saturation mutagenesis. The novel in vivo high-throughput technologies that I will develop in my training phase will enable to study in mice regulatory elements and disease-associated variants at developmental time points and tissues in my independent stage.
