IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute respiratory distress syndrome is an acute onset respiratory failure that affects more than 200,000 people a year United States and is treated with mechanical ventilation which, in turn, causes ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI) that is one of the primary drivers of the 40% ARDS mortality rate. However, determining the mechanical ventilation settings that minimize VILI, and improve ARDS outcomes, for each patient is difficult because individual lung physiology and ventilation requirements are different. To overcome this challenge, we will develop a mechanical ventilation system that uses mathematical models to predict and apply the optimal ventilation pattern to minimizes VILI for each patient and improve ARDS survival.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  As a debilitating disease, eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) affects 1 in 2000 individuals in the United States. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This research will test the potential to repurpose a small molecule BRAF kinase inhibitor, dabrafenib, an FDA- approved drug for several cancers, for new use in preventing cisplatin- induced hearing loss. Significant protection against cisplatin-induced hearing loss has been achieved with oral delivery of dabrafenib in mouse models in doses approved in humans. The successful completion of this study will provide the crucial data needed for rapidly advancing dabrafenib to clinical studies in humans for prevention of hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and diabetes are predisposing factors for vascular dysfunction that precedes the development of cardiovascular disease. The mechanisms behind vascular dysfunction in obese, diabetic individuals are not entirely understood. Thus, in the current study, we are investigating the crosstalk between the adipose tissue and endothelial cells as an underlying mechanism for vascular dysfunction and also as a target for non- pharmacological therapeutic interventions such as aerobic exercise and weight loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term objective of the ongoing research proposal is to understand the functional consequences of the myosin binding protein-C closely-related family of proteins on heart function in health and heart failure. In particular, the proposed studies will determine the specific role(s) of the fast myosin binding protein-C protein, a member of the family recently shown to be increased expression in the heart failure. More specifically, we will investigate the impact of fast myosin binding protein-C on sarcomere structure and function and heart contractility in the setting of heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Recovery from thoracic surgery (used to treat common chronic lung conditions) is associated with serious complications which may be prevented if more effective early detection and management strategies existed. Based on evidence from improved outcomes in oncology, electronic systems for monitoring patient-reported outcomes (ePROs), which are symptoms reported directly from the patient, are one potential solution. This application proposes to bridge the gap in knowledge on the optimal ePRO system design, how to use ePROs in surgery, and the benefits of ePROs in surgery using rigorous implementation science approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Insulin-producing pancreatic β cells play a central role in maintenance of whole-body glucose homeostasis. The proposed studies will examine the role of the key islet-enriched transcription factor NKX2.2 as a regulator of adult human β cell function and provide insight into molecular mechanisms mediating its impact on insulin secretion. To that end, these studies will further our understanding of human β cell biology, with broader implications for new therapeutic strategies for diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE A major complication of a bacterial infection in the bloodstream is the excessive activation of the immune system, which then attacks the body’s own tissues and organs, which can result in a patient’s death even if am infection is treated with antibiotics. We believe that one important reason for this severe immune response is the injury of blood vessel cells which immune cells. The research in this proposal will help us reduce the death of blood vessel cells to prevent the excessive immune response and hopefully lead to treatments for patients suffering from severe infections.

PHR: Project narrative In this project we will develop predictive fitness model that accurately accounts for immune recognition of influenza antigens and for the epidemiological factors that create the environment for the evolution of the virus, to quantify fitness effects that are imposed on the virus. Using machine learning approaches we will leverage large sequence and phenotypic datasets to propose objective criteria for the influenza vaccine strain selection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Lizards and salamanders both regenerate their tails, but the regenerated lizard tail lacks a skeleton with the segmentation and ossification characteristics of the salamander regenerate. This proposal employs an integrated approach to identify the regulatory networks underlying these differences, which will be used to guide manipulations of the regenerated lizard tail to phenocopy the more complex salamander tails. The knowledge gained here should provide important insights into approaches to improve vertebrate regenerative outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In psychiatric disorders characterized by severe stress and anxiety, memories of safety are more difficult to learn and remember than memories of threat, perhaps explaining relapse after therapy. The proposed research uses multivariate pattern analysis of neuroimaging data to localize the neural representation of threat and safety memories in the human brain. This research could lay the theoretical groundwork for more effective clinical treatments for anxiety and stress-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) is a widely used technology for non-invasive modulation of human brain activity with demonstrated efficacy in treatment of major depressive disorder. Accurate quantitative targeting and dosing of TMS requires anatomically detailed models for estimating the induced intracranial electric fields (E-fields) but currently no technique exists that has the computational efficiency to enable “online” neuronavigation applications while at the same time incorporating high level of anatomical detail with the necessary numerical accuracy. To remove this efficiency vs. accuracy dilemma that is currently posing a critical barrier for development of more quantitative TMS approaches, we propose to utilize our recently developed Boundary Element Method (BEM) based computational strategy accelerated by the Fast Multipole Method (FMM) to develop a near-real time high-resolution computational TMS neuronavigation system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: A population of Phox2b-expressing excitatory neurons in the retrotrapezoid nucleus (RTN) of the ventral medulla oblongata provide a CO2/H+-chemosensory and integrative role in regulating breathing; dysfunction of this neuronal system is implicated in potentially fatal syndromes (e.g., sudden infant death, congenital central hypoventilation) and re-setting of CO2 threshold/sensitivity can accompany and exacerbate various chronic disorders of breathing (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease). The cellular and molecular mechanisms that regulate pH sensitivity, and developmental or adaptive changes in those neurons have not been determined. Using mouse genetic models or viral transduction, the proposed work will incorporate single cell electrophysiological and molecular characterization of RTN neurons to uncover receptor and channel mechanisms of pH sensitivity, and to provide a transcriptome-wide examination of phenotypic features that support breathing in the vulnerable perinatal period or sustain function throughout life in the face of environmental or pathological challenge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Hearing disorders such as tinnitus, presbycusis, and noise-induced hearing loss are incredibly common and have long been recognized as public health epidemics. This project employs novel strategies to identify how feedback loops between high and low-level auditory centers contribute to hearing, which could eventually inspire new treatments for hearing disorders. More broadly, similar feedback loops occur across all sensory systems; these studies thus lay the conceptual groundwork to understand a general principle of mammalian sensory perception and higher-order brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies address an important and under-investigated area of childhood developmental stuttering pertaining to neural oscillatory synchrony underlying auditory-motor integration that supports speech perception and production. Using a multimodal imaging approach that combines both EEG and MRI data, the results of the proposed studies are expected to clarify for the first time the temporal dynamics of neural connectivity that are affected in children with persistent stuttering. These studies are expected to guide future intervention development that targets enhancing auditory-motor integration through manipulation of neural synchrony.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma continues to be a uniformly fatal malignancy despite aggressive therapy. The proposed studies are designed to understand how altered lipid metabolism discovered in glioblastoma contributes towards its aggressive phenotype in an effort to identify novel treatment combinations for this aggressive form of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Influenza A virus (IAV) is a major respiratory pathogen causing both annual epidemics and sporadic pandemics in the human population that result in significant morbidity and mortality across people of all ages. Tethered mucin 1 (MUC1) is expressed on multiple cell types that influence IAV infection (e.g. airway epithelial cells; macrophages) and has the potential to impact pathogenesis through physical interactions and/or signaling activity. Our interrogation of IAV infection in novel in vitro and in vivo models with altered MUC1 expression will advance our understanding of mucin biology, reveal how IAV negotiates MUC1 to efficiently infect the respiratory tract, and thereby evaluate MUC1 as a potential therapeutic target during infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COVID-19 has been associated with high in-hospital morbidity and mortality, although longer-term outcomes in patients surviving to hospital discharge remain unclear. This study aims to investigate the prevalence of albuminuria and other markers of kidney injury and inflammation at 3 months following hospital discharge, and to evaluate kidney function decline in patients with COVID-19 post-discharge up to 24 months.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aberrant behaviors of neural stem and progenitor cells (NSPC) during brain development can lead to cortical malformations, such as microcephaly and macrocephaly, as well as various neurodevelopmental disorders. Knowledge about precise control of NSPC behaviors is essential to dissecting the underlying pathogenic mechanisms. Our proposed studies will provide novel insights to how a selective RNA decay mechanism can influence NSPC behaviors and to the etiology of microcephaly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Plasmodium vivax is the major cause of non-African malaria and a significant problem for global health, with an estimated burden $1.4 - $4 billion per year. There is a critical need for a vaccine against P. vivax because of its relapsing nature and limited treatment options to clear dormant liver stages. The goal of this project is to develop a multivalent vaccine to prevent infection from mosquito transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: We have developed a new transvaginal imaging device that uses a co-registered photoacoustic and ultrasound technique for more accurate ovarian cancer diagnosis. In this project, the new imaging device will be optimized and prospectively evaluated by a team of radiologists to determine if the device can improve the current clinical practice by more accurately diagnosing ovarian cancers and reducing unnecessary benign surgeries. The new imaging device will also be used to screen a small group of women who have increased risk of ovarian cancer to determine its effectiveness on early ovarian cancer detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative Physical activity is a key protective factor for reducing risk for chronic diseases and all-cause mortality, yet only 35% of African American women meet national physical activity guidelines. Community settings hold tremendous promise as an important context for reaching African American women, but we argue that previous community- based interventions have focused on a relatively narrow scope of social-environmental variables. Addressing social affiliation needs is a critical next step for improving the impact of community-based physical activity interventions for inactive African American women and reducing existing health inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative  Gene therapies for genetic disorders of the central nervous system have rapidly advanced to the clinic with promising outcomes, and in several instances adeno-associated virus (AAV) serotype 9 has been used given its ability to transduce large numbers of neurons throughout the CNS. We recently discovered that the AAV9 capsid interacts with constitutive promoters to dramatically alter the pattern of CNS cellular gene expression. Determining the basis for this AAV9 capsid-promoter interaction will prove highly important to the design of future studies for CNS gene therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative SRGAP2C is a human-specific gene that regulates neuronal circuit architecture, but it remains unknown how it impacts the functional properties of neuronal circuits. Using a multimodal in vivo imaging approach, this proposal aims to uncover how SRGAP2C controls neuronal circuit function, and consequently affects cognition and behavior. Results obtained in this study will provide novel insights into the role human-specific genes such as SRGAP2C modify the functional properties of cortical circuits, and ultimately provide insight into how these genes may contribute to the pathophysiology of neuropsychiatric and neurodevelopmental disorders in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Choroid plexus cilia are a new type of multi-sensory cilia structurally distinct from primary or motile cilia. These cilia play an important role in regulating the production of cerebrospinal fluid during development and physiology. Using advanced imaging techniques, mouse genetics and genomics, cell and molecular biology approaches, our proposed studies aim to characterize the ultrastructure of choroid plexus cilia, characterized their developmental dynamics, and elucidate the molecular basis for their regulation on cerebrospinal fluid production.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this proposal is to use a systems approach to uncover the gene networks responsible for driving drug resistance and recurrence in an individual patient with brain cancer (glioblastoma). This capability will enable formulation of therapies that will have a higher likelihood to be effective because they will be tailored to the precise characteristics of a patient’s tumor. The research combines a hypothesis-driven approach with data- driven science to make discoveries of mechanisms underlying tumor subtype transitions –linking systems-level behavior to molecular mechanism, and bulk tumor characteristics to the behavior of single cells within a tumor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Adoptive T cell therapy to treat human malignancies has been revolutionized by the use of chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells in the past decade. However, despite the recent FDA approval of CAR T cells for the treatment of leukemia and lymphoma, how these CAR molecules really function remains largely unknown. Therefore, understanding how these novel molecules shape the function of T cells remains critical to logically advancing the field by designing molecules that reflect their true mode of action. In turn, these discoveries will be instrumental to generate more effective and safer therapies for patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This study aims to elucidate the roles of decorin, a cartilage matrix molecule, in regulating the structure and mechanical properties of healthy and degenerative cartilage. We will determine how decorin contributes to the mechanical function of normal cartilage and the degradation of cartilage in osteoarthritis. We expect to reveal a new molecular mechanism that governs cartilage matrix assembly, which can be used for developing new strategies for cartilage regeneration and osteoarthritis treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Psychological distress, presented through symptoms of depression and anxiety, is very common among breast cancer survivors, and it is critical that easily accessible, helpful, and engaging interventions are made available. IntelliCare, an app-delivered intervention, has been shown to be highly effective in reducing symptoms of depression and anxiety in the general population, suggesting strong potential for public impact among breast cancer survivors. This proposal will evaluate the efficacy of IntelliCare to reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety for breast cancer survivors, as well as the added value of human coaching to increase engagement, resulting in an adaptive intervention design for breast cancer survivors that is low cost, easily accessible, and highly efficient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcription factor proteins bind to the human genome and regulate the genes that govern human health. Understanding how transcription factors find their regulatory targets on the genome informs us of how the diversity of cell types in the human body arises during development and how cells go wrong during disease. This project aims to develop machine learning tools for understanding how transcription factors find their DNA binding sites when they are expressed in cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: While synapses within a single cell have long been known to be independently modified to allow the encoding of new information, the elements that allow these processes are thought to be relatively uniform across synapses. Thus, a fundamental gap exists in our knowledge as to whether unique protein signatures at individual synapses create functional differences in activity. This study seeks to determine whether proteins encoded by members of the neuron-specific gene family confer distinct functional properties to a subset of excitatory synapses, which could alter how neural networks respond to the flow of information during experience-dependent plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative: In the US, sugar-sweetened beverages (SSB) is the largest contributor to added sugar intake, with SSB consumption in Appalachia twice as high as national estimates. Excessive SSB is also associated with numerous chronic health conditions (e.g., obesity, some cancers, type II diabetes, heart disease, dental caries). This efficacy trial evaluates a technology-based behavioral and health literacy intervention targeting SSB reduction and weight reduction/maintenance among rural Appalachia adults. The long-term goal of this research is to sustain an effective, scalable, and high reach intervention to improve SSB behaviors and reduce SSB-related inequities and chronic conditions in Appalachia and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study has the potential to positively impact public health by improving the implementation (deimplementation) and sustainment of evidence-based practices in the hospital setting. To do so, I propose adapting and testing an innovative, behavioral theory-driven deimplementation program called DRAUP in two intensive care units for proof of concept and support that the program can help providers and hospital organizations address context determinants of deimplementation. Study data will be used to optimize the intervention for a subsequent R01 trial, resulting in an independent research pathway, to improve the precision of care for critically ill patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This work proposes a new therapeutic strategy to deliver conventional or molecularly targeted therapies across the blood-brain barrier specifically to primary brain tumors. Studies will focus on medulloblastoma, the most common pediatric brain tumor in children, with the goals that brain tumor-specific drug targeting will enhance efficacy and minimize systemic side effects. Should our results prove favorable, we envision applicability to other primary brain tumors commonly seen in children and in adults as well as potential utility in neurological diseases with evidence of neuroinflammation including multiple sclerosis and stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many mucosal epithelial cells project elaborate protrusions on their apical surfaces, called microridges, which help adsorb and retain mucus. The Sagasti lab has established a zebrafish model to investigate the morphogenesis of these understudied protrusions, revealing novel mechanisms by which the actomyosin cortex, cytolinkers, and intermediate filaments contribute to protrusion morphogenesis. Future work will investigate how cortical contractility is temporally and spatially regulated to promote microridge morphogenesis, and identify additional regulatory proteins that build the microridge cytoskeletal scaffold.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative African-Americans have a five-fold incidence of ameloblastoma than Caucasians. One quarter of all post-surgical ameloblastoma recurrence occur in the Black racial group. Full understanding of mechanisms promoting ameloblastoma recurrence are needed to mitigate disparities in ameloblastoma treatment outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative The microbes present in our gut have a profound impact on health, and profoundly influence the human immune system. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE The aberrant presence of double-stranded nucleic acids in the cytoplasm promotes a robust inflammatory re- sponse, which has galvanized interest in developing therapies that can sensitize cancer cells to the immune system. However, we found that cancer cells with chronic inflammation - fueled by genomic instability – have adapted resistance to a key innate immune pathway called cGAS-STING, redirecting a normally lethal output towards alternative pathways that promote metastasis. Motivated by the discovery that these resistant cells can still be sensitized to immune attack in a manner independent of cGAS-STING, we aim to unravel the con- text-dependence of this versatile signaling cascade to test if restoring normal responses to inflammation can be used as an effective therapeutic strategy to sensitize tumors to immune therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Statement of Relevance Transplant-related complications including idiopathic pneumonia syndrome (IPS) are major contributors to the development of multiple organ dysfunction syndrome after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) and continue to limit successful outcomes following this otherwise lifesaving procedure particularly in the pediatric population. The development of novel strategies to reduce the incidence and severity of these complications or treat the life-threatening aspects of each once established remains one of the most significant challenges facing our pediatric HSCT patients. Experiments proposed in this application will enhance our understanding of how alarmins and their receptors contribute to lung injury with the potential to modulate these pathways to reduce the severity of respiratory failure in pediatric HSCT recipients, and thereby improved outcomes and extend the use of HSCT as well as other novel cellular therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder is a devastating disease that affects approximately 50% of people with HIV. While the exact cause of HAND is likely variable and multifactorial, evidence suggest that altered metabolism and reduced bioenergetic capacity in the brain may contribute to the disease. These proposed studies will probe underlying mechanisms of metabolic alterations and reduced bioenergetic capacity in the brain, which may lead to novel therapeutic interventions for HAND and other neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS) are blood cancers with increasing incidence with aging and in cancer survivors and limited therapeutic options. The field lacks adequate MDS models to facilitate hypothesis- and preclinical-testing. The proposed work utilizes a breakthrough humanized mouse recipient to build xenograft models, and then validate both the engrafting material and its response to standard therapy.

PHR: Project Narrative Group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2) and eosinophils are both innate immune cells, but their participation in abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) has never been examined, although blood eosinophil counts are significantly higher in patients with AAA than in those without AAA. This study is proposed to test a role of ILC2 in the development of mouse AAA by releasing interleukin-5 to regulate the expansion and function of eosinophils.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will take multiple genetic and biochemical approaches to tackle two novel nutrient-related problems that are related to human health. The first is to uncover the unexpected beneficial roles of metabolites from the bacterial cell wall to animal development and behaviors, as well as understand the underlying mechanism. The second is to uncover a gut-initiated pathway that senses the imbalance of nucleotides to regulate germ cell proliferation and nucleotide metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Epithelial cells employ components of the epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) program as the main route for entering into the stem cell state with enhance tumor-initiating ability and a greater propensity to acquire resistance to chemotherapeutics. We have identified a TGFβ-regulated EMT program that induces the generation of tumor initiating cells through the reactivation of a silenced pluripotent lncRNA which induces tumor-mediated immunosuppression and tumor cell innervation. A comprehensive molecular characterization of the pathways mediating EMT is vital to our ability to therapeutically target tumor progression and metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genes encoding enzymes in the tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle) are causative genetic lesions in human cancers, including both inherited tissue-specific tumor syndromes and a variety of sporadic cancers. These tumors are associated with the accumulation of oncometabolites which interfere with an enzyme family of ~70 members that use alpha-keto-glutarate (aKG, also known as 2-oxo-glutarate) as a cofactor. In this application, we will use a CRISPRi-based screen to identify and perform pilot validation of the aKG-dependent enzyme(s) whose inhibition by oncometabolites leads to the acquisition of the neoplastic phenotype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rapid expansion of approved treatments and the individual variation in treatment response have created a critical unmet need to develop individually tailored treatment strategy for the nearly 3 million persons with multiple sclerosis (MS) worldwide. The proposed study will address salient knowledge gaps in the MS clinical management due to the absence of randomized controlled trial evidence. To achieve the goal of generating robust real-world evidence to guide optimal treatment selection and patient outcomes at the point of care, we will apply novel computational methods such as machine learning to electronic health records (EHR) data. First, we will compare the effectiveness of commonly prescribed MS treatments using EHR data to correct for confounding bias. Second, we will identify patient clusters based on an individual’s MS treatment prescription pattern over time and compare the clinical outcomes among the patient clusters. Third, we will identify optimal MS treatment sequences that predict favorable treatment responses using EHR data and reinforcement learning. The proposed research will close knowledge gaps due to absent randomized controlled trial evidence and limited real-world evidence to guide optimal treatment selection and bring precision medicine closer to people with MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death in men and women, substantial sex differences exist in disease prevalence and prognosis. Elevated myocardial stiffness is a precursor and a biological response to a spectrum of cardiovascular diseases and is highly likely to be affected by hormonal changes during menopause, but quantitative non-invasive in vivo measurements have not been realized clinically to make these measurements. In this project, we will develop a non-invasive magnetic resonance elastography (MRE) method that quantitatively measures myocardial stiffness and will use it to evaluate the influence of natural aging, sex, and menopause transition on myocardial stiffness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this application, we propose to use machine learning to construct COPD patient profiles integrating their clinical and genomic data to study COPD heterogeneity. We leverage these integrated profiles to identify biologically meaningful COPD subtypes and predict disease outcomes. Finally, we use network-based methodologies to identify the biological pathways connected to each subtype and gain a deeper understanding of the molecular underpinnings of COPD heterogeneity.

PHR: Project Narrative CRISPR/cas9 gene editing has shown great promise for the treatment of genetic hematological diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: SPAN is a randomized, placebo-controlled, blinded, multi-laboratory trial using state-of-the-art experimental design and rigor to successfully reduce or eliminate common sources of bias in choosing treatments for evaluation in clinical studies. The applicant PI and research team—the SPAN Coordinating Center (CC)— created and implemented novel solutions to several key barriers that impede pre-clinical network implementation, resulting in a highly successful, multi-site network for testing putative cerebroprotectants in animal stroke models that include equal numbers of females and males and co-morbidities such as aging, hypertension and hyperglycemia. This renewal application will allow the SPAN CC to continue significant improvement and advancement of preclinical development by implementing critical technical innovations, including novel assessment tools using machine learning, and continue our track record of successful enrollment and technical innovation, providing a model for pre-clinical networks in other disease areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Down Syndrome is primarily caused by trisomy of chromosome 21, resulting in an extra copy of over 200 genes and significant intellectual and developmental disability. Generating translational models and identifying the brain cell type specific contribution to Down Syndrome pathophysiology has been difficult and has hampered development and screening of new treatments. This project is relevant to the NIH’s mission to enhance life and reduce disability, aiming to understand how human microglia contribute to the neurodevelopmental pathogenesis of Down Syndrome with a goal of identifying novel treatment targets and screening methodologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microglial cells are the resident immune cell of the brain and are responsible for the immunological defense of the central nervous system against invading pathogens, brain injury, and amyloid deposition. The studies herein are designed to investigate a novel mechanism in regulating neuroinflammation in response to β-amyloid, a causative factor in Alzheimer’s Disease (AD). The proposed research will lead to a more comprehensive understanding of the establishment of neuroinflammation in aging and AD, and approaches to manipulate this pathway in the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medical devices that use blood pumps, for example on pump cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) leads to the destruction of red blood cells (RBCs) when used over long duration (>4 hour). The hemoglobin released into circulation as a result of RBC damage can cause organ toxicity, for example acute kidney injury in at risk patients. These complications can extend patient hospital stays at a cost of more than $9 billion/year and lead to 300,000 avoidable deaths. Therefore, developing methods to remove hemoglobin and its degradation products in patients undergoing procedures requiring medical device use, such cardiac surgery with on pump CPB will improve individuals outcomes and overall public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure to cues associated with cocaine use can trigger relapse in recovering cocaine users, even after long periods of abstinence. The proposed experiments will test the role of retinoic acid signaling in the synaptic plasticity underlying this persistent vulnerability to cue-induced relapse. By focusing on retinoic acid signaling - a pathway that has only recently been implicated in cocaine addiction - our work has the potential to identify novel targets for therapies aimed at preventing relapse and prolonging abstinence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: LAY SUMMARY: The proposed research has broad relevance to public health as it focuses on improving our understanding of the molecular basis of a shared mechanism of kidney disease progression, i.e., renal hyperfiltration injury. Kidney transplants will be used as a model system to test how hyperfiltration causes kidney damage in humans. We expect the findings to be broadly applicable to common kidney disease states such as diabetes and obesity that are also accompanied by hyperfiltration. Insights from this analysis we be applied to prolong the lifespan of kidney transplants and reduce morbidity and mortality associated with chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) Anorexia nervosa is a serious mental illness that typically begins in adolescence; it is defined by weight loss in conjunction with cognitive disturbances about eating and body image. Adult women with anorexia nervosa show differences in self-concept and social interactions, but whether these differences precede or develop during the course of illness is unknown. This exploratory project will evaluate self-concept and social interactions as adolescents with AN engage in treatment, improving our understanding of how social processing is related to symptom expression in this disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatment with platinum-based drugs, in particular cisplatin, in small cell lung cancer (SCLC) often results in the development of resistance leading to therapeutic failure, but the mechanisms remain unclear. We found that cisplatin activates NFIB-MAST1-PLK1 signals to confer adaptive resistance in ASCL1-high SCLC. In this proposal, we will decipher the role of NFIB-MAST1-PLK1 axis in driving adaptive cisplatin resistance and validate MAST1-PLK1 signaling as a therapeutic target to overcome cisplatin resistant in ASCL1-high SCLC using MAST1 inhibitor lestaurtinib.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Participating in genetic counseling and testing (GCT) can inform treatment and risk management decisions for women at-risk of hereditary breast and ovarian cancer, but Latina women underuse GCT services. This study will test the efficacy of a culturally targeted narrative video in enhancing GCT uptake and psychosocial outcomes in at-risk Latina women through a RCT. We will conduct an Implementation Focused Process Evaluation to gather implementation outcomes that will ultimately enhance the speed and quality of the translational process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Axon myelination is a critical component for circuit function and overall neuronal health, and loss of myelin can result in sensorimotor and cognitive impairments. This proposal seeks to understand the molecular mechanisms oligodendrocytes use to select axons of distinct classes and coordinate formation of appropriate amounts of myelin. These experiments can gain insight as to whether oligodendrocytes use different mechanisms to myelinate axons of distinct classes and may reveal that myelin sheath protein composition might be unique to axon identity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The mechanisms by which B cell responses are modulated by serum antibody remain poorly defined. This proposal seeks to (1) gain mechanistic insight into the regulatory role immunoglobulin plays in humoral responses and (2) evaluate the implications of antibody mediated feedback on B cell clonal selection. Completion of this work will provide insight into a mode of regulation of adaptive immunity that is important for improved vaccination design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project narrative. Inflammasome sensing of PAMPs and DAMPs has tremendous implications for the development of several inflammatory diseases such as sepsis. Sepsis still remains a major life-threatening condition despite the decades-long effort to develop specific drugs. By uncovering new mechanisms involved in the regulation of inflammasome sensing of PAMPs, the findings from this study could offer new immunomodulatory targets to mitigate inflammatory diseases including sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with adult congenital heart disease are at risk for poor health-related quality of life, impaired psychosocial well-being, and early mortality. Palliative care, and specifically, enhanced resilience, has the potential to improve these patient experiences, yet the optimal ways of addressing the palliative care needs of this population are largely unknown. The goals of this project are to evaluate the relationships between resilience and patient-centered psychosocial outcomes, explore patients’ experiences with resilience, and test the feasibility of a resilience intervention to improve these outcomes, in order to improve the health-related quality of life and long-term clinical care of patients with adult congenital heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Electronic health records (EHRs) are a powerful and efficient tool for biological discovery globally while a vital step for EHR-based research is valid, accurate, and reliable phenotyping. Conventional approaches to phenotyping are ad hoc, domain expert dependent, rule-based, and usually specific to EHR environments. We propose to refine, validate, and share a new generalizable high-throughput approach: Phenotyping by Measured, Automated Profile (PheMAP) that allows researchers to rapidly and accurately determine the status of thousands of phenotypes for millions of individuals with minimal human intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will probe the transformative idea that enhancing one carbon (1C) metabolism will increase anti-tumor immune functions and synergize with ICB. We will define how formate and 1C metabolism improve T cell function to synergize with PD-1 blockade, and identify metabolic pathways downstream of 1C metabolism that enhance T cell functions. These studies will illuminate mechanisms by which 1C metabolism and metabolic support with formate enhance ICB, and identify novel targets and strategies for improving cancer immunotherapy outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a devastating illness that causes substantial morbidity and mortality in afflicted patients. No medical therapy is available to target the underlying mechanistic causes of this disease process. The bacteria methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is a major cause of ARDS, and this proposal seeks to better understand how MRSA infection results in disease, as well as determine the potential therapeutic effectiveness of a novel FTY720 analog in a clinically relevant model of MRSA ARDS.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial/ethnic minority children who undergo surgery have worse outcomes compared to white or more affluent peers. Positive relationships and communication between the family and surgeon are essential to make high quality treatment decisions and overcome racial/ethnic disparities in clinical outcomes. This study explores generation of automated methods of analyzing parent-clinician communication, with the goal of identifying effective communication behaviors that can be easily taught to pediatric surgical clinicians.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bilingual children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), especially those with minimal spoken language skills, have long been excluded from research and may have limited access to interventions that support their dual- language needs. This project uses a sequential mixed-methods design to examine the dual-language communication and social-cognitive skills of children with ASD with a range of verbal abilities, contextualized by the experiences of their families in making language choices and seeking support services. The long-term goal of this work is to collaborate with families and providers to develop community-based interventions that promote the linguistic and social-cognitive development of bilingual children with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiac hypertrophy occurs from cardiovascular diseases and can lead to heart failure, disability, and death. This project will determine how a coordinated modification on multiple proteins during physiological stress affects heart function. The successful completion of this project will provide new information into the causes of heart failure that can be developed into new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The total body irradiation induced acute gastrointestinal syndrome is mitigated by administration of an engineered probiotic bacterium Lactobacillus-reuteri, LR-IL-22, which anatomically targets the radiation damaged intestinal crypt stem cells to restore intestinal integrity and is superior to systemic/parenteral administration of IL-22. We have demonstrated that intraoral (gavage) of LR-IL-22 mitigates the gastrointestinal syndrome by restoring irradiation-suppressed gene transcription in intestinal stem cells. We will now establish that LR-IL-22 and a new improved version modulates irradiation-induced molecular biologic cell death pathways in intestinal stem cells, preserves their crypt regeneration capacity, and mitigates the irradiation- induced acute GI syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  This project aims to develop advanced methods and computational tools to address biases and disparities caused by the lack of representation of non-European populations in large-scale genomic datasets and biobanks. We will develop transfer learning methods to improve polygenic risk prediction in under-represented populations by leveraging similarities in genetic architectures across diverse populations and related phenotypes, as well as communication-efﬁcient and privacy-preserving federated algorithms that integrate larger bodies of data across biobanks and large-scale genomic datasets to boost the power of association tests and risk prediction models. We will apply the proposed methods to study major depressive disorder and cardiovascular diseases using multiple national and institutional biobanks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bisphenol A (BPA) is a ubiquitous, endocrine disrupting compound with controversial carcinogenic properties. Our research will test a complete mechanism underlying liver cancer observed in mice exposed to BPA during development. This work will shed critical light on mechanisms underlying the carcinogenic potential of BPA, which will directly inform both epidemiological study design and human health risks due to BPA exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: Sepsis is a common and deadly disease characterized by organ failure due to a dysfunctional immune response to infection; yet there is much we do not understand about the immune response to sepsis because of practical limitations in studying it broadly in humans. Our goal is to optimize and validate a simple whole blood cryoprecipitation method using 2 mL of patient blood that we developed to make deep immune profiling via single cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) broadly available for multicenter clinical investigations in sepsis. This will enable detailed studies of broad and diverse populations of sepsis patients to discover how each individual immune cell type is responding to infection, which will greatly expand our understanding of underlying disease mechanisms, facilitate development of novel immune-directed therapies, and characterize patient subtypes by their immune response signature that might respond favorably to certain therapies over others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As vaccine and other pathogen-specific interventions for enteric infectious diseases (EID) come to market in the coming years, there will be a pressing need to identify areas of transmission risk and monitor EID burden trends under a changing climate. We propose to apply a big data approach to the mapping of EIDs combining advanced molecular diagnostics and geostatistical analyses with global earth observation-derived datasets to provide generalizable estimates of the geographical distribution of these outcomes and their environmental drivers via an interactive web-based dashboard. These outcomes will provide the research and stakeholder communities the data inputs that are urgently needed for targeting existing and novel interventions to priority populations in Low- and Middle-Income Countries.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Birth defects occur in 3-5% of infants, are a leading cause of childhood mortality, and are a large burden to families and society. Despite advances in genome sequencing, often the gene and variant that causes a birth defect is unknown, as are the genetic, cell biological, and pathogenetic mechanisms. We propose a screening platform including sequential bioinformatic analysis and experiments in multiple model systems (worm, fly, fish, mouse, or established human embryonic stem cell lines) to provide functional data in support of new birth defect genes and molecular diagnosis, and to obtain disease relevant mechanistic information necessary to design treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental condition that affects approximately 1% of the population, yet its neural and cognitive bases remain elusive. This proposal will use complex video stimuli together with functional neuroimaging (fMRI) and computational methods to identify brain regions that best predict ASD groups, subgroups, and traits, identify the underlying stimulus features that drive these neural differences, and make the data and tools we generate maximally available for others to use and build upon.

PHR: Narrative Auditory hallucinations in schizophrenia may be rooted in reduced inhibition of abnormal temporoparietal cortex activity due to auditory control network dysfunction. We will investigate neural markers of target engagement to further develop auditory control enhancement (ACE) as a novel, inexpensive, and noninvasive intervention to address treatment-refractory auditory hallucinations in schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Natural sounds like speech contain information at many different timescales (e.g. phonemes, syllables, words), but how the human brain extracts this information remains unclear. Understanding this process is critical to understanding how hearing impairment degrades speech perception. The proposed research will reveal the organization of neural timescales in the brain, and how this organization facilitates the coding of natural sounds like speech, which is a critical first step in understanding how this code is impaired by hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has unrivaled clinical and research utility, is non-invasive, and provides extremely high spatial resolution, however, MRIs have an Achilles heel: subject motion during scanning greatly diminishes the quality of the resulting images. We have developed software (FIRMM) that allows for non- invasive monitoring and reduction of subject motion during brain MRIs. In this proposal we complete late-stage development and commercialization readiness preparations to bring 510(k) FDA-cleared FIRMM into clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fibrosis, which causes dysfunction and ultimate failure of numerous tissues with aging, is characterized in part by increased tissue stiffness. Despite the profound impact of fibrosis on the health of our aging population, no adequate model system exists to study fibrotic stiffening on individual cells in real-time. This project aims to develop a dynamic material platform that enables user-directed manipulation of stiffness and to apply this system to identify aging-related changes in muscle stem cells that could lead to novel therapies to improve muscle function in aged individuals.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: The majority of Veterans will suffer from at least one chronic illness, often at great emotional and personal cost. Self-management is critical to improving physical and emotional outcomes, and many chronically ill Veterans receive self-management assistance from an informal caregiver. Yet, current clinical practices are not designed to effectively support the needs of both Veterans and their caregiver. Furthermore, self-management practices are often taught in person to the detriment of Veterans who face barriers to attending such as Veterans who live in rural areas, experience functional limitations, or experience financial challenges. This project tests a web-based self-paced behavioral intervention that targets the individual and interpersonal stress coping needs of Veterans with chronic illness and their caregivers. Results could provide an important solution to the problem of poor self-management which complicates the lives and prognosis of many Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Research in the field of neuroscience is critical to treat diseases of the nervous system that represent a growing emotional and economic burden to society, and it is imperative that we train research scientists and medical technology developers who fairly represent US society, including ethnic minorities, people from economically disadvantaged groups and people with disabilities. With this goal in mind, the University of Washington ENDURE program seeks to recruit underrepresented minority students from the Puget Sound community colleges, including the Seattle Colleges and Tacoma Community College, into a full-year research and training program at the University of Washington that will provide students with the needed skills to apply and succeed in graduate school within neuroscience-related areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (CA-MRSA) poses a major public health risk, particularly to infants and children, in whom the gastrointestinal (GI) tract is a key site of colonization. To study MRSA colonization of and transmission between patients, we developed a clinically relevant murine model of GI colonization by CA-MRSA, and identified new interactions between CA-MRSA, the host immune system, and commensal bacterial populations (“microbiota”). Knowledge of how MRSA colonizes the GI tract will enable efforts to find novel therapies and vaccines to prevent and treat infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Intra-abdominal infection-induced sepsis is a common clinical problem leading to high mortality, and there are currently no effective treatments. Fibroblastic reticular cells (FRCs) are important regulators of immune cell function that can detect infection and coordinate immune responses, and experimental therapies in mice using FRCs have successfully reduced mortality from an intra-abdominal infection. Our proposed project will help determine how distinct FRC subsets control the body’s response to overwhelming infection and also identify ways to improve the effectiveness of experimental FRC treatments, which will help us move closer to finding new treatments for sepsis in humans that will reduce morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The unifying theme of this proposal is the aim to use state-of-the-art technologies to investigate the basic biology of mammalian organ development and human structural birth defects. Our approach is wide-ranging, and aims to demonstrate how utilization of powerful technologies can inform many disorders. Specific methods we are proposing include: single-cell RNA sequencing and microCT imaging of mid-gestation mutant mouse embryos, and novel methods of genomic and transcriptional analysis to ascertain mutations in children with structural birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Several studies have raised the intriguing possibility that some of the nonmotor behaviors might involve cerebellar outputs to the parabrachial nucleus (PBN). They provided compelling anatomical evidence for direct projections from the cerebellum to the PBN, but they did not know the extent of these connections and were unable to assess their behaviors roles. With this project we hope to show that the PBN could be a new cerebellar output channel solely for the control of numerous nonmotor behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Gross chromosomal rearrangement (GCR) is a hallmark of cancer cells and a DNA double strand break (DSB) repair pathway called break-induced replication (BIR) is believed to be a major contributor to GCR. In this grant application, we will study the mechanism of BIR in repairing DSBs in mammalian cells and its potential role in causing genome instability upon oncogenic stress. Our study will provide new mechanistic insight on how genome integrity is maintained in mammalian cells and present new opportunities to explore the BIR pathway for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis-associated acute kidney injury is a major source of morbidity and mortality in critically ill children, increasing the short-term risk of mortality and the risk of developing a new disability for those who survive. This proposal will evaluate urine biomarkers to improve early detection of those at risk for pediatric sepsis- associated acute kidney injury, determine potentially modifiable risk factors related to medication therapies for sepsis that are associated with risk of acute kidney injury progression, use these biomarkers and risk factors to improve pharmacologic models predicting appropriate antibiotic dosing, and test these new pharmacologic models for antibiotic dose adjustments in a pilot trial, which may lead to more effective antibiotic treatment in sepsis with lower risk of toxicity. These results will inform future interventional studies to target therapeutic strategies to reduce or prevent pediatric sepsis-associated acute kidney injury in those at high risk, with the ultimate goal of allowing children to lead longer, healthier lives free from disability.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes is a chronic disease that results from deficiency of functional insulin-producing beta cells in the pancreas. One promising therapeutic approach to restoring beta cell mass is their expansion through regeneration of residual pancreatic beta cells. This Career Development proposal uses advanced genetic and epigenetic approaches in order to shed light on the fundamental mechanisms of action of the existing beta cell regenerative drugs, as well as to identify novel drug targets for diabetes therapy, and to provide essential and high-quality additional training to the applicant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have recently shown that T cells in the placental villi are active and inflammatory during intraamniotic inflammation, a process commonly associated with preterm birth. In this grant application, we will use our combined expertise in mucosal immunology (L. Konnikova), placental biology (V. Abrahams, S. Guller), placental pathology (R. Morotti) and bioinformatics (G. Tseng) to uncover placental villi T cell abnormalities in preterm births. We will use our current biorepository and ongoing collection of placental specimens to: (1) delineate T cell surface phenotypes, anatomic localization, activation mechanisms, and transcription, and TCR profiles unique to preterm placental villi and (2) interrogate the downstream effects of T cell activation on surrounding trophoblast cells as a potential mediator of preterm labor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative A human genome has 46 DNA molecules, some many inches in length, and when laid end-to- end they span almost 6 feet in length. Consequently, it is now impossible to make human genomes in the laboratory. This challenge will be met by greatly simplifying genome manufacturing through new large-scale chromosome construction technologies that assemble large “chunks” of DNA into chromosome-sized molecules by directly harnessing the very intrinsic physical properties that make them “difficult” objects to deal with.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health, because little is known regarding how individuals acquire the genital bacteria species that increase HIV risk and how to remove them. By studying the impact of sex and antimicrobials on the penile microbiome and what can predict the outcomes, this project will build new knowledge regarding how to design new strategies to prevent and reduce carriage of genital bacteria that are associated with HIV risk and other poor health outcomes. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission to better understand and prevent infectious diseases, including HIV.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many of the invasive transrectal prostate biopsies performed for PSA screening are unnecessary—50% of the men undergoing a biopsy do not have prostate cancer. Although biomarkers and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has been used more often to help better select men for biopsy, these tools are not accurate enough to replace biopsy. We have developed a new way of analyzing the MRI images called diffusion histology imaging (DHI) that can accurately and non-invasively diagnose prostate cancer, which has the potential to reduce—if not eliminate—unnecessary prostate biopsies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The stability, expression, and inheritance of genetic information depends on the packaging of our genome by specialized proteins. The disruption of this protein-DNA complex, called chromatin, results in the genome instability observed in virtually all types of cancer and in chromosomal birth defects like trisomy. My research combines evolutionary predictions with basic chromatin biology to generate unique insights into these disease and infertility states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) is a debilitating disorder that includes severe cognitive deficits that greatly impair quality of life. There is substantial evidence that hippocampal circuits are disrupted in epilepsy but it remains unclear whether these deficits are caused by local processing changes or altered inputs coming into hippocampus. This proposal examines how medial entorhinal cortex projections to the hippocampus are altered in epileptic mice and tests the causal role of this circuit in hippocampal synchronization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is an orally transmitted human gamma herpesvirus and the causative agent of several lymphoid and epithelial cell malignancies that occur with high rates in HIV-AIDS patients. EBV-associated cancers are subject to variable expression of viral oncogenes that is controlled by epigenetic mechanisms. Elucidating the epigenetic mechanisms controlling EBV oncogene expression in different cell and tumor types will provide information necessary for the development of new therapies to prevent latent infection and EBV- associated pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Some individuals genetically make a little more than others a gene product that increases the severity of diabetic complications in heart and kidneys, because it leads to a production of excess production of oxygen radicals. Unbalanced oxygen radical production is known to underlie in aging-associated common diseases as well as in acute injuries, but whether and to what extent the variation in a diabetes-associated gene affects the severities of tissue damage in other diseases is not currently known. Identifying mechanisms by which variations of the genes that influence the severity of common disease conditions should help guide us to new means of treatments/preventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) lead placement is a challenging and time-intensive procedure often requiring patients to be awake to confirm motor symptom reduction and assess side effect profile intraoperatively. Evoked potentials (EPs) hold promise as biomarkers to guide appropriate placement of DBS leads more rapidly and accurately, possibly even in patients under anesthesia. In this way, the use of EPs as a biomarker may reduce surgical time, improve patient outcomes, and improve patient comfort.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: This study has significant relevance for public health, as it is aimed at identifying prenatal risk factors, including markers of maternal oxidative stress, in schizophrenia and autism spectrum disorders in a large national birth cohort. These factors have never before been investigated in maternal sera in relation to these outcomes. The proposed research may offer the potential for prevention of these disorders by public health measures including reduction of exposure to factors that increase maternal oxidative stress, and could also result in an improved understanding of how prenatal insults alter brain development in these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal addresses gaps in our knowledge on the neuromodulatory effects of circulating steroid hormones on reward and aversion behaviors, a function critical for survival. The proposed studies will examine the Lateral Habenula, integrating molecular to circuit-specific approaches, to better understand how reward and aversion- motivated behaviors are sculpted by sex hormones; thus providing a more comprehensive understanding of the dynamics between reward and aversion. Collectively, the findings from this research proposal have the potential to identify therapeutic targets for treating depression, anxiety, and addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heparin and related glycosaminoglycans hold enormous promise in medicine, as their intimate involvement in processes ranging from cell proliferation and differentiation to immune regulation makes them a largely unexploited source of therapeutic agents that can address a variety of medically important conditions. However, heparin turns deadly in a subset of patients by triggering an immune disorder heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), which may be fatal if not immediately diagnosed and prompt actions taken. The proposed research will make a critical contribution towards understanding the molecular mechanism of interaction between heparin and platelet factor 4, two key players in the onset and progression of HIT, catalyzing development of reliable diagnostic/prognostic tools and potent therapeutic intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE M. avium complex (MAC) lung disease is a growing clinical problem that surpasses that of TB, particularly in certain states including Virginia. We will utilize a state-wide clinical cohort of all MAC lung disease patients to understand what features of the organism (such as the species or subtype or drug resistance profile), the host (such as antibiotic drug absorption), and the environment (such as household exposure to MAC) are most important in predicting clinical outcome. The sum of this research will direct future therapies and management algorithms for this difficult disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) is a hereditary neuropathy caused by gene mutations that lead to demyelination and axon degeneration of peripheral neurons. This proposal follows through on data suggesting that mutations in one of the CMT genes called Mfn2 affects mitochondrial fission and axonal transport in unexpected ways. A successful outcome of this project can provide new insight into the underlying causes of the disease and it may point the way towards developing novel treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Meiosis is an evolutionarily conserved process by which a precursor cell is remodeled to produce gametes, which enable sexual reproduction. The proper execution of these cellular remodeling events is critical for production of viable gametes and is controlled by changes in which genes are turned on (expressed) at different stages of the process, although the specific regulation responsible has been unclear. My lab has recently defined the natural gene expression changes that occur during meiosis, discovering mysterious aspects to this regulation that defy expectations based on traditional models, and prompting important questions about how meiosis is regulated that we will now investigate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Humans have many unique features that distinguish them from other animals, ranging from behavior and social organization to susceptibility to infectious and chronic diseases. Elucidating the origin of these novelties is essential for understanding the genetic basis of human biology, individual variation, and health risk factors. The goal of this project is to reconstruct the molecular mechanisms of evolutionary innovations at all levels of biological organization, from new functional elements in the genome to new genetic pathways to new anatomical structures, using experimentally tractable animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This application proposes to validate the robustness of Shutter-Speed Model (SSM) dynamic contrast- enhanced (DCE) MRI as a quantitative imaging biomarker for assessment of cancer therapy response in a multicenter prospective study, using the setting of breast cancer response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy as the clinical test platform. Validation of this quantitative imaging method in a multi-site and multi-MR scanner platform setting and making the associated software tools publicly available will accelerate the translation into clinical trials and, ultimately, clinical practice to improve prediction and evaluation of cancer therapy response for individual patients in the emerging era of precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a condition in which functional impairments are observed at perceptual, cognitive, and motor levels, but few investigations have investigated how these functions relate to and influence each other. Using perceptual decision making paradigms, combined with high-resolution movement tracking, we will (1) investigate the extent movement improves timing deficits in adults with ADHD (and matched controls), and (2) assess how sensory information from multiple visual feature domains are combined to guide movement plans. These investigations present novel methods to probe integrated (i.e., perceptual, cognitive, and motor) performance in ADHD, and may inform the development of more comprehensive behavioral interventions by exploiting the link between movement and cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Preeclampsia (PE) causes maternal-fetal physiologic imbalance with maternal, fetal and neonatal morbidity and mortality. Maternal asthma also increases the risk of PE and childhood asthma. The genomic overlap of the two conditions could help to elucidate their early origins and potential prevention of both disorders and childhood asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary purpose of this project is to adapt and validate wearable, optically pumped magnetometer-based magnetoencephalography (opmMEG) methods to measure brain function in infants, and to then further adapt these protocols to simultaneously record brain function in mother-infant dyads during naturalistic interactions. This would represent the first application of wearable opmMEG in infants, as well as the first simultaneous opmMEG recordings from actively interacting mother-infant dyads. This work will lay the foundation for innovative, hypothesis-driven research aimed at understanding both how these dyadic neural patterns change during normative development, as well as how we can use this technology for identifying functional brain patterns that are indicative of emerging risk for developmental disorders in infants and postpartum psychopathology in mothers, allowing for early identification and intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Hypertension is a condition of premature vascular aging, where the normal decline in vascular function as we age is accelerated and exacerbated. It is well established that upregulation of autophagy can ameliorate this “aged” phenotype; however, underlying mechanisms are yet to be determined. Given that autophagy also serves to mobilize macro- and micronutrients in times of stress, we hypothesize that upregulation of autophagy in the liver, stimulates the production of ketone body, ? -hydroxybutyrate, which induces vasodilation, and decreases phenotypes of premature vascular aging associated with hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Nuclear size is often deregulated in cancer cells, many cancers are diagnosed and staged based on graded increases in nuclear size, and little is known about the causes or effects of nuclear morphology changes in cancer. We will identify nuclear size effectors and elucidate mechanisms of nuclear size regulation, informing how nuclear size impacts embryonic development, cell differentiation, and carcinogenesis and shedding light on novel approaches and targets for the diagnosis and treatment of cancer. Aberrant nuclear size in cancer might actually be required for cell homeostasis and viability, so therapeutic manipulation of nuclear size could provide a means to selectively target and kill only affected cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative-Relevance to Public Health Reduction or loss of antigen presentation is a frequent and essential mechanism used by tumor cells to escape immune recognition and destruction. We identified atractylenolide I (ATT-I) in a screen of natural compounds from herbal medicine for colorectal cancer immunotherapy. We propose that ATT-I significantly promotes tumor antigen presentation of colorectal cancer cells and thereby enhances the efficacy of immune checkpoint blockade therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research addresses the critical need to determine new molecular mechanisms that underlie how the heart relaxes, a key component of diastolic dysfunction and Heart Failure with preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF). We investigate a unique strain-rate (stretch) dependent mechanism to accelerate the relaxation of heart muscle. We utilize novel biomechanical tests to discover new drug targets and diagnostic indexes for diastolic dysfunction that can be translated into clinical practice.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite the high incidence of debilitating coronary microvascular diseases in thoracic cancer survivors treated with ionizing radiation, no effective therapy is currently available. PHR: Project Narrative: In this project, we will reveal a specific epigenetic mechanism by which short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) regulate chronic temporomandibular joint (TMJ) pain. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Africa, the birthplace of modern humans, is the single most informative continent for understanding the human genome and human disorders with worldwide impact. Since most genomic research has not involved African populations, generations of human genetic history are missing from our understanding of human genetics and complex disease. In this study, we will use novel whole genome sequencing strategies to characterize the genetic bases of schizophrenia in the Xhosa population of South Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative This project will advance our empirical understanding of how dexterous updating of the upper limb, in particular reach-to-grasp actions, are orchestrated by the brain. The knowledge will be immediately applicable and translatable for rehabilitation of upper limb recovery in stroke and other similar disorders, by using error augmentation through visual and haptic platforms to facilitate skill reacquisition and identifying cortical targets for non-invasive neuromodulatory stimulation. These findings will be relevant to the mission of the NIH, with broad interest to clinicians and basic scientists, and will have direct public health relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) is a chronic allergic disorder that begins in childhood and affects people of all ages. EoE is poorly understood, although it is known to be associated with allergic conditions. In this proposal, I will study how allergic signals change gene regulation in the epithelial lining of the esophagus and affect the esophageal mucosal barrier.
