IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The dynamic microtubule cytoskeleton plays vital roles in cell division, motility and differentiation. This project aims to provide a fundamental molecular understanding of dynamic microtubule behavior using a multidisciplinary approach that combines biochemical in vitro reconstitution, live-cell imaging and computational modeling. Because microtubules are a common target for chemotherapeutic agents and many of their regulating proteins are implicated in cancer and neurodegenerative diseases, the proposed research bears critical relevance for both basic science and human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it develops better primate models of auditory cognitive processes critical for language in humans. By identifying shared components of auditory working memory, attentional control, and strategic decision-making in primates and humans, this work will enable researchers to use primates in basic and interventional studies. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIDCD’s mission that pertains to biomedical research on processing of speech and language.

PHR: Project narrative Neural tube defects (NTDs) are among the most common serious birth defects diagnosed in human fetuses and newborns that result from the failure of neural tube closure during early pregnancy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CD8 T cells are powerful immune cells that specifically recognize infected cells, and in some settings cancer cells, and eliminate them. However, CD8 T cells in cancer patients fail to eliminate cancer cells because T cells become hyporesponsive. We propose to understand the mechanisms that drive T cells into cancer-induced hyporesponsiveness and test strategies to reprogram T cells into effective cancer killing immune cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE In the rare disease Friedreich’s Ataxia (FA), abnormal skeletal muscle energy production may contribute to functional decline in individuals with heart failure, which is the leading cause of premature death in this condition. We propose a mechanistic randomized controlled trial of exercise training and supplementation with nicotinamide riboside, a precursor for NAD+, a metabolite that is critical for muscle metabolism, in individuals with FA who have not yet developed heart failure but have evidence of defects in skeletal muscle energy production. Our findings will lay the groundwork for future trials to improve functional status in individuals with FA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulated immune responses are an important cause of intestinal toxicities after bone marrow transplantation (BMT), but little is known about where these immune responses occur within the intestinal tissue or how this localization may affect the stem cells maintaining the intestines. The purpose of this project is to study where cells of the immune system function within the GI tract after BMT and how their locations impact specific intestinal targets. This will lead to new biologic insights into the interactions between the immune system and the intestinal stem cell compartment, as well as the development of new therapies that can protect and promote recovery of damaged intestinal tissue after BMT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although allogeneic bone marrow transplantation saves lives of patients with leukemia/lymphoma and certain solid cancers, this therapy is limited when transplanted bone marrow cells attack recipient organs, including skin, in the disorder termed acute graft-versus-host disease. This proposal focuses on how we can manipulate and enhance the skin’s own built-in system designed to suppress such life-threatening immune responses by focusing on a newly-discovered cell termed a dermal mesenchymal stem cell. If successful, we will develop new therapeutic approaches to harness the dermal mesenchymal stem cell to inhibit graft-versus-host disease, and potentially may other inflammatory conditions that affect skin and other vital organs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death worldwide, risk begins early in life, and as a result, policy organizations are recommending that optimal promotion of cardiovascular health begin during childhood. Prenatal maternal depressive symptoms predict offspring cardiovascular risk, though this association has not been demonstrated experimentally; as such, the proposed research will follow up a sample of offspring from pregnant mothers who participated in a randomized controlled trial to test whether reducing prenatal maternal depressive symptoms improves offspring cardiovascular health in early childhood. This research will determine whether an established, effective psychosocial intervention to reduce depression during pregnancy also reduces cardiovascular risk early in life in the next generation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This project addresses the crucial need for regulated delivery of cold medical plasma, based on real-time measurements, to reliably and reproducibly deliver plasma components that promote wound healing. We will develop a control system into which commercial sensors will be incorporated to detect when the effective dose of plasma has been applied to a wound. The system will be integrated into two different medical plasma devices and tested for automated control of plasma dose in a murine skin wound healing model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing a novel and alternative strategy using non-viral dual gene (DNA and RNA) delivery methodology to treat oral cancer pain. Once such strategies have been developed, there is the potential for a significant advance in anti-pain therapy for oral cancer patients suffering severe debilitating pain. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  At present there exists a schism between the rate of disease gene discovery and our present understanding of how mutations in such genes result in mental illness. Understanding of how mutations in these genes affect brain function at a cellular level has lagged behind. My proposal by coupling our expertise in studying the development of cortical interneurons, with the computational skills of the Bonneau laboratory, promises to bridge this gap.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, we describe the development of new synthetic methods and photocatalytic processes that are enabled by excited-state redox chemistry. This work aims to provide solutions to significant and long-standing gap in the synthetic literature and provides a basis for the development of novel methods to enable the construction of both complex targets and common pharmacophores. The reactions and processes enabled by these technologies will provide new tools to simplify the discovery, design and manufacture of drugs and other small molecule probes of biological function, creating a significant benefit for human health and the associated biomedical sciences. ! !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune therapy has become a standard treatment for multiple types of cancers and ultimately relies on T cells to kill tumor cells; however, we don’t yet fully understand the relationship between how T cells kill tumors and how cell death pathways in tumors lead to their death. CAR T cells are engineered T cells that kill lymphoid tumors by targeting a specific protein on their surface, and are now standard treatment for lymphoid cancers. We propose to examine the mechanisms by which CAR T cells kill tumors, and define the programmed cell death pathways in tumor cells that enable susceptibility and resistance to CAR T cell killing, with the goal of using specific combinations of drugs and engineering approaches to enhance T cell-mediated tumor killing.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION

PHR: Project Narrative This project allows the continuation and expansion of an existing unique educational program specifically designed to enable the conduct of nonclinical studies and clinical research trials in maximum containment laboratories and barrier nursing environments in a manner that assures the quality and integrity of the data. The program provides a learning environment that promotes collaboration of ideas, provides tools for study conduct, enhances mutual understanding of scientific and regulatory complexities, and promotes the quality and integrity of data derived from these studies. The result is a better prepared cohesive community of scientific and regulatory experts mutually engaged in, and committed to, the development and approval of medical countermeasures for high consequence pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  How the dorsal striatum contributes to reward-seeking and punishment-avoidance behaviors in healthy and disease conditions remains unclear. In the proposed research program, we will test the hypotheses that distinct striosome populations in the dorsal striatum differentially control reward seeking and punishment avoidance through different circuit mechanisms, and these neurons become dysfunctional after stress, thereby causing maladaptive behaviors. Findings from this project will have important clinical implications, as striatal dysfunctions have been implicated in depression and drug addiction.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Although the implementation of whole genome sequencing in a clinical setting has greatly facilitated the detection of birth defect-associated genetic variants, distinguishing the specific variants that cause congenital birth defects remains a major challenge. This project aims to address current obstacles in variant interpretation through the application of innovative experimental approaches and scalable genomic technologies to profile the functional and phenotypic consequences of congenital defect-associated genetic variants identified in undiagnosed rare disease patients. These methods will rapidly accelerate the process of identifying causal variants and in some cases may reveal previously unappreciated avenues for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CAPPA is a physical activity intervention for employees with chronic knee pain, which is being tested in a developmental randomized controlled trial at two partnering worksites in the Midwest. CAPPA is assessing whether an action planning intervention supporting physical activity can increase and sustain physical activity in employees with chronic knee pain. Knee osteoarthritis is a major public health problem and a leading cause of disability and productivity loss among persons in the workforce. The goal of this program is to develop and assess a low resource physical activity coaching intervention to large groups of employees at risk for knee osteoarthritis. The CAPPA intervention is administered by health coaches, who will use data transmitted from a Fitbit tracker via our customized remote coach interface and Movement Dashboard to 1) support employees in making physical activity action plans for their health, 2) use data transmitted from a personal fitness tracker (Fitbit) to support coach and employee knowledge about physical activity performance, 3) use data about physical activity to suggest optimal timing to step up to higher resource treatments in future research studies. This project has the potential to have a lasting impact on improving symptoms and quality of life of persons with chronic knee pain and decreasing the functional limitations, productivity losses, and soaring healthcare costs associated with knee OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Measles: A Global History Project Narrative This research project will produce a global history of measles, one of the oldest, most familiar, extensively studied, preventable, and still-epidemic infectious diseases of humans. The final outcome of this project will be a book manuscript that, by tracing measles' history from medieval times to the present, will show how scientific and sociopolitical conceptions and perceptions of the disease rooted in space and time have made measles both a stable and dynamic illness. The book's analysis will also reveal how measles management strategies, from quarantine to vaccination, have yielded an array of cultural, political, economic, and medical meanings of the disease over time, with implications for measles' symbolic and practical significance in scientific, popular, and political discussions about the management of other infectious diseases, from smallpox to COVID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Social anhedonia—a reduced tendency to enjoy interpersonal relationships and/or reduced interest in social interactions—presents a significant public health challenge. This application aims to advance our understanding of the underlying mechanisms of social anhedonia by probing a process that is hypothesized to be central to social anhedonia: disrupted social reward learning. The findings of this project will provide valuable insights into the mechanical pathways of social anhedonia and could provide novel neurobehavioral phenotypes that can serve as targets and biomarkers for developing novel treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it develops hydrogel-based materials for localized drug delivery to treat gastrointestinal diseases. Intestinal disorders including inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis), irritable bowel syndrome, and colorectal cancer are significant public health concerns that affect millions of Americans each year, and drug delivery for localized delivery can improve clinical outcomes when compared to systemic administration of drugs. The proposed research will provide materials for 3D printed drug delivery devices that can deliver a broad range of therapeutics for an indefinite period of time.

PHR: Project Narrative The objectives of the grant are to train M.D. and Ph.D. post-doctoral fellows in the application of genomics to infectious diseases, and to prepare them for successful, productive, independent careers that have a significant impact on the health-related research needs of the nation. The training program will exploit the world-class resources and leadership at the host institution in the field of genomics. Graduating trainees from this program will be unusually well-prepared to enhance the public health through the application of this powerful field of science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common primary malignant brain tumor in adults with poor survival. This research proposal is based on strong preliminary data showing that Estrogen Receptor beta (ERβ) exerts tumor suppressive functions in GBM. This proposal is will develop novel ERβ agonists that promote tumor suppression leading to a new therapeutic modality to treat GBM. Identification of CIDD-ERβ agonists as a therapeutic agent can be readily translated into clinical use with current chemo and radiation therapies, providing an additional tool for enhancing survival in GBM patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Hippo pathway plays crucial roles in various physiological processes and is frequently altered in cancer development. The overall goal of this R01 proposal is to elucidate the regulation and function of the Hippo pathway in growth control and tissue homeostasis. Completion of this project will enrich our understanding of the Hippo pathway in normal physiology and lay the molecular foundation for developing new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) is an aggressive malignancy with a poor 5-year survival rate of 6% for patients with metastatic disease and there are no targeted therapies for these patients. The failure to identify more effective treatments can partially be attributed to the lack of appropriate preclinical research models that accurately model ACC metastasis and support the key biological pathways implicated in ACC progression. To address these critical research gaps, we will use our newly developed patient-derived organoid (PTO) model of ACC from patient samples as well as an ACC PTO metastasis-on-a-chip (MOC) microfluidic platform with onboard biosensing of cell migration to determine the roles of IGF, Wnt, and cell cycle regulation-based signaling on ACC metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Advanced age is the greatest risk factor for the onset and progression of Alzheimer's disease. We are using the powerful genetics of the fruit fly Drosophila to better understand the biological mechanisms of aging. The long-term goal of this research is to provide novel therapeutic targets to counteract age-related human diseases, including Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Colonoscopy is a common cancer screening procedure that is far from perfect and one of its major flaws is that the physician is unable to view large areas of the colon hidden behind folds, which leads to missed pre-cancerous growths and the unexpected, early development of cancer. We will develop and demonstrate a unique single viewpoint panoramic imaging technology which can be either integrated to the new colonoscope or added as an attachment to the standard colonoscopes, providing a wide-field forward view and 360-degree side-view. A more thorough colonoscopy will lead to fewer missed polyps, longer screening intervals, and a substantial reduction in the economic burden of colonoscopy

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metal–protein interactions are essential for the function of at least one-third to one-half of all proteins in cells. The incorrect binding of a metal to a protein, however, can lead to harmful effects on the cell, including toxicity. The research proposed here is designed to identify the protein targets of metal stress and elucidate molecular mechanisms that lead to toxicity. The outcomes will advance our understanding of how proteins across the proteome respond to exposure to excess levels of biologically relevant Zn and Cu, with important implications for developing pharmacological agents to leverage metal stress against microbial pathogens and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROPOSAL NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most aggressive type of glioma, characterized by fast growth and poor prognosis, with an average survival of 15 months. Here we will apply a systematic molecular analysis to identify alternatively spliced genes in GBMs and then validate the biological function of those splice forms in patient- derived glioma stem cells. Our main goal is to identify putative alternative splicing genes as therapeutic targets for future studies in personalized medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Iron deficiency and inflammation are major stimulators of FGF23 production and FGF23 cleavage. In diseases associated with impaired FGF23 cleavage, such as CKD, iron deficiency and inflammation contribute to disproportionately and extremely elevated levels of circulating intact FGF23 compared to the levels of FGF23 cleaved peptides, which directly leads to adverse cardiovascular outcomes. This project proposes to investigate the function of C and N terminal FGF23 peptides as key regulators of iron metabolism, erythropoiesis and cardiac remodeling, providing novel therapeutic targets to improve outcomes related to FGF23 perturbations in patients with CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trauma is the leading cause of death and disability in the United States for people under the age of 45, and the current clinical management of complex extremity trauma is associated with high rates of complication, repeated hospitalizations, and permanent disability. Advancements in the treatment and functional restoration of composite bone-muscle traumas are hindered by the lack of available therapies that can repair both of these tissues together. Our research will guide the development of highly regenerative materials that work in concert with the body's healing programs and physical rehabilitation to restore the structure-function relationship within and between damaged muscle and bone with the potential to improve treatments for extremity trauma.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The prognosis is poor for patients with advanced head and neck cancer (HNC) and scientists are investigating whether radiotherapy and immunotherapy combinations can improve treatment outcomes; however, HNC patients with high risks for regional metastasis typically receive RT targeted to their primary tumor site as well as regional lymph nodes (RLN) in order to eradicate latent metastatic tumor cells. Using translational animal models, including orthotopic murine head and neck cancer and spontaneous canine oral carcinoma, we will define the impact of regional lymph node irradiation on the anti-tumor immune response for patients with head and neck cancer treated with RT and immunotherapy (IO). If we demonstrate RT+IO and RLN sparing improves outcomes in translational preclinical models of advanced HNC, the results of this project would challenge the current standard of care and clinical paradigm surrounding radiation, immunotherapy, and elective RLN irradiation for patients with advanced HNC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A national challenge in the biomedical sciences is to recruit, train, and retain the broadest and most diverse scientific talent pool possible. At the University of Utah, we are poised to tackle this challenge by leveraging our recent successes in recruiting underrepresented students into our graduate programs and extending our efforts to the postbaccalaureate population. We will establish the IDEAS in Neuroscience Program to support the intellectual, professional, and scientific development of trainees from underrepresented backgrounds who had limited access to research experience during their undergraduate training so that they can flourish and continue on the path to a career in biomedical science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a common endocrine condition affecting adult women, with significant comorbidities including diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and infertility. The earliest signs of PCOS appear in peripubertal females, representing an important opportunity for prevention. However, there is limited data on targeting at-risk girls for preventive interventions. This career development award will take a stepwise approach in examining the development of PCOS risk among young females in relation to physical activity behaviors, followed by a structured plan to refine and pilot a targeted physical activity intervention for peripubertal girls.

PHR: Relevance Physician-scientists are crucial for translating laboratory discoveries into improvements in patient care. As advances in biomedical research continue to expand our understanding of human biology, it is critical to maintain a strong cadre of physician-scientists who will be able to apply this new knowledge to improve health outcomes. The Vanderbilt Training of Otolaryngology Physician-Scientists (V-TOPS) program will develop physician- scientists in otolaryngology, preparing trainees to become independent investigators and leaders in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a significant public health challenge and a substantial cause of mortality, morbidity, and health care expenditure. The goal of this project is to decipher how dysregulated iron metabolism, a hallmark of CKD, may impact the course and progression of CKD. The studies will focus on ferritin, a key iron storage protein, in the macrophages and will examine the exciting novel approach of targeting macrophage ferritin expression to diminish CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative LPL is the enzyme that clears lipids from the blood, and ensuring optimal LPL levels and activity are important to preventing heart disease. After it is made, LPL must be folded into its active form and stored within cells until insulin signals it to move out of the cells. Here, we will study the mechanisms that ensure LPL has efficient transit through cells so it can reach the blood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recurrent urinary tract infections (rUTI) are especially common in older women, but our understanding of the natural progression of UTIs in this population is limited by inadequate inclusion in previous randomized trials. High quality, prospective data demonstrating the safety and acceptability of a culture-directed UTI treatment strategy is required to drive change in current clinical practice of prescribing empiric antibiotics for UTI symptoms in older women. Our initial pilot randomized trial of a culture-directed versus empiric antibiotic strategy for patient reported UTI in older women with rUTI is the first step towards attainment of key information for shared decision making to improve outpatient antibiotic stewardship in this population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pregestational diabetes specifically impacts neurulation leading to neural tube defects, the second most common structural birth defects in human. This project will determine the crosstalk between the mTOR- p70S6K1 signaling and the HIPPO kinase Lats1 in the inhibition of the tissue organizer Yap and failed neurulation. The study will provide new mechanistic insights and therapeutic targets for diabetic embryopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences) This doctoral readiness program, Iowa Diversifying Research Experiences And Mentorship (iDREAM), capitalizes on an outstanding T32 supported (JSPTPN) Neuroscience Graduate program with a highly successful track record of training neuroscientists from diverse backgrounds, particularly those from backgrounds underrepresented in STEM. It integrates an outstanding interdisciplinary neuroscience research environment with evidence-based practices designed to cultivate self-efficacy and a strong sense of belonging within the local and global neuroscience research communities. In doing so, iDREAM is designed to provide high quality research experiences and didactics to post-baccalaureate students from institutions that do not offer undergraduates substantial research opportunities, ultimately empowering trainees to be competitive for and successful in rigorous, top-tier neuroscience graduate programs and beyond.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm birth (PTB) is a leading cause of infant morbidity and mortality, and yet very few options are available for identifying and treating women at risk of PTB. Herein, we propose studies that build from exciting preliminary data using nanomedicine to probe fundamental questions regarding the role of epigenetic regulation in inflammation-induced PTB. If successful, we will generate fundamental mechanistic knowledge of epigenetic regulation in inflammation-induced PTB, as well as identify new cellular pathways that may be important targets for PTB prevention.

These results are not only important for fundamental understanding of stem cell biology, but may also inform innovative therapeutic solutions related to conditions such as hair loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The corneal neovascularization is a potential sight-threatening condition caused by the growing of new blood vessels into the normally avascular tissues. Fibroblast growth factor 2 and membrane-type 1 matrix metalloproteinase are highly induced by injury and infection in cornea. We propose a novel function of MMP-14 in regulating fibroblast growth factor 2-downstream signaling, and selective MMP-14 inhibitors can be potential therapeutics against FGF2/FGFR2-mediated corneal neovascularization.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project is to generate a collection of split-Gal4 lines that will be used to map the cell clusters characterized from scRNAseq studies to anatomy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative An increase in the amount of a protein called lamin B1 in the brain occurs in a disease known as Autosomal Dominant Leukodystrophy (ADLD) causing loss of myelin (a fatty substance covering nerves) and leading to muscle wasting, weakness and early death. Why more of lamin B1, a protein expressed in many different tissues, specifically causes demyelination is unknown. This proposal aims to understand the mechanisms that cause the specificity by characterizing elements that regulate the expression of this gene both in cells and mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Children who are born with a single pumping chamber in their heart instead of the usual two are particularly dependent on the health of their lung vessels to ensure blood flows freely through their lungs. Despite the importance of the lung blood vessels to SVHD patients, options to diagnose and treat inadequate lung vessel growth are limited; we are interested in testing if endothelin-1 (ET1, a small molecule that causes lung blood vessel walls to thicken) or two amino acid pathways (arginine and tryptophan, amino acids whose family of molecules can cause the pulmonary artery vessel walls to constrict) are present in abnormal concentrations in SVHD patients over time. This study will help us determine if the arginine and tryptophan pathways and ET1 are important in SVHD patients and will accelerate the identification of new drug targets to improve blood flow to the lungs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic has had a detrimental effect on mental health, especially for emerging adults. Utilizing the longitudinal Early Steps Multisite prevention trial of diverse, low-income families (N=731) from three geographic areas across the United States, we plan to take advantage of an 18-year-long prospective dataset in conjunction with new mental health assessments to examine risk and resilience factors for at-risk emerging adults, transitioning from adolescence to adulthood in the context of a pandemic. With genotyping on an extensive contemporary array, prospective data on experiences of discrimination, and neighborhood and community risk/resilience factors, we plan to examine direct, interactive, and cascading effects on mental health outcomes, and the long-term preventive effects of the Family Check-Up, in the context of growing up in poverty, and, more recently, the pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative A subset of T cells, regulatory T cells (Tregs) and plasma High Density Lipoproteins (HDL) both control immune responses, and curb inflammation. We found that HDL can directly promote Tregs survival, revealing possible cooperation between these two separate processes. By exploring how this works, we will have sustained impact on both the fields of lipoprotein biology and immunology and our work will open new avenues for potential therapeutic interventions in a host of auto- immune and chronic metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: There is an urgent need for learning initiatives that make science both approachable and relevant to American middle school students. This SBIR FastTrack award will enable Killer Snails, LLC to develop and commercialize VenomSquad, an immersive learning experience that leverages mobile augmented reality to put students in the role of scientists collaborating to solve a real-world problem: finding new, non-addictive pain therapies based on the venom of extreme creatures like scorpions, snakes, and cone snails. VenomSquad engages students with authentic health and medicine content while offering educators assessment tools to enhance students’ use of science and engineering practices, STEM identity, and interest in future careers in science and medicine, and a roadmap of best practices for applying emerging technologies in science learning for educators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will address quality of care issues associated with hearing loss in adults who have mild-to-moderate hearing loss and who have no access to hearing healthcare. This project will identify the needs of adults living in rural communities and will use this information to develop effective intervention strategies to mitigate the negative effects of hearing loss. This information is important to NIH’s mission because it will lead to options that will increase access and affordability of hearing healthcare for adults with mild-to-moderate hearing loss, a specific goal of NIDCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV infection remains a chronic disease requiring life-long therapy and creating a substantial burden for both patients and the healthcare system, therefore, efforts to eradicate HIV infection, or at least induce a state of viral control and drug-free remission are needed. This proposal examines the potential of a novel vaccine strategy to enhance the body's immune response to better control the virus and destroy HIV infected cells. The insights generated in this proposal will help maximize efficacy of current and future therapeutic vaccine strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: About 70% of patients with colorectal cancer who receive oxaliplatin will develop oxaliplatin-induced peripheral neuropathy (OIPN): numbness, tingling, and pain in the toes/feet and fingers/hands that can last for years. OIPN poses a serious health risk because it causes disability, falls, depression, impaired sleep, poor quality of life, and the need to reduce or stop oxaliplatin treatment. This randomized controlled trial will test a well- tolerated, widely available, non-opioid, preventive treatment for a debilitating chemotherapy side effect (OIPN) experienced by millions of cancer survivors, for which there is no good treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-influenza secondary bacterial infection (super-infection) can cause a cytokine storm, an overexuberant immune response, which leads to irreparable damage to the infected lungs. Eicosanoids are lipid mediators that play critical roles in the induction and resolution of inflammation during microbial infections. Deciphering the mechanism by which lipid mediators escalate a harmful inflammatory response will provide insights for developing novel therapeutic strategies for severe viral infections and their potentiated clinical complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poor quality primary care providers' vaccine recommendations lead to low adolescent human papillomavirus vaccination rates and hundreds of thousands of adolescents unnecessarily at risk for HPV-associated cancers and diseases. Though our provider communication intervention, called PCOM, was found to be effective for increasing adolescent HPV vaccination in primary care, its dissemination is limited by the need for significant research team involvement to teach providers how to use the intervention's components. To address this, we propose to develop and test a virtual version of PCOM, use mixed methods to assess contextual factors affecting its use compared to the original PCOM intervention, and develop an optimized version of PCOM for broad dissemination to increase adolescent HPV vaccination nationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insects transmit a wide variety of diseases to hundreds of millions of people each year, and the geographic ranges of some of these diseases have been increasing. Many of these insects rely on their chemosensory systems to identify their human hosts, their food, and their mates. This project is designed to elucidate how these systems operate and could lead to new means of manipulating them so as to control these insect vectors of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease negatively affecting the personality, behavior and language of patients, for which there is no cure. Our goals are to define the abnormal processes that contribute to the development of FTLD, as well as devise strategies to monitor and prevent disease progression. The novel insight and translational nature of our findings are expected to transform the field and improve the prognosis for patients with FTLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart disease remains a major health problem worldwide. This study will address the importance of a novel protein post-translational modification in the maintenance of heart function under resting and stressed conditions, and will investigate how this modification regulates the function of mitochondria, whose dysfunction is implicated in cardiac and other diseases. This research will also produce broadly applicable, basic biological insights.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it develops a novel exper- imental model of horizontal gene transmission in poxviruses. Horizontal gene transmission is a critical mecha- nism for the evolution of large DNA viruses to evade the immune response of their hosts, yet currently it can only be studied by indirect sequencing-based approaches. This project is relevant to the NIH’s mission because it opens new avenues of research to experimentally test this critical evolutionary pathway and understand how infectious disease-causing viruses acquire host genes to manipulate the immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mental illness stigma is a substantial barrier to recognizing and treating depression and anxiety among emerging adults, who are at greater risk of depression and anxiety and are more vulnerable to stigma than people of other age groups. Understanding how mental illness stigma develops, evolves, and impacts treatment outcomes during emerging adulthood can inform the tailoring of interventions to address stigma with greater efficacy. Findings from this three-year longitudinal study of emerging adults will inform the ideal timing of stigma interventions among emerging adults, identify which emerging adults are most vulnerable to the impact of stigma, which stigma mechanisms should be targeted in interventions, and how to combine stigma-reduction tools for subgroups of emerging adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the mechanisms contributing to pathological inflammation during malaria and the processes that govern the control of malaria parasites within the host can provide insight for the development of adjunctive therapies against this deadly infection. Using human samples and relevant model systems, we will investigate the interactions between multiple stages of the Plasmodium parasite and p53 pathways within relevant host tissues and how such interactions impact malaria pathogenesis and infection biology. Results from this study will provide mechanistic insight into the role of p53 in modulating malaria-induced pathogenesis and liver-stage infection, which may identify druggable targets for interventions aimed at mitigating malaria disease severity and/or liver-stage prophylaxis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Bitter taste receptors are expressed in many cell types beyond the tongue, including on immune cells called macrophages that patrol the airways and other tissues in the body. Stimulation of these receptors enhances macrophage uptake of bacteria and may reduce their inflammatory responses. Our goal is to understand the function of these taste receptors in macrophages so we can determine how to best leverage them to combat respiratory infections and reduce inflammation in airway diseases like chronic rhinosinusitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals who suffer from a diminished or lost sense of smell (Hyposmia/Anosmia) self-report compensating for the resulting lack of flavor and palatability of foods by adding more salt and self-report preferences for saltier foods. Despite the positive association between salt intake and cardiovascular disease, salt intake and preferences have not been assessed using validated measures in H/A individuals, and there is little guidance on how to improve diet quality in these individuals. This project aims to assess salt taste preferences and intake, as well as appetite in H/A compared with normosmic (i.e. a normal sense of smell) individuals, and to determine if capsaicin can help avoid excess salt use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The overall goal of this application is to provide support for the candidate to continue to expand her research and mentoring programs in sarcoidosis patient-oriented research. In addition to providing support for mentoring activities, this proposal will determine the relevant mechanisms by which metformin inhibits pulmonary sarcoidosis progression, with a specific focus on pSTAT3 signaling and immuno-metabolomic alterations of the sarcoidosis Th17 cell. The protected time, as well as the expanded clinical and basic research focus, will lay the foundation for future advanced translational investigations of sarcoidosis pathogenesis, thus providing an effective platform for the career development of the next generation of clinical researchers.

This K24 award proposal is based on Dr. Palaniappan’s plan to use human induced pluripotent stem cells, metabolomics and exosome profiling to model cardiometabolic disease, and aims to use this platform to offer mentorship, education, training, and advocacy for potential K23 awardees. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: SUMMARY  Although adipose inflammation is associated with obesity, the defined pathways and their role in the development  of the metabolic sequelae of obesity including non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) remain unclear. Our  studies will determine the cellular and molecular contributors to a novel LIFR-α/JAK/STAT3-dependent  Cytokine-Adipose-Hepatic Axis that facilitates adipose inflammation resulting in increased lipolysis and altered  expression of other inflammatory/metabolic cyto/adipokines in diet-induced obesity. The activation of this axis  limits adipose expansion, resulting in triacylglyceride mobilization from adipose to the liver and ultimately leading  to NAFLD and steatohepatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Based on its neuroanatomical connection, the mediodorsal thalamus (MD) could be a key taste-processing brain area; however, we have surprisingly very little knowledge on its role in gustation. Here we use electrophysiological recordings and chemogenetic manipulations in behaving rodents to uncover the contribution of MD neurons in integrating taste-related information, modulating neural activity in gustatory cortex (GC), and shaping gustatory behaviors. By providing a comprehensive system-level investigation on the role of MD in taste, these results will help us better understand how the brain controls feeding behavior as well as the circuits involved in dysfunctional eating.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The inner membrane complex (IMC) is a unique organelle that plays critical roles in host cell invasion and replication in apicomplexan parasites. We previously identified a large number of IMC proteins and have used functional studies to identify those that are essential for parasite survival. This work will determine precisely how these proteins function and interact with their partners which promises to lead to new therapies for T. gondii and related parasites.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Coronavirus-19 disease (COVID-19) is a global pandemic, and Veterans are at risk of infection and poor outcomes from COVID-19. However, long-term outcomes of COVID-19 have not been characterized or quantified. We will determine outcomes of patients after COVID-19, including their trajectory of health recovery and rehabilitation needs. We will evaluate risk factors for worse long-term outcomes from COVID-19 such as chronic lung disease and other chronic conditions in order to identify individuals at greatest risk of doing poorly and in need of rehabilitation services. We will assess the feasibility and acceptability of a virtually-delivered, home-based personalized telerehabilitation program for survivors of COVID-19. Our pilot study will inform future larger trials of this novel program to determine if it can improve function and well-being of individuals after COVID-19.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: NARRATIVE Hearing deficits are pervasive in military veterans owing to noise exposures, head trauma, and aging among other factors. To restore hearing completely in the severely damaged cochlea, a biological solution such as stem cell therapy is required to replace the sensory epithelia. Here, we propose a series of experiments deriving inner ear-like donor cells from pluripotent stem cells and implanting these into the deafened auditory epithelium.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: HIV care continuum gap remains a major problem in the country of Georgia. To help improving national efforts for successful implementation of “End AIDS” strategy in the country this proposal to build capacity in conducting implementation science research that will address gaps in HIV care in the country. This addresses a high priority topic from the NIH strategy on reducing the incidence of HIV/AIDS by implementing strategies to improve HIV testing and entry into prevention services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Despite the importance of extrahypothalamic corticotropin releasing factor (CRF) and its type 1 receptor (CRF1) in the development of ethanol dependence, the role of this system in amygdala-cortical circuits has not yet been delineated. The present application will provide new molecular and circuit information on CRF function and neuroadaptation that may drive ethanol dependence and withdrawal. The results could be invaluable in the development of new pharmacotherapeutics for the treatment of alcoholism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE According to 2018 data collected by the CDC, 128 people die per day from opioid overdose (CDC/NCHS). This number represents the culmination of a 40% increase in deaths attributed to opioid overdose since 2015, despite aggressive public messaging campaigns, policies to curb availability of non-prescription opioids, and wide-spread awareness of the dangers associated with opioid misuse. This proposal aims to understand how individual variability for non-drug rewards relates to escalation of fentanyl-seeking and define the neurocircuitry and genomic contributors to these relationships.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in HIV prevention, the HIV incidence among young men who have sex with men (YMSM) is increasing, threatening to derail achievement of the United States End the HIV Epidemic goals. Although, pre- exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a highly effective HIV prevention method, adherence was sufficiently low to comprise efficacy among a high proportion of YMSM in multiple clinical trials and demonstration projects. In this study, we will leverage a novel urine point-of-care drug-level test for PrEP adherence, to both enhance and target adherence counseling among YMSM, with the goal of preventing HIV infections among this critically at- risk group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Proposal Narrative Lack of effective imaging methods for detecting residual breast cancer and predicting treatment outcomes remain a major barrier to effective therapy. The proposed research will develop new strategies to enhance imaging signals and map the tumor-stroma ratio noninvasively using optical imaging methods. This work will enable improved detection of small lesions that may harbor recurrent tumor cells and investigate how the relationship between cancer cells and stroma relates to disease outcome.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: This application from the BRTI responsive to Fogarty HIV Research Training Program for Low-and  Middle-Income Country Institutions will build capacity at academic institutions in Zimbabwe for  laboratory, data science and genomics for excellence in HIV research. The program combines  individual level and institutional level capacity building by training young researchers from a  variety of disciplines in the skills required to formulate, conduct and report on research  related  to HIV drug resistance, prevention, pathogenesis and transmission. Effective training of PhDs and  postdoctoral fellows to become research leaders, mentors and supervisors will mitigate brain drain  and develop academic and scientific leadership to guide public health policy and practice at  national level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it evaluates a novel therapeutic option—rapid-onset opioids—for exertional dyspnea, one of the most common and distressing symptoms in cancer patients. Rapid- onset opioids are not currently routinely used to treat dyspnea, despite strong theoretical and empirical support, and available treatments for dyspnea are lacking. This project is relevant to the mission of the National Institutes of Health because effective management of dyspnea may ultimately help improve function and quality of life in cancer patients suffering from this devastating symptom; a better understanding of how opioids affect dyspnea will help us to devise new, more effective treatments for this highly debilitating condition.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Our Program for Advanced ReseArch Capacities for AIDS in Peru (PARACAS) plans to expand its current focus of providing long term, sustainable care to people living with HIV/AIDS and actively contribute to eliminating pediatric HIV in Peru. PARACAS will reinforce the doctoral-level Implementation Science mentored-research training for outstanding young and mid-career health researchers; this will allow them to design and test effective interventions tailored to the health context. Our PARACAS renewal should consolidate the proficient and passionate HIV scientific workforce in Peru that is needed to reach an AIDS free generation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative:  Dysregulation in cell metabolism leads to many prevalent human diseases. Yet, tools that are able to map the metabolic activity inside single living cells are lacking. This proposal aims to develop platforms enabling high- speed, high-content, and high-sensitivity mapping of cell metabolism, with a focused application to metabolic reprograming in drug-resistant cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed project focuses on characterizing the genes, regulatory elements and pathways associated with frugivory (fruit based diet). Utilizing primates and bats, both of which have species that have a high fruit diet, we will use a combination of comparative genomics, functional genomics and mouse engineering to detect the genes, regulatory elements and pathways involved in this phenotype. This research will improve genotypephenotype predictions with regards to diet and environment and genetic factors elucidated here have the potential to assist therapeutic developments for people with metabolic diseases like diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Excision of introns from pre-mRNA is critical in the pathway of gene expression. This excision occurs within spliceosomes and requires precise recognition – during both spliceosome assembly and splicing catalysis – of three sites (two splice sites and a branch site) to appropriately join exonic coding sequences. Mutations in components of the U2 snRNP are implicated in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and other cancers, and mutations that alter snRNP levels underlie spinal muscular atrophy (SMA). The roles of small molecule IP6 and mutations in U2 snRNA, identified here, have not previously been investigated. Our studies will provide a better understanding of U2 snRNPs, their interactions with the RNA ligands that are substrates for catalysis, and how disease-related mutations alter this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative (relevance): Despite appropriate treatments, chronic blood disorders such as myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPN) and chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) (called here collectively MPD) can transform respectively into secondary acute myeloid leukemia (sAML) or blast crisis (BC) CML, which are very poorly responsive to currently available treatments. This proposal seeks to understand the mechanisms through which deficit of a molecule called miR- 142 confers to the MPD cells a more aggressive clinical behavior that transforms them into sAML/BC CML cells. To address the unmet need for effective therapies for these conditions, we will also develop a novel drug called CpG-M-miR-142 designed to restore levels of miR-142 and hopefully to lead to a cure in these otherwise poor- risk patients.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: This research will develop and explore a new imaging technology (MR Elastography) that provides unique diagnostic information that cannot be obtained using conventional imaging techniques. The research has already shown that MR Elastography has a promising role in the detection of important complications of chronic liver disease, an important health problem in the US and worldwide, as an alternative to invasive biopsy. MR Elastography has many other potential applications, such as cancer detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This study will provide new information about how social stressors contribute to obesity among Mexican and Filipino American women. Specifically, it tests the hypothesis that stressors lead to eating behaviors and dietary changes and that alter the brain-gut-microbiome axis. A better understanding of the role of how stress “gets under the skin” to contribute to alterations in the brain and gut microbial metabolites in obesity, could lead to novel therapeutic strategies tailored to treat altered ingestive behaviors and obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to advance and test Medication Education, Decision Support, Reminding, and Monitoring System 2.0 (MEDSReM-2), a theory-based, technology-enhanced comprehensive self-management system that supports hypertension medication adherence and blood pressure (BP) management for non-adherent older adults. MEDReM-2 builds on previously NINR-funded efforts (Multifaceted Prospective Memory Intervention R01; MEDSReM R21), as well as advanced technology tools (e.g., optical image capture, reliable BP monitoring transmitted wirelessly) to foster self-management of hypertension, through greater perceived competence and autonomy, and reduced cognitive demand. We will test the efficacy of MEDSReM-2 in a randomized controlled trial of 224 non-adherent older adults with hypertension, randomized to MEDSReM-2 (n=112) versus education control (n=112), in a 6-month study to assess BP medication adherence (primary outcome), and systolic blood pressure, perceived competence and autonomy, and mobile device proficiency (secondary outcome).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Low back pain (LBP) causes more years lived with disability than any other health condition. This research will develop and validate approaches to predict LBP-related outcomes for Veterans by leveraging information from the electronic health record and Veterans’ genetic risk profiles. The project will analyze data from the Million Veteran Program and other large genomic biobanks. The information gained from this research may be used in the future to tailor treatment approaches to the unique characteristics of individual Veterans with LBP and lumbar spinal disorders.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: The focus of this training program is to improve HIV-related outcomes of adolescents (10 to 19 years) and youth (20 to 24 years) in Haiti by providing research training to extend adolescent HIV service from the clinic to the community. A multidisciplinary group of investigators, including four PhDs, will be trained in four priority adolescent health research areas including HIV prevention, HIV treatment, HIV/TB co-infection, and HIV and non-communicable diseases. The goal is to train the next generation of Haitian leaders at GHESKIO and the Haitian Ministry of Health who will conduct community-based research with the ultimate goal of improving health outcomes among adolescents and youth in Haiti.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Telomere maintenance mechanisms (TMMs) are molecular hallmarks of cancer and are linked to significant metabolic reprogramming in brain tumors. Our goal is to leverage this link to identify novel, translational, metabolic imaging biomarkers that can non-invasively inform on TMM status and, thereby, provide a means of distinguishing tumor from normal brain, edema or necrosis, of monitoring tumor recurrence, of tracking response to therapy including novel TMM inhibitors and of monitoring the development of resistance to TMM inhibitors. This research will, therefore, have the potential to significantly enhance quality of life and care for brain tumor patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because the development of imaging tools capable of assessing structural and functional changes in the brain’s microvessels (i.e. vasculome) over the life cycle of a brain tumor model will yield invaluable insight into their role in brain cancer progression, tumor spread, and treatment efficacy. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission because the assessment of changes in the vasculome of patient-derived brain tumor models over their entire lifetime would help elucidate the role of non-angiogenic brain tumor growth in resistance to antiangiogenic therapies, vascular modulation associated with immunosuppression of the brain tumor microenvironment, and help identify new biomarkers and treatment strategies for patients with brain cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative We aim to use whole genome sequence and blood omic biomarkers in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) study to illuminate the pathobiology of type 2 diabetes (T2D) and its quantitative traits fasting glucose, insulin and hemoglobin A1c. We will integrate TOPMed results with beta cell-, liver-, fat- and muscle-specific omics and epigenomic annotation in the Accelerating Medicine Partnership (AMP) T2D Diabetes epiGenome Atlas and with hundreds of additional genomic trait associations in the AMP T2D Knowledge Portal for ‘in silico variant-to-function’ and phenomic studies aimed to find new approaches to address the global epidemic of T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative  The recent trend in opioid drug abuse and overdose deaths has reached an epidemic level. Naltrexone has shown great promise in assisting people recovering from opioid dependence, but current treatment induction and regimens remain problematic for many. The goal of this project is to optimize and advance a patient-friendly, 380 mg 2- month naltrexone PLGA formulation from the lab scale to phase I clinical trials.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative This grant seeks to investigate the effects of estradiol on perimenopausal-onset anhedonia and psychosis and reward-related brain functioning measured by simultaneous positron emission tomography and functional magnetic resonance imaging (PET-MR). Results of this project will increase our understanding of anhedonia and psychosis during the menopause transition and will have the potential to deliver validated molecular imaging targets to use in future mechanistic clinical trials of novel treatments for perimenopausal-onset anhedonia and psychosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE B cells produce the antibodies that help us control infections and are the primary mechanism though which vaccines work. Although we understand well the general biology of B cells, the rules determining how the immune system chooses what targets to make antibodies too, and how the durability of these antibodies is controlled remain unclear. Better understanding of these rules will be essential to designing more potent vaccines against variable pathogens such as influenza, HIV, HCV, and SARS-CoV2.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE As Africa's most populous country, Nigeria is one of six nations facing the threats of high HIV burden, low combination antiretroviral treatment (ART) coverage, and slow decline in new HIV infections. While ART programs have turned HIV into a chronic condition, morbidity from HIV-associated NCDs is becoming more common as HIV-infected individuals live longer, encumbering an already troubled and undercapacitated health system and emphasizing the need to develop clinical trial research capacity to generate evidence to tackle the burden of HIV and NCDs in Nigeria. In response to this need, the Vanderbilt-Nigeria Building Research Capacity in HIV/Non-communicable Diseases (NCDs) (`V-BRCH') program harnesses the longstanding and highly successful research partnership between Aminu Kano Teaching Hospital and the Vanderbilt Institute for Global Health to establish a research and training platform that will create a cohort of highly skilled Nigerian investigators with the capacity to lead independent clinical trials research focused on the intersection of HIV and NCDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to test the hypothesis that bi-directional interaction between tumor microenvironment and region-specific macrophages plays a role in tumor progression thru regulation of hypoxia and acidosis. In vivo mapping of tumor hypoxia using innovative magnetic resonance technology in mice deficient in specific macrophage populations or lacking hypoxia-regulated macrophage functions in a mouse model of breast cancer may provide new insight into a macrophage/tumor microenvironment axis that suppresses the efficacy of clinically-relevant anti-cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Abstract Pseudomonas aeruginosa (P. aeruginosa) is versatile opportunistic pathogen that can cause devastating persistent infections; P. aeruginosa successfully colonizes a hyper-inflammatory environment of the wound and can persist for months or years even with aggressive therapy. The overall objective of this study is to develop bacteriophages that can be used alone or in combination with traditional antibiotics to eradicate these infections. This research will directly benefit patients with chronic wound infections, the numbers of which are substantially increasing in our health care system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Because irritability in late childhood and adolescence predicts mental disorders and poorer functional outcomes across the lifespan, identifying the neural mechanisms of irritability across the transition to adolescence is paramount to intervene before youth irritability problems harden into entrenched psychiatric disorders in later adolescence and adulthood. Our overall goal is to identify reward- and inhibition-related neural pathways that characterize changes in irritability across the transition to adolescence. Our project is significant because it will be a catalyst for a research program to inform precision medicine for irritability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is largely resistant to immunotherapy, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy, in part due to presence of an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment that limits adaptive tumor control. This proposal investigates how macrophages responding to damage-associated molecular patterns released from dying cells reinforce the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment through activation of the inflammasome. A deeper understanding of mechanisms underlying immunosuppression following radiation therapy will allow us to therapeutically target these pathways to achieve durable responses in a larger subset of patients than currently attainable.

PHR: Narrative This application focuses on a family of RNA-binding proteins (ZFP36/TIS11) identified in our screens are able to control “stemness” and differentiation of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells. It tests the hypothesis that 3’UTR targeting of key hematopoiesis-regulating mRNAs by the ZFP36/TIS11 family represents a novel posttranscriptional mechanism of stem cell differentiation and leukemic transformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative In order to advance our understanding of the nature of biomedical changes associated with Alzheimer’s disease (AD), we will develop a novel, non-invasive, and cost-effective retinal vascular biomarker for early AD risk detection and disease monitoring. An understanding of metrics of retinal tissue oxygenation and their associations with retinal structure and other functional measures in AD patients will provide information valuable for the early detection, management, and monitoring of the disease in the preclinical phase. Outputs from this proposal will be used to identify whether a novel retinal vascular biomarker can be used to characterize distinct cognitive groups and thus identify it as a potential retinal biomarker of early AD risk detection and disease monitoring.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Creation of sperm and egg that contribute to our next generation requires an incredible series of coordinated events, including recombination and synapsis between homologous chromosomes, and two rounds of chromosome segregation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Supercomputers will be used to simulate a major antibiotic target (the ribosome) in atomic detail. Atomistic and reduced-model molecular simulations will be used to understand ribosome conformational changes, and effects of antibiotics on these processes. Results will be closely integrated with single molecule data. Testable predictions will be made to guide future experiments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Identification of extranodal extension (ENE) for head and neck cancer in the pretreatment setting would be extremely useful in selecting the optimal treatment strategy for patients. Currently, ENE can only be definitively diagnosed pathologically after surgery, and pretreatment radiographic ENE prediction has proven unreliable for expert diagnosticians. This project uses artificial intelligence to identify ENE pretreatment on Computed Tomography, with the goal of developing a clinically usable tool to help patients with newly diagnosed head and neck cancers and their physicians choose the most effective treatment strategy that minimizes the risk of side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission to improve health as it will test the notion that rifampin, a widely used and safe antibiotic, can be repurposed as a safe and effective treatment for idiopathic infantile hypercalcemia, a lifelong disorder associated with elevated levels of blood and urinary calcium and recurrent renal stones. Patients with idiopathic infantile hypercalcemia manifest hypersensitivity to vitamin D due to genetic deficiency of CYP24A1, an enzyme that inactivates vitamin D metabolites. There is no standard treatment for the vitamin D defect in idiopathic infantile hypercalcemia, and the studies that we propose have the potential to normalize vitamin D metabolism in this disorder, thus providing a novel medical treatment for patients with idiopathic infantile hypercalcemia as well as other forms of renal stone disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiovascular disease is a progressive condition that typically results in increasingly invasive interventions over the lifetime of the patient. The significance of this proposal is in the ability to provide a patient specific intervention that can be automatically adapted over time. To achieve this goal, several technical innovations will be implemented including partial electrical nerve block of sympathetic cardiac activity and direct norepinephrine (NE) readings to assess cardiac function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Overall Significance to Public Health (Project Narrative)  The overarching objective of this COBRE application is to establish a new biomedical imaging research center with appropriate infrastructure and research capacity along with a multidisciplinary mentoring team to support the promising research project leaders of junior investigators as they conduct the innovative translational cancer research projects using advanced medical imaging technology. The success of this COBRE will ultimately have a high research and clinical impact lead to a reduced cancer burden both for individual patients and society as a whole.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Transcriptional memory is a biological phenomenon first described in yeast genetics studies and now widely seen in other organisms. Using the well-organized herpesvirus mini-chromosome as a tool to replicate the phenotypes and study molecular mechanisms is a very convenient, efficient, and highly cost-effective approach to understand underlining mechanisms of enhancer-promoter regulations. Understand how transcription memory (latent KSHV chromatin) is maintained will help us to understand regulation of herpesvirus latency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This MERIT project will clarify circadian mechanisms at molecular levels that were heretofore unreachable. Biological clocks have been found to be crucial for physical and mental health, and knowledge of circadian mechanisms along with the development of therapies to properly phase sleep will allow us to enhance health, performance, and well-being in addition to improving the quality of life for depressed subjects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is the necessary first step to building a stronger evidence-base for the use of diuretics as a management strategy for BPD, which are frequently prescribed despite limited evidence for their benefit. This study and the proposed larger clinical trial will answer the current, relevant clinical questions of whether individual patients in the current treatment era derive short-term benefits from diuretic treatment and whether diuretic treatment is safe and effective in the long-term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Although it is widely known that people with opioid use disorder struggle to abstain from opioid use even when receiving evidence-based opioid substitution treatment, the cognitive and neural changes that give rise to reuse risk remain poorly understood. In this project, we use new behavioral, computational, and imaging tools to evaluate the role of a potential modifiable neurocognitive mechanism of reuse risk: unrealistic optimism driving more uncertainty tolerant decision making. Ultimately, our findings have the potential for clear benefits in a clinical setting, providing easily implementable tools to monitor and potentially manage reuse risk, and evaluate clinical status in individual patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Voice problems constitute the most common communication disorder across the lifespan. Many malignant and benign vocal fold lesions require surgical removal using cold cutting tools or lasers, leaving a wound and in some cases a large void in the lamina propria and/or a tear in the epithelium. We are developing novel biomaterials that can be injected or deposited layer by layer into the wound site to help vocal fold tissue healing and promote the permanent regeneration of engineered tissue with the same viscoelasticity and morphology than the native uninjured lamina propria. These materials and tools would help patients with vocal fold injuries to completely recover their voice, with less hoarseness or dysphonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells change shape and move, during their normal functions and during the course of various disease processes. Molecules inside the cell are responsible for cell shape and movement, and we study how these molecules work. Our results are fundamental, and they provide essential knowledge for research focused on many diseases, including cancer, infections and arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This research application is focused on the structure and function of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, which are neurotransmitter receptors critical for triggering muscle contraction and regulating brain function. They are major drug targets in myasthenic syndromes (muscle weakness), neurodegeneration and mental illness, and they are the targets of neuromuscular blockers used during anesthetic induction. The proposed studies will elucidate how neurotransmitters, venom toxins and modulators interact with this important class of cell surface receptors, providing essential information for improved therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Fibrosis is a common and debilitating physiological response to injury and inflammation in many tissues and organs, however very little is known about whether there is a fibrotic response to inflammatory diseases of the central nervous system (CNS) including multiple sclerosis, neuromyelitis optica, stroke, and CNS infections. We have identified that a robust fibrotic scar forms in response to CNS neuroinflammatory lesion formation and we will test the hypothesis that a fibrotic scar limits repair following neuroinflammatory disease. We will further examine the molecular mechanisms that lead to fibrotic scar formation, with the goal of identifying potential therapeutics to aid in repair following neuroinflammatory disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Understanding the autonomic regulation of the liver and manipulating the brain-liver circuit have the potential to improve hepatic glucose and lipid metabolism in patients with diabetes. The potential to target specific populations of neurons to restore metabolic homeostasis will provide novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of type 1 and type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The extent to which visual impairment is associated with the patterns of the longitudinal cognitive trajectory of aging adult is unclear. The goal of this proposal is to evaluate the complex associations among visual impairment, brain neurodegeneration, CVD risk factors, APOE ε4 genotype, and other sociopsychological factors as they relate to the longitudinal trajectories of cognitive decline and the linking mechanisms between visual impairment and cognitive decline. Visual impairment is a prevalent condition that is highly treatable and represents an important modifiable risk factor that can be prevented and treated as an effective means to preserve cognitive function and improve quality of life.

PHR: Public exposure to radiation by large-scale radiation incidents is a rising global concern, but there are no FDA-approved therapeutics for radiation injury. The outcome of these studies will identify a new medical countermeasure to treat radiation injury by targeting the gut microbiota.
