IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE This K24 Mid-Career Investigator Career Development Award in Patient-Oriented Research seeks support for Christopher Pittenger, a tenured Associate Professor of Psychiatry at Yale University and Director of the Yale OCD Research Clinic; training and mentorship activities supported by this award will take place in the context of two NIMH-funded projects, R01 MH100068 and R01 MH116038. The Award will support Dr. Pittenger in a robust training plan aimed at increasing his skills in statistics and in the design and analysis of fMRI experiments, with the goal of making him a more effective collaborator and mentor in these domains. The robust Mentorship Plan supports a range of trainees, from high school students through junior faculty, with a particular focus on the research track with the Yale Psychiatry Residency, of which Dr. Pittenger will become the Director in the coming years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using combined genetic, biochemical, spectroscopic and structural approaches, we propose to investigate a novel mechanism of N2 reduction that involves dynamic structural rearrangements of the active site of Mo-nitrogenase. Through our proposed studies, we hope to facilitate a (re)calibration of the mechanistic thinking of nitrogenase and establish a framework for further mechanistic exploration of this intricate reaction. Success along this line will not only lead to a molecular depiction of the intricate catalytic mechanism of nitrogenase, but also facilitate development of nitrogenase-based applications in the long run.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed “Child Mental Health in HIV-impacted Low-resource settings in Developing countries: Global Research Fellowship” (CHILD-GRF) training program will support the development of a cadre of 18 well- trained, culturally-embedded in-country scientists from Uganda to conduct child and adolescent mental health (CAMH) research in the context of HIV/AIDS using rigorous and culturally-congruent research methods. This will ultimately provide a robust platform for the development and implementation of culturally-congruent evidence-based HIV prevention and CAMH interventions for youth and families living in communities heavily impacted by HIV/AIDS. By producing a sustainable network of individuals in key research institutions who are well trained in various aspects of CAMH, HIV/AIDS research, and dissemination & implementation research, this training program, in partnership with Makerere University in Uganda, will contribute to improving CAMH and HIV prevention efforts, both of which have implications for public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: High iron stores are toxic due to metal-induced oxidative stress that promotes multiple organ damage, including cardiomyopathy, liver cirrhosis, hypertriglyceridemia, diabetes, and premature death. Using an iron chelator-coated ultrasmall nanochelator that captures iron from the plasma and liver, without distributing it into non-target tissues, we aim to develop subcutaneous injectable hydrogel formulations with increased exposure for 3 weeks. This strategy can decrease body iron burden and reduce the risk of iron-mediated organ toxicity, without overt chelator-related side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance Cancer researchers have identified genes and molecules that directly drive the proliferation, survival and metastasis of cancer cells. In addition, genes have been identified that can direct an altruistic form of cellular suicide that protects the organism from mistakes in development or DNA replication. We are developing small molecules, which we call TCIPs (Transcriptional Chemical Inducers of Proximity) that rewire the cancer cell to kill itself with its own driver and may enable an entirely new, less toxic and more effective approach to the treatment of blood cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance  Sex-specific differences exist in the cardiovascular system following acute injury and female hormone - estrogen is one critical factor to mediate such disparity. Our project aimed at investigating sex-related cardiac mitochondrial responses to inflammatory cytokine and systematically evaluating rapid action of estrogen on preventing mitochondrial dysfunction. These findings will greatly improve our scientific knowledge and offer the basis of developing novel interventions for cardiac recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project is relevant to public health because it addresses cancer drug resistance, a National Cancer Institute (NCI) scientific priority. Malignant cartilage bone cancers have a poor prognosis due to lack of effective drug treatments. The goal of this proposal is to systematically evaluate promising new treatments that target aspartate β-hydroxylase (ASPH), a cell surface protein that influences the growth, spread, and resistance of cancer cells, with the ultimate goal of improving patient survival and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common cardiac arrhythmia. It occurs in 9% of the population older than 65, and is associated with increased morbidity and mortality. We recently found in humans that the NADPH oxidase isoform 4 (NOX4) is markedly increased in patients with AF. Here we will test the hypothesis in novel fish and mouse models that NOX4 activates novel oxidative stress mechanisms and autophagy that produce specific cellular and electrophysiological changes leading to AF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Babies born prematurely who are exposed to oxygen in the neonatal intensive care unit are at increased risk of airway diseases such as asthma, which makes it important to understand how oxygen detrimentally impacts the developing airways. The goal of this proposal is to use human cell and mouse models to investigate a novel, targetable mechanism (hydrogen sulfide) that we believe is normally protective in developing airways and can help to reduce the reactivity and fibrosis that occurs with oxygen exposure (thus reducing asthma in babies and children). The importance of our work lies in the potential application of novel drugs that can enhance hydrogen sulfide for improving airway function in preterm infants and reduce the risk of developing asthma later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE KRAS is the dominant oncogenic driver of pancreatic cancer, and new small molecule inhibitors of KRAS have the potential to transform the treatment of this disease. This proposal will use an integrative strategy with genomic and functional genetic approaches in new human and mouse models of pancreatic cancer to investigate the molecular mechanisms of response and resistance to KRAS inhibitors. These studies will form a foundation for development of new biomarkers and combination therapy strategies with KRAS inhibition that can be evaluated in future clinical trials for pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Autophagy, a major way to clear cellular debris, is crucial to prevent accumulation of damaged and non-functional proteins and organelles. Clinically, protein clearance by autophagy is required to prevent many diseases including neurodegeneration at old age. As autophagy declines with age, problems with damaged proteins worsen during life and shorten healthspan. We have established an animal model for endosomal microautophagy (eMI) in the fruitfly Drosophila. eMI is a form of autophagy that can be selective for proteins with a targeting motif and does not require protein unfolding and thus is able to deal with protein aggregates frequently occurring in disease. Having identified eMI in a genetically easily tractable model organism enables us to better characterize the physiological relevance of eMI and simplifies the identification and characterization of novel pathway components with the ultimate goal to identify novel treatment options to improve healthspan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Radiation therapy produces DNA double strand breaks (DSBs) which are thought to be the critical lesion producing the death of cancer cells. We have recently discovered that ZEB1, a well-established driver of the epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) has a novel function in DNA repair namely recruiting 53BP1 to DSB’s. We will elucidate the role of the ZEB1-53BP1 axis in DSB repair and test whether this axis can be exploited therapeutically as a biomarker for sensitivity and/or to make cancer cells more sensitive to radiation and PARP inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to total body irradiation produced by nuclear accidents causes gastrointestinal acute radiation syndrome a state of severe intestinal mucosal barrier damage and loss of tissue integrity. Specific members of the intestinal microbiota promote tissue repair and function. Here we will generate novel microbiome therapeutic agents and microbiome-promoting dietary interventions that, by specifically targeting intestinal barrier function, minimize GI-ARS and increase survival after total body irradiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Non-dividing muscle and nerve cells have limited options to clear harmful biological insults. One such insult is the progressive accumulation of protein aggregates that destroys cellular function and may result in death. The overall goal of this application is to understand how cells normally clear aggregated proteins to eventually develop successful therapeutic strategies to maintain healthy cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Opioid use disorder is a key driver of the U.S. opioid overdose crisis, yet treatment remains both underused and unequal. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on identifying modifiable structural predictors of treatment initiation and retention in care for opioid use disorder. The results of this project are expected to inform multilevel interventions equitably deliver treatment for opioid use disorder, ameliorate the overall health burden of substance use disorders, and reduce health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary cause of sickness and mortality in respiratory viral infections in humans is often not uncontrolled viral replication, but respiratory distress caused by pro-inflammatory cell infiltration and a loss of epithelial cell resilience and function. An understanding of the baseline host factors present in diverse people is critical to better determine the risk of susceptible populations and novel therapeutic strategies to effectively promote tissue resilience. Importantly, as vaccines for both influenza and SARS-CoV-2 are non-sterilizing, and variants continue to emerge for both, underlying causes of severe viral respiratory diseases will still continue to require adjunctive therapies to complement vaccination campaigns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This research will develop and examine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of an intervention to improve psychological distress symptom management related to chronic stigma exposure among Black GM women in a community-based setting. The long-term goal of this intervention is to disrupt the complex interacting psychosocial and behavioral factors that exacerbate symptoms of psychological distress with the hope to eventually prevent and/or reduce poor health outcomes in Black GM women experiencing chronic stigma. The proposed study has high public health significance because it plays an essential role in developing and evaluating evidence-based interventions to improve health among a historically disenfranchised group, i.e., Black GM women. 2

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transposons are mobile DNA elements that are ubiquitous in genomes of all animals, including humans. Overactive transposons are correlated with DNA damage and infertility, but it is unclear whether the transposons are playing a causative role in infertility. In this proposal, we will examine transposon activity in germ cells and experimentally block or activate transposition to assess the effects on genome integrity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to study the immunophenotype of PTPN11 and NPM1 mutant acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and the mechanism of resistance to cytotoxic and targeted therapies. Because PTPN11 mutations can activate similar signaling pathways as FLT3-ITD, we hypothesize that the addition of PTPN11 mutations to NPM1+ AML can clinically phenocopy NPM1+/FLT3-ITD AML with adverse outcomes and therapy resistance. Successful completion of these aims will provide an understanding of the biology of PTPN11 and NPM1 mutant AML and how these cells resist treatment so that more effective therapies can be developed for this patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Pseudohypoparathyroidism is a genetic disorder with limited treatment options, characterized by early-onset obesity, short stature and resistance to multiple hormones. This phase 2 clinical trial and open-label extension study will test the efficacy of theophylline, a phosphodiesterase inhibitor, in pseudohypoparathyroidism. We hypothesize that theophylline will cause weight loss, slow the rate of growth plate closure and decrease hormone resistance in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate how the brain controls behavior by guiding the flow of neural activity between brain regions. Disrupting the brain’s ability to control the flow of neural activity leads to the deficits observed in many neuropsychiatric and neurological disorders, including schizophrenia and autism. By providing insight into the mechanisms controlling neural activity, our work will lay the foundation for improved diagnostics and treatments of these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The Rhode Island Child Health Study (RICHS) cohort provides a unique and innovative birth cohort resource focused on the fundamental role of the placenta in the programming of children’s health and disease risk by the prenatal environment. During the prior funding period, cohort resources and investigators have made seminal contributions to children’s environmental health and to training the next generation of environmental health scholars. Infrastructure support for sustaining the cohort will support new longitudinal assessments within this extensively characterized resource, enrichment of data management and sharing activities, and new efforts to diversify the participants, measures, and workforce for the cohort—all serving the ultimate goal of catalyzing transformative environmental health research by strengthening and diversifying the scientific workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is to study the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying Zika virus vertical transmission from mother to fetal brain and its associated microcephaly. The outcomes of this study will pave the way toward identification of innovative targets for the development of new treatments or preventive strategies against ZIKV- and possibly other viruses-mediated brain teratogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Plasmodium vivax parasites have the unique ability to remain dormant in the liver before reactivating weeks or months later to cause relapse infections. This feature, that greatly complicates vivax malaria elimination efforts, remains poorly understood due to the difficulties of studying P. vivax liver-stage parasites. We propose to use a combination of novel ‘omic approaches, including the characterization of host cells and parasites spatially and at the single cell level, to study dormancy in vivo in a non-human primate model, and well as in vitro. Our studies will generate novel biological insights on the regulation of liver-stage dormancy and provide immediately-relevant clinical information to better control this important human pathogen.

PHR: Project Narrative Many pathologic conditions are associated with genetic or acquired abnormalities in the levels of hormones secreted by the central nervous system. This project studies Gbeta5-R7, a protein complex highly expressed in the brain, and the new finding is it is responsible for maintaining normal body weight in mice. Mutations in the human genes that encode Gbeta5-R7 are genetically linked in with obesity, and this research will develop a new avenue for understanding, diagnosing and treating obesity and other metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LOMA LINDA VETERANS ASSN RESEARCH & EDUC
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Developing strategies to treat osteoporosis, a major public health threat, would require a thorough understanding of the molecular mechanisms involved in the regulation of bone resorption and bone formation processes. Successful completion of the proposed in vitro studies using primary cultures derived from Lrrk1 knockout mice and in vivo experiments in CRISPR/Cas9 gene modified mice should lead to improved understanding of how leucine rich repeat kinase 1 (LRRK1) regulates osteopetrosis specific transmembrane protein 1 (OSTM1) activation, osteoclast function and thereby bone resorption. Our identification of LRRK1 direct biological substrates and confirmation of the role of LRRK1 phosphorylation of OSTM1 in regulation of osteoclast function and bone resorption in animal models will lead to development of novel anti-resorption drugs for treatment of patients with osteoporosis and osteoporotic fractures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Climate change poses an enormous threat to human health on a global scale. Because the health consequences of climate change vary by location, depending on complex relationships among population characteristics, livelihoods, and built and natural environmental conditions, understanding and mitigating the health impacts of climate change requires information on population and agricultural characteristics at the community level. By providing easy access to detailed data on demographic and socioeconomic characteristics and agricultural activity at community scales and making them readily linkable to data on health, IHGIS will serve as critical infrastructure to support a wide range of environmental health research for public health policy worldwide.

PHR: Project Narrative The goals of the proposed study are to test whether fatty acid supplementation to the diet during pregnancy reduces the risk for asthma and allergic disease in children at ages 5-6 years. The burden of asthma in the U.S. has fallen disproportionately on Black children living in low-resourced communities, for whom the prevalence, morbidity and mortality rates far exceeds those for White children. To our knowledge, this will be the first test of prenatal fatty acid levels on asthma and allergy in Black children living in low-resourced environments in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rapidly growing population of older breast cancer survivors (estimated to be >6 million by 2040) is at increased risk for cancer treatment-related accelerated aging. We hypothesize that targeting senescent cells with senolytic agents will improve the adverse age-related effects in frail older breast cancer survivors. If our hypothesis is correct, the impact on clinical practice would be substantial and of paramount importance.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative COVID-19 infection is associated with serious health outcomes for pregnant women, and adverse infant outcomes are more likely when a mother has COVID-19. Even though COVID-19 vaccines are considered safe during pregnancy, vaccination rates are very low among pregnant women. This study will involve in-depth assessments with pregnant and postpartum women, and with prenatal care providers, in order to help identify reasons for the low rate of COVID-19 vaccination among perinatal women, as well as possible solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evaluating the distribution of pathogens within airborne particles generated during breathing is essential for modeling disease transmission and optimizing mitigation strategies. In this project we propose an innovative microcyclone array technology to enable more effective aerobiology studies by improving the accessible particle size range, throughput, fraction count, resolution, and bioavailability. The aerosol fractionation technology, fabricated using a high resolution 3d printing technique, will be integrated with an established exhaled breath collection instrument, enabling system validation through a clinical study of influenza virus aerosol distribution during tidal breathing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) affects about 8% of pregnant women in the U.S. and China, and perpetuates the intergenerational cycle of obesity and type 2 diabetes. This project will measure unmethylated INS DNA, a biomarker of insulin-producing cells, in stored blood samples among women after GDM delivery to evaluate associations and predictive ability for new onset type 2 diabetes. If successful, our study will provide novel methodology to assess β-cell death and help transfer this assay into clinical practice for early prevention and potential treatment for inhibiting β-cell apoptosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative The current medical paradigm is to treat most patients according to standard clinical guidelines, which in the majority of cases results in all patients with a similar condition receiving substantially similar treatment, this is in opposition to personalized approaches which use prediction models to assign treatment. We aim to quantify the potential benefits of using a personalized approach by simulating the outcomes of predictive allocation in ~130 previously published NHLBI randomized controlled trials. We will then compare the outcomes of predictive allocation to a secondary simulation where all patients are treated similarly and thus determine under what circumstances and to what extent, would predictive allocation result in a net benefit at the population level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Many people think of type 1 diabetes as an autoimmune disease of the insulin-producing cells of the pancreas, however, the exocrine pancreas, which is involved in digestion, is also substantially impacted. The primary goal of this project is to determine when in the development of type 1 diabetes the exocrine pancreas becomes affected and whether stool or blood exocrine pancreas markers predict the onset of type 1 diabetes in those who are at risk. The secondary goal of this project is to investigate what is specifically causing the exocrine pancreas changes seen in type 1 diabetes.

PHR: Project Narrative Cells expressing LGR5 play key roles in organ/tissue development, homeostasis, regeneration, and disease, including cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Home health care services provide a critical mechanism to support older adults with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) to remain in their own homes for as long as possible, even after a disruption in care, such as caused by a disaster event. We hypothesize that older Americans with ADRD are at particular risk for poor health outcomes that result from the disruption of a disaster, requiring increased healthcare resources particularly at the end of life, where receiving home health services may be a protective factor. The proposed study will fill immediate and critical gaps in knowledge about the relationship between home health care use and conventional healthcare use after care disruptions and provide evidence for the use of home health care as a strategy to support individuals with ADRD and their caregivers to promote aging in place.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Neural crest and ectodermal placode cells are both transient embryonic progenitor cells that arise from the neural plate border. While ~10% of human birth defects affect early neural crest or placode development, the molecular mechanisms underlying these defects are largely unknown. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Acute Myeloid Leukemia Digital Twin (AML-DT) system is centered on personalized models that virtually represent a patient's disease; where patients and their doctors work together with an interactive dashboard to visualize dynamic changes in disease trajectory and to explore therapeutic possibilities. The proposed AML-DT prototype system visualizes patient history, makes predictions of disease progression and drug response which can be validated in clinical trials, and gives clinicians and patients a way to make better care plans by providing needed foresight. Our innovative solutions integrate detailed domain-specific knowledge graphs with multiscale dynamical models of the malignancy, providing a foundation for the development of the first AML Digital Twin.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuroblastoma (NB) arises in the sympathoadrenal lineage of the nervous system. An understudied highly lethal form of NB is characterized by an in-frame fusion within the ATRX gene (ATRX IFF), in which multiple chromatin-interacting domains are deleted from this ATP-dependent SWI/SNF-like chromatin remodeler. Our studies will reveal the role of ATRX IFFs in epigenomic reorganization, gene expression programs, protein interactions, and epigenetic inhibitor sensitivities of this aggressive NB subtype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PTSD is a highly debilitating mental illness that is difficult to treat. We have proposed a novel neurosensory account of PTSD emphasizing a tripartite sensory-prefrontal-cortex-amygdala (SPA) pathology. Taking a mechanistic, cognitive-affective neuroscience approach to elucidate this SPA pathology, this project will generate rich insights to significantly advance the conceptualization and treatment of PTSD and related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to study how poor sleep affects the glymphatic pathway – a network of channels that allow waste to exit the brain during sleep – in adolescents. Poor sleep is reported by an alarming number of adolescents worldwide and leads to an increased risk of motor vehicle accidents, poor school performance, impaired social functioning, and other adverse outcomes. This study will contribute to fundamental knowledge about sleep and brain function in a particularly vulnerable population and has broad ramifications from pre-clinical research to public health policy (e.g., school start times).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Significant differences in neurotransmitters have been identified between rodents and humans, and this biological variance may partially explain why medications for neurodegenerative diseases that often show promise during preclinical development in rodent models fail to elicit the same therapeutic effect in humans. The proposed project will greatly improve our knowledge of the impact of age on neurotransmitters and their associated behaviors in chimpanzees, our closest living relative whose brain naturally develops the pathologic hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease. By gaining a better understanding of species-specific alterations in neurotransmitters, we can potentially improve therapeutic efficacy for age-related neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: No technology to date can provide customized therapy that adapts to the individual’s needs with regard to the specific FoG triggering scenarios. The wearable sensor and smart-phone system proposed has the potential to detect different environmental triggers and deliver an optimized dose of vibration at the precise moment it is needed. For people who are isolated in their homes and at risk for falls due to FoG, this new technology has potential to improve their mobility, independence and quality of life; and have important economic benefits for patients, their families, and for the health-care system as a whole.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To understand the neural basis of behavior, it is important to move beyond correlational validations of hypotheses toward their causal validations in real-time and/or closed-loop perturbation experiments and to study naturalistic behaviors in unconstrained experiments. To achieve this goal, this program will develop novel multiscale neural network models of neural population activity that not only capture nonlinearity, but also enable the new capabilities for flexible inference and closed-loop control. These models and methods will greatly impact diverse domains of neuroscience by causally driving and testing new hypotheses, informing closed-loop experimental paradigms and data-collection, and enhancing neurotechnology for treating brain disorders.

PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator: Schryvers, Anthony B. PROJECT NARRATIVE Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacterial pathogen that causes gonorrhea, is considered a serious public health threat due to the emergence of “superbug” strains that are resistant to the last line of recommended antibiotics. The inability to effectively treat with antibiotics puts patients in danger of developing severe complications including infertility. With a global incidence rate of over 106 million new cases every year, including over 800,000 in the US, developing an anti-gonococcal vaccine has become an urgent priority. The objective of this program is to evaluate large-scale production and perform non-clinical toxicology studies of a highly promising vaccine candidate that targets the systems required for iron acquisition during infection by gonococci.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Patient sexual harassment of staff is common in Veterans Affairs (VA) healthcare facilities. Patient harassment of staff reduces quality of care; negatively impacts staff wellbeing, burnout, and turnover; and contributes to an environment that tolerates other forms of harassment (e.g., toward women patients) and discrimination (e.g., based on race/ethnicity). Recent VA anti-harassment campaigns focus on harassment prevention, but additional work is needed to help staff respond to and cope with experiences of harassment when they occur. This pilot project will engage VA staff, leaders, and other stakeholders in the co-design of an intervention to guide immediate staff, clinic, and facility responses to patient harassment of staff in primary care settings, which serve as the entry point into VA care. The resulting intervention has the potential to increase staff well- being and quality of patient care, bolster ongoing anti-harassment efforts, and create a safe, respectful environment of care in which harassment is not tolerated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With little understanding as to its pathogenesis, colorectal cancer recurrence occurs in up to 40% of patients undergoing surgery, and when it does, it is almost universally fatal. This proposal is focused on studying a novel hypothesis in cancer recurrence and defining the role of intestinal microbes to influence cancer cells towards an invasive phenotype promoting tumor formation. These studies will provide transformative insights into the dynamic interaction between host-microbe-cancer that can be leveraged to provide novel interventions and therapeutics to prevent primary cancer and its recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will examine the effect of prenatal and early life metals exposure on the developing brain, cognitive and adaptive function, and risk for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and related traits. We will integrate novel tooth-based biomarkers of metals exposure into the Autism Spectrum Disorder Enriched Risk (ASD-ER) cohort, a unique collaborative of 13 prospective high familial risk for ASD populations. Because exposure to metals is common and our study is conducted in very young children there is great potential for intervention and broad public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The Successful Clinical Response In Pneumonia Therapy (SCRIPT2) Systems Biology Center will continue to delineate the complex host/pathogen interactions occurring at the alveolar level that lead to unsuccessful response to therapy in serious pneumonia. In SCRIPT2, we will determine whether models generated using high-dimension data describing the host, pathogen, microbiome, and clinical phenome in severe community- acquire pneumonia and hospital-/ventilator-acquired pneumonia can predict favorable or unfavorable clinical transitions/outcomes over the course of a pneumonia episode. We will query these models to identify potential therapeutic host, pathogen, and microbiome targets and determine when, whether, and how standard or investigational therapies can be applied to increase the likelihood of a favorable outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Transcranial ultrasound could facilitate a broad range of applications in imaging and therapy, such as functional imaging, intracerebral hemorrhage detection, brain perfusion evaluation, cerebrovascular disease diagnosis, neurological disorder treatment, and neuromodulation. Despite its promising potentials, transcranial ultrasound imaging remains difficult and limited largely because skulls cause severe phase aberration, leading to highly degraded ultrasound images. This project aims to address this major limiting factor by developing new machine-learning-based methods to extract the skull profile and speed of sound directly from backscattered ultrasound signals and therefore enable accurate phase aberration correction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Protein arginine methyltransferases (PRMTs) influence gene expression and signaling pathways by catalyzing arginine methylation, including on histone and non-histone proteins. In malignant glioblastoma (GBM), cell mitosis is critical for tumor growth and survival therapy response. This application will investigate the mechanism and therapeutic targeting for protein arginine methylation regulation of GBM tumorigenicity by elucidating the role of protein arginine methyl transferase 6 (PRMT6) on regulating cell mitosis through directly arginine methylation of chromosome condensation 1 (RCC1), thereby regulating malignant GBM phenotype and GBM responses to therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the deleterious implications of neighborhood disadvantage for child development, a large proportion of exposed youth demonstrate adaptive functioning and competency in the face of this adversity. The current proposal focuses scientific attention on children’s strengths in the face of chronic stressors by examining developmental trajectories of three domains of resilience (academic, social, psychiatric) and identifying epigenetic biomarkers of resilience trajectories. By illuminating the developmental etiology of youth resilience, the proposed project has the potential to ultimately enhance policy and interventions for youth experiencing neighborhood adversity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The obesity epidemic has led to a dramatic increase in morbidity and mortality, with a greater than $190 billion burden annually on American healthcare. There is a need for therapeutic approaches that lessen or eliminate obesity-associated morbidity and mortality with a transformative impact on the American population and healthcare spending. This research effort aims to explore Osteocytic connexin 43 (Ocy Cx43) as a therapeutic target for obesity, by systematically exploring how changes in Ocy Cx43 hemichannel activity leads to local and global changes in adipose tissue formation, ultimately improving whole-body energy expenditure and enhancing systemic metabolic function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Successfully increasing cessation rates among African Americans will reduce the racial disparity in mortality among African Americans and Whites by up to 20%. This K01 research proposal outlines, in detail, a plan to develop an evidence-based smartphone intervention for smoking cessation with adjunctive sedentary behavior reduction, which will be culturally tailored for African Americans. Although there are numerous in-person interventions for smoking cessation that have been tailored for African Americans and minorities, smartphone-based interventions are still lacking; thus, this proposal represents an innovative and modern approach for eliminating tobacco-related health disparities in this underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Our previous experiences can influence our future choices in many ways, for example by biasing choices towards actions that have been successful in the past (“retrospective decision-making”), or by choosing actions that you think will be successful based on careful mental planning (“inferential decision-making”). Biologically, retrospective decision-making is thought to be mediated by dopamine, though recent work has also suggested a role for dopamine in inferential decision-making. This proposal seeks to describe novel neural circuits that underlie inferential decision-making, the results of which will have applications in neuroscience, psychology, and machine learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The pathological consequences of myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) are understudied in the visceral smooth muscle of the gastrointestinal tract despite a high prevalence of gastrointestinal disturbances in affected individuals. This proposal focuses on the impact of muscleblind-like (MBNL) loss of activity, a primary mechanism of DM1 pathology, on gastrointestinal motility. The studies proposed in this fellowship will elucidate both physiological and molecular impacts of MBNL loss on smooth muscle, providing novel insight on the myogenic mechanisms of DM1 gastrointestinal pathology and potential avenues for therapeutic study.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer is too often fatal and there is a strong need to prevent this disease before it becomes recalcitrant to conventional cancer therapy. An important field-driving and novel goal of this application is to develop dietary combinations of green tea polyphenols and sulforaphane-rich broccoli sprouts that can be safely consumed to reduce estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer risk and severity in offspring generations even when consumed by either of their parents before conception of the offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to maintain relevant information necessary to make decisions and continuously update our autobiographies as we amass experience from childhood into adulthood depends on the medial temporal lobe and prefrontal cortex. By measuring electrical activity directly from the human brain, the proposed research will determine the mechanisms by which these regions interact to form and maintain memories in real time, and identify sources of developmental variability in these mechanisms from childhood into adulthood. The outcomes will increase understanding of how the brain implements normal memory and how brain circuits may go awry in disordered behavior, laying the foundation for translational work aimed at improving memory in populations suffering from disease or injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to neurovascular coupling, neural activity creates a reliable increase in blood flow and hence local temperature, which can be measured in the operating room with an infrared thermographic camera. While an awake patient performs tasks, this new method of monitoring the patterns of temperature fluctuation can be used to create a map of brain function, that once validated the surgical team can use to avoid damage to key functional areas. This can lead to safer, faster, and more effective surgeries for patients with drug-resistant epilepsy, glioma, or neurovascular malformations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Precision medicines that specifically target proteins that drive cancer growth are leading to improved responses in many advanced-stage cancer patients. However, this clinical success is limited because treatment resistance occurs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reliable non-invasive differentiation of aggressive vs. indolent prostate cancer is imperative for the early detection of aggressive cancers (currently missed in ~50,000 American men/year) while minimizing side effects from unneeded biopsies (currently affecting ~500,000 American men/year). We propose to develop pathomic MRI biomarkers and include them in rad-pathomic deep learning models to learn the appearance of aggressive and indolent cancers on MRI from patients with matched MR and pathology images. We will validate our deep learning models when assisting radiologists in detecting aggressive cancers on prostate MRI.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social interactions are critical to the normal development of the brain. A critical period is a developmental epoch during which the nervous system is expressly sensitive to specific stimuli that are required for experience dependent learning, circuit organization, and synaptic plasticity. Critical periods have been described for both sensory (e.g. vision, touch) and social (e.g. language, imprinting) functions. While mechanistic insights into the establishment and reinstatement of sensory critical periods have transformed therapeutic practice (e.g. for treating deafness and blindness), to date, the molecular, synaptic, and circuit mechanisms underlying social critical periods are largely unknown. Our proposed studies will have significant implications for understanding the pathogenesis of neurodevelopmental disorders characterized by social impairments, such as autism and schizophrenia, as well as diseases like addiction and PTSD that respond to social influence or are aggravated by social injury. At the same time, these insights will provide the basis for new therapeutic strategies, improved mechanistic understanding of therapeutic interventions currently in clinical trials, and objective measures of social reward learning across maturation that are tractable for future translational studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Enhancers are regulatory DNA sequences within our genomes that control when and where genes are activated. In the myriad cell types in the human brain, enhancers direct transcriptional programs required for the genesis of neurons and glia and for constructing synapses and circuits. As such, enhancers are critically important to human brain evolution, development, and health, yet their function remains poorly understood. This project is focused on the development and implementation of novel approaches for decoding the function of enhancers and elucidating their role in the healthy and diseased brain.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The VA mandated expanded community care services for Veterans with the MISSION Act of 2018 and has increasingly partnered with community-based facilities to provide acute care for Veterans Living with Dementia (VLWD). Research shows that transitions across care systems are vulnerable times, resulting in fragmentation and worse health outcomes. Unfortunately, these Veterans are especially at an increased risk of adverse outcomes, resulting in continued deterioration. Our work will evaluate transitions of care from community hospitals to VA care using a mixed-methods approach. We will identify important risk factors that lead to adverse outcomes in transitions for dual-use VLWD, and then adapt and pilot an intervention to improve transitions of care that may be used for all VLWD being discharged from the community hospitals or ED. This work is a high priority area of VA’s MISSION Act implementation and is supported by the VA Offices of Geriatrics and Extended Care, Community Care, and Emergency Medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement (Project Narrative) Chronic pain is a major health care issue, but mechanisms of the transition from acute to chronic pain still remain to be determined, particularly at the level of the brain. The proposed multidisciplinary research project addresses this important knowledge gap by identifying neuro-immune signaling in the amygdala, a brain center for emotions and pain modulation, as an important pain mechanism. Successful completion of the proposed studies will advance our knowledge about neuro-immune brain mechanisms of pain that can be targeted for pain management, which is highly significant from a basic science and clinical perspective hence translational.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance New technology that allows the classification of thousands of gut microbial features has made it possible to identify the many physiological and metabolic processes through which microbiota may influence the health of their hosts. Evidence from animal experiments and feeding studies has suggested that microbiota may modulate the risk of diabetes, although few prospective studies have been conducted to establish the relationship between gut microbiome and diabetes incidence. This study aims to examine microbiota composition, functional potential, and fecal metabolome in relation to the risk of developing diabetes in two well-established cohorts of U.S. men and women with complementary ethnic and socioeconomic backgrounds. Study findings will help identify novel microbial features as targets for developing individualized prevention and intervention strategies to alleviate the increasing societal and healthcare burden of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the project is to develop and clinically validate an ultrasensitive, selective, rapid, and simple HIV-1 viral load test that can be performed in point-of-care settings. Our integrated approach first separates viral particles from whole blood with a microfluidic filter, followed by capture and counting intact virions. Specific recognition of HIV is achieved through designer DNA “net” nanostructures that match the spatial pattern of envelope glycoprotein gp120 on the virus outer surface, where the DNA net is immobilized upon a photonic crystal biosensor surface, enabling a new form of microscopy that enhances viral light scattering intensity to count the captured HIV with digital precision. In contrast to nucleic acid tests that require sample pre-processing and enzymatic amplification, our direct approach is performed in a single step with no added reagents, yielding a result in less than 30 minutes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative As the prevalence of autism rises to unprecedented levels, the need to identify children who are at the greatest risk for developing this disorder is paramount to providing early intervention services in a timely way. In the current application we propose to collect high-dimensional EEG data in a large pediatric primary care clinic that disproportionately serves under-represented groups (95% Hispanic or African American), with the goal of being able to identify children in the first year of life who will subsequently develop autism by age 24 months.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Carcinoma invasion and metastasis is not only regulated in a cancer cell-autonomous fashion, but also through complex interactions with surrounding stroma cells as well as the surrounding interstitial matrix itself. Herein, we outline a series of novel in vivo and ex vivo models that support a pre-eminent role for the membrane- anchored matrix metalloproteinase, MT1-MMP, in regulating tumor cell progression by unexpectedly controlling a series of mechanotransduction-linked programs that directly impact the transcriptional programs underlying invasion and metastasis. These studies should not only shed new mechanistic insights on the key proteolytic events that regulate MT1-MMP-dependent control of cancer cell invasive and metastatic activities, but also help facilitate the identification of novel targets relevant to therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While sharing genomic data holds great promise for advancing biomedical research and personalized medicine, the uniqueness of the genomic data and the rich information they carry can put participants’ privacy at risk. In this project, we will develop practical solutions for genomic data sharing that provide data contributors with strong privacy assurance while enabling the release of high quality data. The outcome of the proposed research will encourage data contributors to participate in studies, widen the access to genomic data, and, in the long-term, facilitate genomic data-driven medical research to promote health and ease the burden of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The mechanisms of replicative lifespan of hematopoietic stem cells (HSC) are poorly understood. The functional decline of HSC through division is thought to be a degenerative process caused by accumulated damage that leads to cellular dysfunction, tissue failure, and death. Evidence accumulating over the past decade has now proven that there is a measurable and successive division-dependent functional decline in hematopoietic. The studies proposed in this application will provide information on cellular factors that become deregulated in hematopoietic stem cells with cumulative division and cause functional decline of the hematopoietic tissue, and will identify conditions under which HSC can be maintain with full potential through divisions. This could be a first step towards designing treatments to attenuate/revert HSC functional decline and consequently to improve tissue homeostasis and tissue regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Primary cilia are microtubule-based projections on virtually every cell type and are linked to multiple signaling pathways. Among the best studied is Sonic hedgehog (Shh), which requires the cilium for signal transduction. Here we use a series of mouse models to genetically uncouple ciliogenesis and vertebrate Hh signaling, and in the process paint a clearer mechanistic picture of each. These proposed experiments have great potential to give us the fundamental knowledge we need to develop strategies to treat diseases related to abnormal cilia or Shh signaling.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) remains a common and frequently fatal cause of acute respiratory failure in critically ill patients, with no specific preventative strategies or therapies available. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Therapies that lower apolipoprotein C3 (APOC3) levels are currently under investigation for triglyceride- lowering in humans with severely elevated triglyceride levels. If successful, our proposed studies would set the stage for a cardiovascular outcome clinical trial on APOC3 lowering as a novel strategy for preventing the increased cardiovascular disease risk in patients with T1DM and high APOC3 levels in APOB100 lipoproteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this research is to improve post-treatment recovery outcomes in head and neck cancer survivors and caregivers through the delivery of the dyadic survivorship needs assessment planning (SNAP) tool implemented into clinic workflow at the end of treatment. SNAP is a survivorship care planning care transition tool with the central purpose to automate and simplify care practices to improve receipt of recommended care in dyads. In this research, we will conduct a randomized controlled trial to test the effects of the SNAP system on caregiver burden, survivor symptom severity and healthcare utilization in dyads and concurrently identify key barriers and facilitators to disseminating the SNAP system to diverse cancer care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ischemic stroke is a public health crisis given its high incidence and associated morbidity and mortality. The proposed work seeks to resolve the diagnosis of cryptogenic stroke or stroke of undetermined source by using advanced computational techniques and novel data sources. Pinpointing the underlying cause of stroke may optimize clinical care, identify therapeutic targets for clinical trial research, and improve neurologic outcomes on a large scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The emergence of electronic health records exposes clinicians to massive amounts of information about the millions of patients who suffer from communication and swallowing disorders, yet most clinical scientists do not have the training or skill to apply meaning to the data toward improving patient care. The overarching mentorship goal of this proposal is to train early, patient-oriented communication and swallowing scientists in big data analyses, including computer machine learning approaches. The research project will uncover distinct patterns and severity of swallowing impairments in large groups of patients with high risk medical diagnoses, which will have high impact on patient care planning and identification of treatments that directly target these impairments for improved outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The lung is home to a wide variety of tissue resident cells including an increasingly complex cadre of immune cells that have important roles in the response to environmental insults and infections. Dysfunction of immune cells forms to the basis of many common lung diseases. This project will explore early responses of immune cells in lung injury and also newly discovered populations of hematopoietic cells in the lung to facilitate the discovery of new approaches to treat lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The COVID-19 pandemic due to SARS-CoV-2 infection poses new challenges to the nearly 3 million persons with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) worldwide. The proposed study aims to address salient knowledge gaps in the clinical management of PwMS during the pandemic and its aftermath. First, we will examine the association between MS immune-modulating disease- modifying therapies and COVID-19 risk and severity. Second, we will examine the COVID-19 vaccine efficacy and safety in MS and association with MS outcomes. Third, we will examine the effect of the pandemic on personal social network and health outcomes in PwMS. To pursue these research questions, we will leverage existing collaborations across multiple academic MS centers and a large data warehouse of integrated claims and electronic health records data. Given the protracted COVID-19 pandemic, real-world evidence emerging from the proposed study will critically inform the clinical management of PwMS during the rapidly changing landscape of neurological care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Balance while walking is essential for mobility, yet individuals with vestibular loss experience instability in gait and increased fall risk. Through computational and experimental approaches, this project aims to understand how the body enacts different strategies to retain stability while walking, and how the execution of these strategies is affected by vestibular loss. The results from this research will identify strategies to be emphasized in rehabilitation for individuals with vestibular disorders to enhance stability while walking and decrease fall risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Phosphatidylserine is a lipid whose exposure to blood promotes clotting. This proposal uses animal models and state-of-the-art microscopy techniques to study how endothelial cells on the blood vessel wall contribute phosphatidylserine to generate thrombosis. By studying the regulation of phosphatidylserine exposure on endothelial cells, we will gain a better understanding of how blood clots form in vessels, which may allow for the development of novel therapeutics to treat thrombotic disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pain is a significant problem affecting millions of people per year with limited therapeutic options. To address this issue, we have proposed to identify mechanisms underlying redistribution of voltage gated Na+ channels in peripheral axons following trigeminal nerve injury. The results of these studies may suggest novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of neuropathic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Initiation of nuclear DNA replication is tightly regulated such that the entire genome is duplicated exactly once in every cell division cycle. Deregulation of the mechanisms that control this process provokes genomic instability and fuels malignant transformation, but is also the underlying cytotoxic activity of a new anti-cancer therapeutic approach. In this proposal, we characterize the genomic abnormalities that arise when these mechanisms are derailed both in cancer and non-cancer cells and investigate the molecular activities that participate in the generation of these abnormalities. A full understanding of this process will guide the development of better strategies to treat cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  There is increasing interest in using immunotherapy or targeted therapy to treat brain metastases, including leptomeningeal disease from cancer. However, it can be challenging to interpret response to treatment or to understand patterns of response or resistance to treatment since serial tissue samples are difficult to obtain from brain metastases. The goal of this proposal is to use circulating tumor DNA and sophisticated MRI scans to characterize the biological response of brain metastases to immunotherapy and targeted therapy by monitoring circulating tumor DNA burden and clonal evolution during treatment and comparing these to changes on MRI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance This research is relevant to public health because it aims to improve quality of life in the many US patients with cancer who live in medically underserved areas with a non-pharmacological approach to pain management. This innovative work will demonstrate the efficacy of a behavioral cancer pain intervention delivered by mHealth technology (i.e., video- conferencing with a remote therapist in the patients community based oncology clinic and home-extension with a basic smartphone) to decrease pain and disability; demonstration of efficacy has a high potential to lead to rapid wide-spread use, particularly benefiting individuals who face significant barriers (e.g., access, distance, financial, time, low literacy) to traditional behavioral interventions. The project is relevant to NIH’s mission because it aims to use a non-pharmacological approach reduce pain that incurs burden and disability and increase quality of life in patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This research program focuses on the systems developmental biology, biophysics and biomechanics of early spinal column development. The research program utilizes zebrafish as model for understanding the mechanisms of human development and causes of birth defects such as scoliosis and spina bifida. Overall, this is multi-scale research program that considers the roles of molecules, cells and tissues in the genesis of order in the developing embryo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alport Syndrome (AS) is an inherited disease that affects the kidney, the ear, and the eye; patients with AS often require dialysis early in life. We show that deficiency of a protein named perilipin 5 (PLIN5) affects the respiratory function of podocytes, a key cellular constituent of the kidney filtration barrier. Findings from this proposal may allow for the identification of a new function of a drug called Ezetimibe which was developed for the cure of high cholesterol and may be helpful in preventing kidney disease in AS by regulating PLIN5 expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: “Integrin adhesion complexes” (IACs) are assemblies of many different proteins, and are crucial for proper attachment of cells to their surroundings. Using the “model worm”, C. elegans, we discovered a molecule that is required for the formation of IACs in muscle, and that deficiency of the comparable molecule in mice and in fruit flies results in a heart muscle defect called “cardiomyopathy”, an often- inherited disease of humans. Using the unique advantages of worms, mice and flies, we will learn how this molecule functions and how the absence of this molecule leads to cardiomyopathy.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Researchers in the social sciences lack formal training in advanced analytics that may slow progress in understanding complex relationships between social determinants of health and population health outcomes. Multi-disciplinary, team-based science can align research methods in advanced analytics with social science perspectives to produce a new generation of researchers addressing racial and ethnic disparities in healthcare to improve health equity. As the only NIMHD T32 research training program in the state, the proposed program will serve as model to improve disparate population health outcomes in the state, region, and nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Dravet syndrome (DS) is severe form epilepsy with a high mortality rate that is caused mainly mutations in the Scn1a gene which preferentially regulates activity of inhibitory neurons. Despite evidence showing that respiratory failure is a leading cause of death in epilepsy and DS patients' frequently exhibit disordered breathing,mechanisms underlying respiratory dysfunction in DS are unknown. The main goal of this project is to investigate the untested possibility that loss of Scn1a function in brainstem inhibitory neurons directly affect brainstem respiratory centers and serve as a common substrate for both seizure and respiratory dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A possible explanation for failure of standard chemotherapies in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is cellular phenotypic heterogeneity within tumors, which may enable subpopulations of cells to survive therapy and repopulate the tumor. Elimination or re-differentiation of cancer stem-like cells (CSCs) is an attractive strat- egy-- by homogenizing cancer cell phenotypes within tumors, such therapies may suppress tumor progression and lead to improved response to conventional therapies. We hypothesize that disrupting CSC and niche cells can translate into novel therapeutic strategies for PDAC patients, and therefore we propose to identify mecha- nisms that drive the Wnt target gene Lgr5 (expressed by CSCs) and Porcupine+ niche cell states and to ex- plore the therapeutic potential of Wnt inhibitors in PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE Breathing after birth requires coordinated development of the airways and surrounding tissues within the lung. Defects in the mechanical environment of the fetal chest cavity, such as congenital diaphragmatic hernia, disrupt the pressure across the developing lung and lead to abnormal development of the airways. Here we combine an innovative model system to mimic the mechanical environment around developing lungs with transgenic mice to measure the mechanical forces and identify the molecular signals that are activated by pressure, which will suggest new therapeutic targets for the treatment of underdeveloped lungs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Peripheral nervous system (PNS) disorders affect a large population world-wide; however, few researchers invest efforts into understanding the causes of PNS disorders, leading to very few treatments available to patients. Familial Dysautonomia (FD) is a rare, genetic and particularly devastating disorder of the PNS, where patients’ symptom severity differs dramatically from mild to severe despite the fact that they all harbor an identical mutation. This project investigates the molecular mechanistic basis of disease severity in FD, using human induced pluripotent stem cells, with the promise of attaining knowledge that will have fundamental implications for FD patients, possibly for other peripheral neuropathies, and will improve our general knowledge about the molecular underpinnings of dysfunction in the PNS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many researchers use DNA sequencing to study disease and biology, and analyzing this data requires sophisticated software capable of piecing together puzzles made of billions of fragments of DNA. Mean- while, public archives are ﬁlling with huge datasets that could be used in everyday research, but they are not organized in a convenient way. We propose a set of projects that allow everyday scientists to easily (a) analyze sequencing data, (b) examine archived sequencing datasets to ﬁnd those most relevant to their research, and (c) provide a “search engine” for answering scientiﬁc questions with respect to the archive.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE When exposed to stress, cells move the bulk of their RNA into clumps of RNA and protein called ribonucleoprotein (RNP) granules, seemingly so that they can focus on the specific RNAs that will help them respond to the stress. Different types of RNP granules interact and transfer RNA between themselves during stress, but it is unknown whether these interactions and the transfer of RNA serves an actual role in the cellular stress response. I will improve a tool that allows me to see single molecules of RNA in live cells under a microscope, use that tool to figure out which stress conditions cause RNP granule interactions and the transfer of RNA, and use that tool to test a hypothesis about how RNA is actually transferred between two RNP granules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narratives The overall goal of this project is to utilize hypothesis driven experimentation to elucidate key mechanistic processes governing the phytoextraction of arsenic from soil, transport, detoxification and sequestration into above ground biomass. Detailed investigations will focus on biogeochemical processes in the soil that impact contaminant availability to plant roots and also on critical biological limitations and physiological processes that can enable sustained and significant contaminant phytoextraction and hyperaccumulation. This “bottom-up” focus on mechanisms at and within the abiotic-biotic interface will enable the optimization of plant-based remedial strategies for arsenic and facilitate the development of future analogous platforms for additional contaminants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While the US adult population is approximately 61.3% non-Hispanic white, 17.8% Hispanic or Latino, 13.3% African American, 5.7% Asian, and 1.5% American Indian, Alaskan Native, or Pacific Islander, the picture in academia is much different, with over 85% of full-time faculty identifying as non-Hispanic white or Asian. This loss of diversity is limiting our potential as a nation to build knowledge and improve human health. Our Mid- Atlantic Neuroscience Diversity Scholars (MiNDS) program is a five-year plan to bolster the number of underrepresented minority (URM) students within the neuroscience academic pipeline and build a foundation for URM students to succeed in graduate school and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: In the United States, over 80% of prostate cancer patients die with bone metastases. Second line hormonal therapies such as enzalutamide only improve overall patient survival by a few months in about 50% of the patients, and almost all patients develop drug resistance. Thus, there is an urgent need to determine the mechanisms of drug resistance and to develop new approaches for overcoming such resistance and for better treatment of prostate cancer bone metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is a life-threatening emergency that requires rapid diagnosis of infections and treatment with antibiotics. In trauma patients, diagnosis of sepsis is particularly challenging because initial injury itself can cause physiological derangements that mimic those attributed to infections. In this project, we propose to develop biomarkers to improve diagnostics, clinical management, and outcomes for sepsis in trauma patients using sequencing analysis of circulating microbial DNA in plasma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research has direct public health implications through clarifying how delirium is associated with the accumulation of neurodegeneration pathologies and understanding how these pathologies contribute to the development of cognitive decline. As such, this application is immediately relevant to the NIH's mission of fostering innovative research strategies for improving health through identification of the causes, preventive approaches, management of, and novel therapies for, delirium and Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). This application will result in novel insights into which Amyloid-Tau-Neurodegeneration pathologies predispose to acute brain dysfunction and delirium, accumulate following delirium, and contribute to the development of ADRD after critical illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As one of the largest cellular organelles, the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) choreographs the production of virtually all membrane and secretory proteins, along with lipid synthesis and calcium regulation. Critically, the ER cannot be built from scratch in newly divided cells but must be carefully inherited at each cell division; indeed, we found a cell cycle checkpoint termed the ER surveillance (ERSU) pathway that ensures functionally competent ER is inherited at sufficient levels. Dissecting the molecular mechanisms of the ERSU pathway holds great promise to ultimately unveiling the pathogenesis of human diseases caused by uncontrolled cell division, such as cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anthracyclines and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-targeted agents have improved overall breast cancer control and survival; however, the benefits of these cancer therapies are offset by cardiovascular toxicity. Aerobic exercise training (AT) is an effective multimodal strategy that favorably impacts cardiovascular outcomes. Leveraging the infrastructure of a rigorously conducted AT intervention trial in patients with breast cancer, our ancillary biomarker study will evaluate the impact of AT to prevent the cardiovascular toxicity of breast cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In Uganda, fears of relationship dissolution and loss of the ability to have children remain major barriers to HIV in heterosexual couples. Our communication strategy aims to promote HIV testing with reassuring messages about the ability to have stable relationships and healthy families with the increased availability of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP). We will evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of this communication strategy among clients and partners within assisted partner notification and antenatal care programs in two hospitals and evaluate preliminary effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Ribosome quality control (RQC) monitors the fidelity of protein synthesis in real-time to ensure that genetic information is correctly decoded and defects in this process cause devastating human diseases. While basic mechanisms of RQC have been recently defined for cytosolic proteins, almost nothing is known about RQC for ribosomes at the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) that make the nearly one third of human proteins destined for the secretory pathway. The proposed research leverages innovative technologies to elucidate the RQC mechanism for proteins in the secretory pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative  This project will uncover how signaling by cytokine and growth factor receptors at the cardiomyocyte plasma membrane is transduced within the cell to promote cardiac hypertrophy and heart failure. Although a number of signaling pathways have established roles in cardiac disease pathogenesis, the mechanisms controlling hypertrophic signal transduction circuitry in the adult cardiac myocyte are ill-defined. We will interrogate the functions of protein S-acylation or palmitoylation, a reversible lipid modification, in spatiotemporal regulation of signaling events downstream of cytokine stimulation in cardiomyocytes that may potentially be leveraged for the development of more targeted strategies to treat cardiac disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Vascular cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) is a devastating disorder with no effective treatments available to alleviate VCID-related white matter injury and cognitive dysfunction. Vascular insufficiency due to metabolic dysregulation is a potential modifiable factor in VCID pathogenesis. The proposed study will explore adiponectin, a cytokine produced by adipocytes, as a promising therapeutic target for white matter protection and cognitive improvement. We will investigate whether and how activation of adiponectin receptor in VCID brain promotes cerebrovascular autoregulation and strengthens the blood-brain barrier, thereby improving white matter integrity and long-term cognitive outcomes. This information will be valuable for future development of new therapy for VCID and, possibly, other cerebrovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The integrative stress response is an evolutionary conserved pathway to allows cells to react to various stress stimuli to restore cellular homeostasis. We found that the activation of this process in neurons leads to the secretion of a protein fragment that enhances the resilience of surrounding cells to cell stress. We propose to study how this signaling molecule is generated and secreted from neurons in response to stress, how it affects recipient neurons, and how its activity is coordinated with transcriptional programs to facilitate cell survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  Many approaches exist to predict RNA structures so that function can be better understood, but generally they tend to be biased towards any sequence having a structure of some sort. We will create a web-based platform that will reliably assess the existence of a conserved RNA structure and propose such a structure with high accuracy, using evolutionary as well as RNA structure information. Integrating existing but not widely adopted computational methods into a webserver that will take a single RNA sequence as input will enable its extensive use throughout the community so that RNA research can continue thriving in new directions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kentucky ranks highest in rates of overall cancer incidence and mortality [1]. To address this major health issue, the University of Kentucky Center of Biomedical Research Excellence on Cancer and Metabolism will sustain a robust infrastructure to continue to conduct basic and translational research to better define the metabolic dysregulations governing tumor development, metastasis, drug resistance and recurrence. This will be achieved through the cultivation and expansion of a cadre of promising project leaders by providing research support, mentoring and access to state-of-the-art metabolic and imaging core facilities.
