IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Azoles are common antifungal agents widely-used in clinical applications and agriculture. In vertebrates, exposures to azoles during early embryonic development results in developmental toxicity outcomes, including, craniofacial and axial defects. In this study, we aim to delineate mechanisms underlying azole-induced developmental toxicity utilizing single cell transcriptomic-based approaches, gene-editing tools, and established alternative model systems of early embryonic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and its associated conditions (e.g., traumatic brain injury and suicidality) are often underdiagnosed, and have outcomes that are difficult to predict. Treatment of PTSD often involves frequent treatment changes with multi-drug regimens (polypharmacy) and off-label medications for which the relative risks and benefits are largely unknown. To address these problems, we will develop and apply methods to identify undiagnosed patients, predict disease trajectories, and compare the effectiveness of all common PTSD treatments using health records from millions of patients in Veterans Administration (VA) and non-VA databases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This translational research applies cutting-edge bioengineering techniques to better understand and characterize the mechanisms of ventricular arrhythmias, which remain the most common cause of sudden death in patients with heart failure. Novel analysis of the interplay between structural and electrical abnormalities of the heart will provide actionable classifications of ventricular arrhythmia substrate for therapy and future study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Cancers of children and young adults result from the interplay between genetic and epigenetic factors and the cellular states that accompany a period of developmental progression and accelerated growth. We propose a project that explore this relationship through the bone and soft tissue cancer Ewing sarcoma. How the critical oncoprotein that leads to Ewing sarcoma influences and is itself influenced by an evolving chromatin environment will be studied.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal aims to apply innovative multimodal MRI approaches to evaluate the therapeutic effects of the combined therapy of hydrogen water and minocycline treatment on ischemic stroke in the established middle cerebral artery occlusion model in rats. These integrated approaches are expected to provide a comprehensive anatomical, physiological and functional profile of ischemic tissue at risk and their spatiotemporal characteristics and how the treatment reduces ischemic injury. These findings have the potential to lead to novel effective treatment of ischemic stroke during the acute and chronic phase, and enhance clinical decision making in the treatment of acute stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Air pollution exacerbates inflammation and is a significant contributor to the development of chronic inflammatory diseases. Emerging scientific evidence suggests that air pollution mitigates pathways involved in the resolution of inflammation leading to chronic inflammatory diseases including atherosclerosis and IBD. Successful completion of work proposed in this application, i) will identify novel molecular mechanisms that regulate resolution of inflammation and ii) will provide novel therapeutic strategies for, the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases including atherosclerosis and IBD, exacerbated by environmental exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Taxane-induced peripheral neuropathy (TIPN) is an irreversible, life-altering side effect of taxane chemotherapy that cannot be prevented or treated, and therefore requires premature discontinuation of taxane treatment in many patients. The proposed research is highly relevant to the NCI mission because it will validate clinically-useful and mechanistically informative predictive TIPN biomarkers and develop an Integrated TIPN Prediction Model. This work will enable the study team to develop biomarker-informed interventions that positively impact patients’ quantity and quality of life by preventing TIPN and enhancing taxane treatment effectiveness.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The research proposed in this application seeks to understand the neurodevelopmental mechanisms through which stable housing can reduce some of the negative effects of poverty on children. Childhood poverty is associated with lower academic achievement, under employment, and poorer health across the life course. This project examines the effect of stable housing on processes likely to improve these outcomes, including decision-making and impulse control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We aim to define the molecular basis of HER3 signaling promotion of triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) progression and metastasis via upregulation of PHF8, a key histone lysine demethylase. The proposed studies will shed a new light on our understanding of epigenetic promotion of HER3-driven TNBC. Data generated will provide compelling evidence to develop novel therapeutic agents/strategies inhibiting HER3 or PHF8 either alone or in combination with chemotherapy for the patients with TNBC, especially those with the subtypes of Basal-like 1 (BL1), Luminal-Androgen receptor (LAR), or Basal-like 2 (BL2).

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Narrative-Relevance  This R01 application tackles one of the unmet challenging problems in the breast cancer field: prevention of estrogen receptor-negative (ER-) breast cancer. The major goal of this research is to determine whether and how vitamin E administration via both local and systemic deliveries would enforce dendritic cell antigen presentation, increase tumor antigen-specific T-cell response, boost effector memory T-cells, and potentiate cancer vaccine-induced immunoprevention against ER- mammary tumor and human breast cancer. If preclinical studies are successful, our new strategies could be fast-track translated into breast cancer immunoprevention clinical trials for women at high risk for ER- breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women exposed to hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI)) suffer from pre-term labor, pre-mature abortion, and intrauterine fetal growth restriction (IUGR). In humans, exposure to endocrine-disrupting chemicals leads to inadequate uterine spiral artery remodeling in early pregnancy resulting in pregnancy-related disorders. The outcome of the proposed NIH-R21 project will lead to a better understanding of the molecular mechanism of Cr(VI) in causing maladaptation of placental /uterine vasculature, which leads to IUGR and pre-term labor, that in turn might help regulate Cr(VI) exposure in a vulnerable population, such as pregnant women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The cytoplasmic sulfotransferase (SULT) conjugating enzymes are expressed from the earliest stages of human development and throughout the life-course. The SULTs metabolize both endogenous and foreign chemicals, sometimes to less toxic or inactive compounds and sometimes to reactive and carcinogenic compounds, and so are important determinants of the effects of the environment on the human during critical early windows of susceptibility that can program an individual’s likelihood of developing disease later in life. SULT expression varies markedly among individuals and changes over time, but the mechanisms that control these dynamic changes in metabolic capability are not understood. This project will undertake the challenge of developing a comprehensive and detailed understanding of the mechanisms that control SULT expression and function during human development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Young adult women biologically-related to people carrying breast cancer-causing genes may be at high risk for developing breast cancer themselves. These relatives should take precautions to learn about their risk and possibly act on it. Our study aims to understand how trained peer coaches can help young adult women navigate this process--potentially changing how they learn to control hereditary breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths among men and women in the United States. Using laboratory-based science, this project aims to elucidate novel functions and the regulation of an enzyme, MOF/KAT8, in lung cancer. This research has the potential to save lives and improve lung health by advancinge strategies for lung cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Fundamental behaviors, including reward-based learning, attention, and movement invigoration, rely on a complex recurrent network of striatal, midbrain, thalamic, and cortical brain circuit loops. Here, we propose to functionally dissect the anatomical organization of this system, using new methods to simultaneously manipulate and measure neural activity in multiple circuits at once during behavior. Our goal is to better understand information flow at the network level, for insight into basic neurobiological mechanisms of normal and pathological states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Maintaining normal calcium and phosphate homeostasis is essential for a myriad of cellular and metabolic functions that promote healthy skeletal development and ensure optimal organ function. Disordered mineral homeostasis causes metabolic bone diseases and nephrolithiasis, and is a common and morbid complication of chronic kidney disease. By performing the first detailed analyses of the tissue-specific effects of the vitamin D degrading enzyme, CYP24A1, in health and in disease, we will generate new evidence to support the design of novel therapies to enhance treatment of metabolic bone diseases, nephrolithiasis and chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a disease that is more prevalent in the elderly, but it is not clear how cell types that contribute to aging can promote lung fibrosis. Our proposal will take advantage of a novel tool to identify and characterize senescent cells, a cell type that accumulates with aging, in lung fibrosis. Our study will define how senescent cells promote lung fibrosis, and screen for drugs that might better target these cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative  Retinal vein occlusion is a leading cause of vision loss for which present therapy is limited to incompletely treating the complications of the occluded vein, rather than by directly addressing the causative thrombus. Retinal vein cannulation with precise delivery of therapeutic agent is a very difficult freehand procedure that is well suited to robotic assistance—and potentially best suited for bilateral robotic support. To consistently enable human clearance of obstruction in a retinal vein, we propose to develop a novel bilateral robotic system that will enhance retinal vein cannulation efficiency, success and safety via coordinated bilateral robotic assistance with real-time, multipoint, multisensory feedback.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor intrinsic CREB activation exacerbates the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment and hinders the adaptive immune response in pancreatic cancer. Targeting CREB can remodel the tumor immune microenvironment, specifically through macrophage signaling, to enhance the efficacy of immunotherapy. This study will investigate the tumor intrinsic cellular mechanism of CREB-mediated immunosuppression using various preclinical mouse models and clinical samples to refine ongoing therapeutic approaches to this lethal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative G protein–coupled receptors, the targets of one-third of all FDA-approved drugs, undergo a set of concerted conformational changes that enable them to respond to external stimuli and stimulate intracellular signaling. This proposal proposes to develop a computational–experimental biophysical approach to determine the activation mechanisms for members of a GPCR subfamily, the metabotropic glutamate receptors, thereby enabling discovery of new ligands with safer therapeutic profiles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Humans have an incredible number of different T Cell Receptors (TCR) giving T cells their specificity; some of these, called "public TCRs," are shared in the population and may have important functions. We have discovered 3 special public TCRs whose presence in the peripheral blood of cancer patients correlates with progression free and overall survival. In this proposal, we will investigate the scope of predictive power for these special public TCRs and investigate their potential for therapeutic applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative All cells in tissues and organs experience some degree of physical forces, but how cells react to such forces is not well defined. Using innovative techniques to detect protein associations, we will determine how physical forces change protein interactions surrounding cyto-keratins, a family of fibrous proteins required for maintaining the physical integrity of cells and tissues. This proposal aims to understand the molecular basis of the keratin network’s force-induced responses and reveal novel keratin functions that may contribute to how cancer cells break free from their primary tissues and metastasize to tissues elsewhere and identify targets for novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will examine how large-scale increases in funding for and access to school counselors, through California’s 2006 Supplemental School Counseling Program, impacted youth mental health, health behaviors, and well-being. It will describe how schools used the funding to increase access to counselors and mental health services, and examine heterogeneity in policy implementation and impacts by gender, race, geography, and income, which is important given disparities in access to mental healthcare and the incidence of mental health disorders. This study will have a high impact because it can inform the current policy debate about whether and how to expand mental health counseling in schools, and it will provide evidence on how to effectively design related policies so that they impact the children most in need of these services and address the current national child and adolescent mental health emergency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gene expression requires the splicing of mRNA precursors by the spliceosome, a dynamic cellular ribonucleoprotein machine of staggering complexity harboring over 150 proteins in human cells and mutated in numerous cancers. We recently developed the first global genetic methods for investigating the function of the spliceosome in haploid human cells. In this project, we will leverage our new methods and reagents to explore functions of individual spliceosomal proteins to understand human-specific features of gene expression in a manner not possible previously.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric chronic pain is a common, complex and highly debilitating developmental health concern that has been associated with multiple risk factors for heavy and frequent marijuana use. However, the longitudinal interplay among chronic pain and two key risk factors, sleep disturbances and decreased inhibitory control, as it relates to adolescent marijuana use, remains minimally explored. This study aims to map the unfolding of pathophysiological processes using a combination of mobile health assessment tools, in order to implement personalized, early intervention in these vulnerable adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Current studies of Marfan Syndrome (MFS) etiology, identification of potential early diagnostic markers, and development of non-invasive therapies have been hindered by animal models which fall short in to completely replicate signaling mechanisms in humans or provide a limited observational window of disease progression. Here, we propose to develop and utilize a patient-derived vascular graft as a novel in vitro model to study MFS. We anticipate understanding the underlying mechanism of vascular fragility and identify diagnostic markers or footholds for early therapeutic intervention for MFS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Proper lineage development and function of intestinal epithelium is critical to human health. Preliminary evidence suggests that epithelial PPARsignaling and fatty acid oxidation may be under the modulation of intestinal microbiota. This project will determine the mechanism of actions of how key members of human gut microbiota spatially shape epithelial differentiation and function along the crypt-villus axis and provide novel metabolites that have potential to impact intestinal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As the burden of neurological disorders and neurodegenerative diseases in the United States and worldwide is high, there is a critical need to develop novel molecule imaging tools, such as PET ligands, to visualize and monitor pathophysiological processes in the brain. This work will develop key imaging ligands designed (1) to advance the scientific understanding of subtype-specific phosphodiesterase and its role in the pathophysiology and altered neuroimmune function of CNS diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias; and (2) to enable target engagement studies and facilitate drug discovery of novel neurotherapeutics for Alzheimer’s patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic liver disease is a major contributor to morbidity and mortality worldwide, in part because there are no therapies to delay progression or promote resolution of hepatic fibrosis, the end stage pathology of chronic liver disease. Activation of the blood clotting cascade is associated with chronic liver disease progression, but the specific mechanisms linking clotting factors to deposition of scar tissue (i.e., collagen) in the injured liver are poorly understood. The primary goal of this research proposal is to uncover precisely how blood clotting factors interact with collagen-producing cells in the injured liver so that new therapies can be designed to delay the progression of liver fibrosis in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Changes in the genome structure due to copying, deletion, rearrangement, or otherwise reorganization of sequences is a major source of genetic variation in all organisms, including humans. Although structural variants cause many heritable diseases and underlie phenotypic changes, 40-80% of this genetic variation remains hidden to the common genotyping strategies. Here, we propose to create a comprehensive catalog of polymorphic structural genetic variation using 50 de novo platinum genome assemblies of genetically diverse D. melanogaster strains and investigate their fitness consequences using population genetic theories and experimental fitness assays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE According to the American Brain Tumor Association, over 16,000 people are estimated to die from brain tumors this year while the currently available therapies cause motor and cognitive impairments and only extend life by 2 years. CAR T cell immunotherapy has the potential to improve outcomes in adult and pediatric brain tumor patients; however, optimized CAR design must be evaluated in models that closely mimic human disease and barriers for therapy. In this study, I propose using immune competent brain tumor models to enhance CAR T cell efficacy for brain tumors by optimizing CAR costimulatory domains, silencing negative T cell regulators, and targeting suppressive effectors of the brain tumor microenvironment including tumor associated macrophages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In South Africa, where 8 million persons are living with HIV, 56% are on ART, and only 45% are virally suppressed (the key indicator of treatment success) due to barriers to care including offering streamlined care only those persons demonstrating treatment success. To address this implementation gap, we propose to test the effect of adaptive differentiated service delivery by offering, in sequence, more tailored services to clients with detectable viral load and those not engaged in care. Working closely with the local HIV clinic, we will leverage ongoing changes in clinic practices to determine the impact of adapting the best clinic practices to include lottery incentives, community ART, and home ART delivery on viral suppression and cost-effectiveness at population level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to characterize the transcription cycle structurally and functionally in the actinobacteria phylum, focusing on the pathogen Mycobacterium tuberculosis. RNA polymerase, the central enzyme of transcription, is a proven target for antimicrobials, and regulators of the transcription cycle are often clade-specific but essential for viability and virulence. Understanding how these factors regulate Mycobacterium tuberculosis RNA polymerase informs us on unified and clade-specific mechanisms, providing a more comprehensive understanding of the transcription cycle that can lead to new therapeutics against specific bacterial pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to air pollution from traffic early in life may increase the risk of childhood obesity. We will examine whether maternal and child exposure to a traffic-related component of air pollution, black carbon, promotes higher adiposity, overweight, and obesity and changes to markers of cardiometabolic risk. If associations are identified, results will inform a comprehensive evaluation of the health risks associated with traffic-related air pollution exposure to pregnant women and children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The mechanisms of sex determination are an important and complex medical issue that involves multiple interacting cell types, several organs, and impacts susceptibility to disease, psychological development, and sense of person. We lack, however, full knowledge of how various genetic factors interact with the environment and its contaminants to direct sex determination. Because zebrafish is an important medical model with a sex- determination system that is sensitive to unidentified genetic variation and poorly understood environmental influences, we propose a research program to discover the developmental genetic basis for zebrafish sex determination.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The failure of proper termination of tissue regeneration results in the emergence of unwanted cells, leading to abnormal organ size and a high risk of cancer. However, the mechanisms by which stem cell proliferation is precisely controlled during the course of regeneration are poorly understood. The proposed study is designed to define the molecular mechanisms that function for stem cell inactivation and the extracellular matrix remodeling at the regeneration termination stage using the Drosophila midgut intestinal stem cell model.

PHR: Narrative The proposed studies will reveal how dendritic cells utilize environmental signals from allergens to alter energy metabolism towards glutaminolysis that results in T follicular helper13 (Tfh13) stimulation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of illness and death in U.S. women at all ages, and although it has been linked to earlier difficult pregnancies, we lack the strong evidence about the causes of CVD in women that is needed to guide effective clinical prevention strategies. To optimize CVD risk prediction and prevention strategies for women, we propose to continue follow-up of the nuMoM2b Heart Health Study cohort, a diverse group of 4,475 women enrolled starting 7 years ago during their first pregnancy. Continuing to follow these women—building on a foundation of high-quality data and biospecimens collected under a regulatory framework that allows responsible sharing among vetted scientists, and taking advantage of an existing robust administrative and scientific framework—provides what we believe to be a unique opportunity for scientists to understand how CVD starts and develops in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Estimated glomerular filtration rate and urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio, measures of glomerular function and injury respectively, are currently used to stage chronic kidney disease. Novel urine measures that quantify the health of the kidney tubules have recently allowed us to define additional dimensions of kidney health. Our global hypothesis with this application is that kidney tubule damage and dysfunction are related to the onset and progression of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease and heart failure.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite major advances in the care and treatment for people living with HIV (PLHIV), morbidity and mortality among PLHIV remains unacceptably high in sub-Saharan Africa, largely due to the parallel challenges of poverty and food insecurity. The proposed Sustainable Development for HIV Health (SD4H) Training Program aims to train a cadre of interdisciplinary Kenyan PhD and Masters students' at Maseno University who will work at the intersection of sustainable development and health with a focus on improving HIV care, treatment and prevention outcomes. The proposed structure of the program supports young investigators to remain in Kenya because students remain vested and actively engaged in studies and meet the requirements for a degree within their home institution while benefiting from enhancements, i.e. additional courses/certificate offered at participating University of California campuses, full-participation in a SD4H mentored-research experience and a multidisciplinary team of dedicated mentors from Maseno University, the Kenya Medical Research Institute and the UC Global Health Institute.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent, oxidative form of regulated cell death that is morphologically and biochemically distinct from other cell death pathways, and has been implicated in numerous cancer therapies and natural tumor suppression mechanisms. This proposal will utilize small molecule and lipid probes, genetic modulation techniques, lipidomic profiling and activation state assays to investigate the roles of lipid remodeling and lipid-responsive signaling pathways in mediating ferroptotic cell death. Building a more comprehensive model of the molecular networks involved in ferroptosis may uncover new avenues of research to exploit this cell death pathway for therapeutic benefit in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mild traumatic brain injury is extremely common among adolescents, who suffer disproportionately from prolonged concussion symptoms – a condition for which no biologic test exists. Emerging evidence suggests non-coding RNA released into saliva by neurons and glia, may provide a biologic window into the brain’s repair response. This study will measure longitudinal brain-related RNA levels in the saliva of adolescents with mild traumatic brain injury to: 1) validate an innovative method that helps clinicians predict the duration and character of concussion symptoms; and 2) define a biologic signature that aids assessment of concussion recovery for return-to-play and return-to-learn decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative There are too few under-represented minorities, people with disabilities, and persons from rural and inner-city communities who are pursuing careers as researchers who will develop new treatments for cardiovascular disease, the most common cause of morbidity and mortality both internationally and within the United States. Over the last 15 years, Virginia Commonwealth University’s Pauley Heart Center, has created a high-quality research environment with federally funded, multi-disciplinary (involving collaborations among seven [7] institutional departments), translational (involving pursuit of fundamental discoveries that impact meaningful health outcomes) research projects conducive to training and mentoring students interested in a future related to cardiovascular care. We now propose to further expand this academic environment to partner with six Universities across Virginia in a shared goal to teach and engage a diverse range of students in learning to perform translational cardiovascular research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) is a major cause of cancer-related mortality and long-term disability. Most patients have abysmal outcomes, with five-year survival rates of less than 40%. Recently, single cell analysis of HNSCC tumors revealed a new transcriptional pathway dubbed the hybrid epithelial/mesenchymal (HEM) program that is a critical driver of invasion and metastasis in this cancer. The importance of this pathway is highlighted by the fact that the presence of the HEM signature in tumors is more predictive of treatment outcome than any other commonly used pathologic or demographic factor. Can this pathway be targeted to improve treatment of patients with HNSCC? The main driver of HEM appears to be a transcription factor called Snail2. Since it is difficult to develop drugs to transcription factors, we propose to map the genes regulated by Snail2 and determine which of these drive the metastasis and invasion phenotypes observed in HEM cells. We also propose to learn which other transcription factors regulate HEM in concert with Snail2 and to map their target genes. Accomplishing these goals will identify opportunities for rational drug design and targeted therapeutics against HNSCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The frog Xenopus tropicalis can fully regenerate the spinal cord following injury, a capability that is lost as the tadpole undergoes metamorphosis. Our project centers on defining the transcriptional regulatory networks that allow neural progenitor cells to regenerate a functional spinal cord after injury, how these contrast with embryonic patterning mechanisms, and the changes in neural progenitors that lead to regeneration failure in the post-metamorphic frog.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulated immunity is a hallmark of many neurological disorders including delirium and dementia. Delirium superimposed on dementia remains a poorly understood, life threatening, complication that impacts millions of Americans that require common surgical interventions, such as orthopedic surgery. ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Just by using oxygen to generate energy, cells sustain daily oxidative DNA damage. This oxidative DNA damage is especially dangerous at replication forks, where the damage must be repaired before replication makes the oxidative mutations permanent. EEPD1 mediates a unique pathway for the cell to repair this damage that brain cancers subvert for their survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project proposes to develop a paper-based blood test through the multiplexed analysis of five colorectal cancer biomarkers, which are expected to provide accurate early detection when combined with our signal amplification strategy. The proposed research project is relevant to public health because it seeks to develop a more sensitive, low-cost, and minimally invasive blood test to improve colorectal cancer screening rates in minorities, uninsured and low-income patients. Upon completion, this project will provide community health centers with unique preventive and diagnostic capability that will enable them to expand their reach to all eligible patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Inclusive Excellence Training Program in the Systems Biology of Cardiovascular Inflammation is a new training program at the University of Minnesota. This program fills a major void at our institution by focusing emphasis on the highly clinically relevant problem of inflammation in cardiovascular biology, obesity, diabetes and metabolism with study focus from gene to whole organism. This program will train the next generation of biomedical researchers by leveraging outstanding faculty with successful mentoring history and new core facilities for a stellar training program for our trainees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Very little is known about the factors that regulate antiviral immune responses in the oral cavity, a prime site for viral infection and dissemination to other tissues. In this proposal, we will determine how viral-bacterial and epithelial interactions occurring at the oral mucosal barrier impact the development of antiviral immunity and, in turn modulate host susceptibility to oral viral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As our population ages, and the need for dermatologic care continues to grow, there is an urgent need for a user-friendly tool for older patients to collect photographs, report symptoms and monitor their skin disease from home. We propose to use our novel, older adult-friendly, automated text virtual assistant – Dermatology of OldeR Adults (DORA) – to develop a longitudinal diverse image library of common skin diseases and describe the progression of common skin diseases affecting older adults. We will compare the information collected virtually through DORA to in-person clinical assessments at 6 and 12 months to inform the long-term use of this novel tool to monitor skin disease in older adults from home.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Maternal blood vessels undergo dramatic adaptations to decrease blood pressure and increase uteroplacental perfusion to meet the metabolic demands of the fetus. The proposed studies will help define the role of environmental exposure to perfluorooctane sulfonate (PFOS) in blunting vascular relaxation, increasing blood pressure, and decreasing uteroplacental perfusion and nutrient transport to the fetus during pregnancy. These results will contribute substantively to a mechanism-based understanding of PFOS's role in pregnancy complications and alert environmental agencies to devise policies to curtail PFOS exposure to reproductive- age women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Chylomicrons are large lipoproteins that consist mainly of fats and cholesterol. They transport dietary fats from the intestines to other parts of the body, and have been widely considered to not promote the formation of fatty plaques in arteries. The overall goals of this project are to understand the biological consequences of chylomicron uptake across the thin endothelial layer that lines blood vessels, and how chylomicrons affect arterial biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Projective narrative The rising super crop tef has a great potential as nutritious and healthy grains, but there has been limited knowledge available on this crop due to lack of investment in its research and limited genome information. This proposal aims to identify bioactive chemicals from tef grains and study their role in boosting the antioxidant pathway towards mitigating ROS-induced inflammatory diseases such as CVD, type II diabetes and cancer. We also aim to identify the molecular genetic mechanisms regulating variation in antioxidant activity in tef grains that can be used to improve tef or introduced into other major crops such as corn via molecular breeding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant pediatric brain tumor, with deaths occurring due to metastatic spread of primary tumor to the leptomeningeal membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord. We present data that these metastases actually arise through active hematogenous dissemination rather than via passive spread through the CSF, as was presumed. We outline aims to determine the role of hematogenous dissemination across MB subgroups; determine the preclinical utility of circulating tumors cellsas a biomarker for metastasis; and to clarify roles and therapies for CCL2 and CCR2 in metastases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontitis is one of the most prevalent inflammatory diseases in humans and harbors heterogeneous disease phenotypes. A biomarker analysis in stages of a new periodontal profile classification, which improved the homogeneity within each disease stage, identified that Type I interferon played a novel regulatory role in periodontitis. This translational research program will delineate the mechanism of Type I interferon in dampening excess innate and adaptive immune response involved in periodontitis and evaluate the effect of a nanoparticle-mediated sustained delivery system that activates and releases Type I IFN locally in periodontitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE We have identified a mitochondrial signaling axis centered on MnSOD-K68 which, when its normal acetylation status is altered, disrupts cell metabolism, leading to aberrant-ROS levels, and a tumor permissive phenotype (Zhu et al, 2019). Interestingly, emerging data suggests that the disruption of mitochondrial metabolism, including aberrant ROS levels, is an increasingly accepted mechanism of oncogenicity due to an enrichment of stem-like cells. Thus, it is proposed that when MnSOD-Ac exists outside of its normal physiological context, it disrupts cellular and mitochondrial metabolism and promotes lineage plasticity properties (or tumor cell stemness), leading to an oncogenic permissive and TamR phenotype, and is a potential target for new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Phagocytosis of apoptotic cells is fundamentally important for many biological processes, and defects in cell clearance have been linked to multiple inflammatory diseases. Similarly, mutations in solute carrier (Slc) family proteins have been linked to >100 human diseases. This proposal addresses the role of the Slc genes and proteins during the process of apoptotic cell clearance, in the context of inflammation models. Since SLCs are membrane proteins and have been shown to be drug targets, the results of this proposal could have significant therapeutic implications for diseases such as autoimmune diseases, lung inflammation, atherosclerosis, and acute kidney injury, where both the apoptotic cell clearance and SLC function have been previously linked.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project aims to further develop innovative, easy-to-follow protocols for cryopreserving Drosophila (fruit fly) embryos in labs and stock centers around the world. These protocols, which likely prevent the genetic drift common to live stock continuation, will be a highly useful tool for reliable and cost-effective long-term preservation of thousands of Drosophila stocks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative It is well established that most individuals with alcohol use disorder (AUD) can briefly quit drinking, but a significant challenge is to not relapse to excessive drinking following a period of abstinence. The TSRI-ARC renewal addresses key gaps in our understanding of AUD, in that it focuses on the less well-understood persisting heightened neurobiological stress responses and impaired cortical control that may drive drinking relapse. The overall goal of TSRI-ARC is to identify fundamental neurobiological mechanisms mediating AUD, and guide the translation of our basic research findings toward helping individuals recover from AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Vestibular schwannoma (VS) is a brain tumor that severely impairs one’s ability to hear and communicate. Surgical removal of VS through a craniotomy leads to significant morbidities including hearing loss, paralysis of the face and injury to critical parts of the brain. Using a combination of the state-of-the art tools, including cell and animal models of VS, genomic sequencing and nanotechnology, this proposed study identifies new biomarkers that could help surgeons identify which VS are aggressive, and develops nanoparticles that home to tumor cells to label areas of the tumor to make surgery more precise and safer for patients.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Humanized mouse models remain suboptimal in mounting a human immune response and lack key components of human mucosal immunity. To address these research gaps, we propose to construct and credential a novel model based on genetically engineered immunodeficient mice, which, when transplanted with human hematopoietic progenitor cells and human bronchial epithelial progenitor cells, will develop a broad range of human immune cell types and a human lung epithelium, thereby enabling the study of human mucosal immunity. Once credentialed, our model will facilitate a wide range translational immunology studies and testing of mucosal adjuvants, allergens, vaccines, and biologicals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to explore the natural human mechanism, to use so-called heat shock proteins, to retain protein homeostasis and prevent the formation of toxic protein aggregates. Such aggregates are found in different illnesses such as Alzheimer's disease but nothing is known how they become toxic. Completion of the proposed objectives will provide valuable insights about how healthy individuals prevent such toxicity and this may provide therapeutic strategies against Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative There is an urgent need to better understand the genetic regulatory mechanisms that affect antibiotic synthesis operons, as this information will influence the strategies used for discovering novel antibiotics and will lead to new tools for improving heterologous production of antibiotics. We recently discovered a new family of transcription elongation factors called LoaP, which we hypothesize are broadly used for regulation of antibiotic synthesis operons. In this project, we will reveal the genetic regulatory strategy used by this important protein and show how its molecular mechanism provides unique and fundamental insight into the workings of the transcription elongation complex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Neural tube defects (spina bifida and anencephaly, for example) constitute the second-most common class of birth defects, resulting in significant suffering and monetary costs: ~$1 billion total in hospitalization costs for all US patients each year. This proposal seeks to understand mechanisms of apical constriction, a change in cell shape that contributes to successful neural tube closure, using the roundworm C. elegans as a simple model for efficient investigation of cellular and molecular mechanisms. The long-term goal of the work is to understand fundamental mechanisms that can lay a foundation for future diagnosis and prevention of neural tube defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The SPURS program addresses the lack of diversity in biomedical research, which is rooted in the limited number of under-represented students entering the field of science, ultimately affecting the goals and direction of research. Underserved communities suffer from a lack of representation at the decision-making level in science, in terms of policy issues and the determination of priorities for conducting research. Therefore, the SPURS program addresses the critical need to increase the pipeline of highly qualified trainees into neuroscience.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain-computer interfaces must enable robust and generalizable control of assistive devices in uncontrolled environments, such as the home. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Doxorubicin is one of the most efficacious anticancer agents in the treatment of several solid tumors as well as hematological malignancies, but its utility is severely limited by its induction of cardiotoxicity and cardiomyopathy. This occurs due to the ability of doxorubicin to promote the accumulation of redox-active iron into the cardiac mitochondria, but current iron chelators do not offer clinical benefits since they are mitochondrial-inaccessible or impede doxorubicin’s antitumor efficacy. We report a new class of a small molecule that provides selective and efficient iron removal from the mitochondria without affecting doxorubicin’s antitumor activity, which has the potential to revolutionize approaches in many anthracycline- based cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT – PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastatic triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) patients have poor clinical outcomes, in part, because there are no targeted therapies approved to treat this aggressive breast cancer subtype. By elucidating new post-translational mechanisms of eIF5A1/2-dependent TGFβ/fibronectin-induced heterogeneity and metastasis within primary and premetastatic niches, the proposed studies have the potential to identify new therapeutic strategies for abrogating TNBC progression. Additionally, this work has broad applicability across the field of oncology as many of the molecular regulators being investigated in this proposal have been reported to be altered or dysregulated in other solid tumor types where cancer metastasis is a primary cause of patient mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell migration is critical to many physiological and pathological processes, including embryogenesis, wound healing, immune function, and cancer metastasis. Lamellipodia are thin, sheet-like protrusions that facilitate cell migration in diverse environments. This project combines high-resolution light-sheet microscopy, computer vision, and molecular biology techniques to study the formation and function of lamellipodia in 3D fibrous matrices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a collection of acquired or inherited diseases wherein the bone marrow produces too few blood cells, and patients progress to acute leukemia. We idenitified that dysregulation of innate immune signaling and inflammation are critical drivers of MDS pathogenesis. Research initiatives to dissect the genetic, molecular, and cellular underpinnings of MDS, with an emphasis on dysregulated innate immune signaling, will be pursued. Knowledge gained by our basic research findings will facilitate identification of novel therapeutic targets and treatment modalities for MDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The recent Ebola and Zika crisis have highlighted the need for vaccines against infectious pathogens. While serum IgG is crucial for the provision of immunity in the bloodstream, induction of protective IgG responses often requires multiple doses of vaccines. This proposal will address innate mechanisms that can be exploited to induce brisk and broad immunoglobulin isotype responses, including secretory IgA responses by injected vaccines to improve protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Disabled 2 (DAB2) is one of the few proteins that are known for removing the phosphorylation of c-Src protooncogene and Src pathway is frequently activated in triple negative breast cancer (TNBC). We have previously reported that mitochondrial reprogramming to fatty acid oxidation (FAO) is a key regulator of Src activation in TNBC, but the mechanism of regulation is not understood. Since our current preliminary data suggest that FAO regulates DAB2 expression in TNBC, this project will evaluate the significance DAB2 in the metabolic activation of Src in TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physical therapists commonly manage patients with chronic musculoskeletal pain (CMP) who are on long-term opioid treatment (LTOT). Mindfulness is an effective psychological approach for both pain and opioid use outcomes in persons with CMP and LTOT but has not been studied in the physical therapy setting. This project will test the feasibility conducting a cluster randomized clinical trial to evaluate the integration of mindfulness principles with evidence-based physical therapy in patients with CMP and LTOT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Pneumonia is a leading cause of death in the U.S. and an improved understanding of key risk factors is needed to reduce its burden. Alcohol is the most frequently abused substance that also increases susceptibility to bacterial pneumonia. We have identified that CFTR-mediated ion transport is decreased by alcohol, and may be responsible for reduced mucociliary clearance of inhaled pathogens. Hence, we propose to determine mechanistic basis and test novel treatment approach to restore CFTR function and lung defense against bacterial infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is the most common lethal autosomal recessive disorder among Caucasians, occurring in1 per 2,500 to 3,500 U.S. births annually. An overarching goal of our work is to evaluate the role of CFTR translational efficiency during disease pathogenesis, including identification of cellular targets that address mutations refractory to CFTR modular treatment. The project will improve understanding of cystic fibrosis, advance new experimental technologies, and provide mechanistic insight relevant to CF and other genetic conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will build upon data from the previous funding period to understand how genetic variation in the viral accessory protein Tat affects its function and hence neuroHIV. Using complimentary in silico, in vitro, in vivo and ex vivo assays, we propose to delineate the mechanism by which Tat promotes neurotoxicity and neurocognitive impairment. Successful completion of the proposal will have implications in developing novel therapeutics to treat neurocognitive impairment and genetic diagnostic assays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Circadian rhythms in behavior and physiology are strongly linked with psychiatric disease, but fundamental of how brain circuits are modulated by circadian rhythms to bring about behavioral changes is lacking. The proposed study will begin to fill this gap by determining for the first time how in vivo neural network electrophysiology in the prefrontal cortex is altered by circadian rhythms in freely-behaving diurnal animals. The proposed research is relevant to public health and the mission of NIMH that aims to transform the understanding and treatment of mental illness through basic research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Even before the COVID-19 pandemic, emergency department (ED) healthcare workers (HCWs) were already known to be at greater psychological risk than nearly every other subgroup of clinicians. Psychological and physiological stress factors have been drastically magnified during the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly among frontline ED HCWs in New York City, the initial US epicenter of the outbreak. It is therefore critical to understand the degree of sustained psychological symptoms seen in ED HCWs who treated COVID-19 patients, as well as the downstream impacts on cardiovascular health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2) is a disease with multiple manifestations, including the vestibular schwannoma, a tumor of Schwann cells. Patients with NF2 can experience hearing loss, facial paralysis, and vertigo due to the location of a vestibular schwannoma on cranial nerve VIII. In this study, we will model NF2 using a human pluripotent stem cell culture system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Historical observations suggest that revolutionary scientific and therapeutic advances often emerge at the interface between disciplines. Therefore, we believe that individuals trained in both engineering principles and cardiovascular science (biology) are critically needed to develop novel therapeutic approaches for treating cardiovascular diseases that are leading causes of death and disability in the Western world. The proposed program aims to provide such training to students pursuing a doctoral degree in bioengineering, with a focus on the cardiovascular system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer is increasingly becoming a larger public health burden, with rising incidence of many cancer types and rapidly rising treatment costs worldwide necessitating development of new, effective cancer therapies. We are developing a new approach, representing a dramatic shift in the treatment of metastatic cancer, utilizing immune responses to recognize and destroy cancer (known as immunotherapy) in combination with systemically administered radiation therapy, known as targeted radionuclide therapy (TRT). This grant application proposes experiments that will deepen our mechanistic understanding of the dynamic radionuclide-specific effects of TRT on tumor cells, immune cells, and anti-tumor immunity, with potential for the results to expand treatment options for metastatic cancers in the U.S. and abroad.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Pa) cause severe infections in patients with burns, severe wounds, pneumonia, or undergoing nosocomial procedures. Most Pa strains are resistant to many antibiotics limiting the treatment options. Vaccination is perhaps the greatest health advancement of our lifetime. Our vaccine to prevent Pa, regardless of initial injury or Pa strain, will positively impact all of us. Indeed as we age, we all have a greater risk of a potential Pa infection. Our vaccine is aimed at preventing these infections as well. Herein we examine the vaccine formulation for efficacy in rodent models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE There are nearly 5 million adolescents and young adults living with HIV (AYALH) globally who have survived growing up with HIV and are now emerging into adulthood to confront high rates of HIV-related co-morbidities including preclinical cardiovascular disease (CVD) which is associated with premature death and disability. The epidemiology of preclinical CVD among AYALH is not defined, including age of onset, progression, and associated risk factors. In this K01 proposal, Dr. Reif will conduct a prospective cohort study of 500 HIV+ and 500 HIV- participants ages 18-30 years in Haiti followed for 3 years to address this knowledge gap and inform the adaptation of evidence-based CVD interventions for AYALH and for integration into HIV clinics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our propsal will clarify the role of endocannabinoid (eCB) system in the pathology of migraine headache and seeks to validate enhancing 2AG tone as a novel antimigraine strategy. In three aims, we will 1) determine the levels of eCB components during two models of headache, 2) investigate the mechanisms by which eCB dysregulation contributes to headache, and 3) examine the therapeutic effects of selective MAGL and ABHD6 inhibitors for headache prevention and mitigation. These will lay the foundation for initiating a drug discovery program for targeting eCB signaling for headache with respect to 2AG degradation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The mechanisms that drive progressive multiple sclerosis (MS) remain enigmatic; however, expression of the proinflammatory cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) in cerebrospinal fluid of MS patients correlates with disease progression, which suggests that TNF plays a key role in demyelination and glial cell function. Surprisingly, however, TNF-blocking drugs with proven efficacy in other autoimmune diseases triggered onset and exacerbations of MS, which provided evidence that TNF signaling is important for promoting CNS protection and repair. The main goal of this proposal is therefore to understand how TNF signaling through TNF receptor (TNFR) 2 restricts progression of neuroinflammation, chronic astrocyte activation, and pathogenic T cell responses in a pre-clinical progressive EAE model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiomyocyte loss is a major cause of morbidity and mortality of ischemic heart disease and heart failure. Accumulating evidence suggests that pre-existing cardiomyocytes can proliferate and are the prominent source of CM renewal in adult mammalian heart; however, the limited regenerative capacity of adult cardiomyocytes impedes the recovery from myocardial infarction. We will study the paracrine regulation of cardiomyocyte proliferation and renewal and identify novel therapeutic targets and strategies for treating these devastating diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary fibrosis (PF) syndromes, including adult idiopathic PF (IPF) and childhood interstitial lung disease (chILD), cause significant morbidity and mortality worldwide. Treatment options are limited and the development of new therapeutics is hampered by the lack of available human in vitro models that are needed to understand pathogenesis or develop novel therapies. This proposal seeks to establish a new recombinant human organoid model system, using patient-specific cells to study the role of the alveolar epithelium at the inception of PF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to study the role of aflatoxin exposure on child growth, and whether the effect of aflatoxin is mediated by the gut microbiome and inflammation. We will evaluate aflatoxin exposure and height-for-age difference trajectories among children between 6-9 and 24-27 months of age, and will examine markers of inflammation, gut microbiome composition and function, and microbial nutrient extraction and aflatoxin microbial biotransformation. Through a multidisciplinary approach that leverages access to an exposed population and expertise in epidemiology, pediatrics, toxicology, environmental engineering and human microbiome, and bioreactors as model system, we will be able to gather evidence that can be practice- changing, as it will help support large-scale investments in aflatoxin remediation efforts on the part of CDC, USAID and other international public health organizations working to improve global child health.

PHR: Project narrative Basic patterns in the spatial layout of cells in a tumor can influence patients’ response to therapy and metastasis, and while significant technology development to measure the properties of cells in intact tissues have advanced at pace, detailed and robust investigations have been limited by a lack of computational methods for analyzing spatial tumor data. This proposal addresses this gap by developing and validating new statistical methods and algorithms capable of (i) extracting rich patterns from spatial tumor data, (ii) generalizing across multiple spatial technologies, and (iii) validating on real-world data from ovarian cancer patients. Addressing this gap will lead to new fundamental discoveries in cancer biology and enable the rational design of spatial biomarkers to enable biological discovery and a new generation of single cell spatial properties of tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative A cochlear implant can provide auditory sensation to someone who would otherwise be deaf due to a dysfunctional inner ear. However, the signal provided by a cochlear implant does not have the clarity of what would be provided by healthy biological hearing, and the degree to which listeners with cochlear implants can understand spoken language varies considerably from patient to patient. Here we use functional brain imaging to measure the involvement of different brain networks during speech understanding in patients with cochlear implants to better understand individual differences in speech perception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This new post-doctoral training program will establish a pipeline to train outstanding surgeon scientists in cardiac surgery. We will leverage the considerable resources at the University of Michigan in medical education; NIH- funded laboratories in basic, translational, and clinical/health services research as well as a talented pool of mentors to attract surgeon scientists during their cardiac surgery residency. Our multi-disciplinary training program for surgeon scientists will prepare them for exceptional careers in cardiac surgery with the ultimate goal of advancing health and health outcomes for patients with cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Addition of sugars to proteins (glycosylation) is required for proper development, and defects in glycosylation cause a variety of genetic disorders. Here we propose studies on specific types of glycosylation found on cysteine-rich domains of proteins. We seek to identify proteins with these types of glycosylation, examine how these glycans are affected in a genetic vascular disorder called CADASIL, and learn more about the genes involved in their biosynthesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripheral neuropathy occurs in 30-40% of patients who are treated with neurotoxic chemotherapy and results in dose-limiting pain, numbness and weakness that can lead to long term illness. This proposal aims to use human adult stem cell-derived neurons to investigate a protein, MAP2 (microtubule associated protein 2), which has been recently identified as playing a key role in the development of chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy. A detailed understanding of MAP2 in chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy brings the promise of a therapy that could ultimately prevent the development of this dreaded complication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – MODELING MULTISCALE IMMUNO-MECHANICS IN AORTIC DISEASE Vascular diseases continue to be responsible for significant disability and death. They result from myriad molecular causes, but manifest clinically at the tissue scale. We will develop novel multiscale computational models that integrate, for the first time, immuno-biological and mechano-biological contributions to aortic disease in order to establish both a new paradigm for understanding disease progression as a function of age of onset, immune status, and sex and a better approach for selecting and timing drug therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reducing the mortality rates associated with coronary artery disease will require the development of accurate strategies to risk stratify coronary lesions that will precipitate an acute coronary event. The proposed research will establish and validate computational frameworks to characterize the in vivo plaque stiffness and mechanical stress field, and evaluate the predictive accuracy of these frameworks to identify high-risk coronary lesions in the clinical setting. The outcomes of this research will promote the prognostication of coronary lesions to guide patient management and treatment strategies towards minimizing major adverse cardiac events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Channelrhodopsins are ion channel proteins from motile algae that convert light into cellular electrical signals and are widely used as molecular tools in biomedical research to control the activity of targeted neurons and other excitable cells. This approach, called optogenetics, has led to remarkable advances in our understanding of brain function and has recently shown clinical promise in restoring visual activity in blind patients. Understanding how channelrhodopsins are opened by light and the basis of their diverse functional properties will enable the development of new optogenetic tools for research and clinical applications with the potential to treat diseases of the nervous and cardiovascular systems including arrythmias, epilepsy, visual loss, hearing loss, and chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE Breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL) is a common and debilitating complication of breast cancer treatment. We have found that the risk of this complication is significantly increased in Black women. The purpose of this study is to uncover the cellular mechanisms that drive racial differences that increase the risk of BCRL development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Gene fusions of the receptor tyrosine kinase, ROS1, have been shown to drive neoplastic transformation of cells in a range of malignancies and targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI) that have activity against ROS1 kinase domain, has led to significant reduction of tumor burden in patients. Unfortunately, clinical resistance to TKI therapy frequently occurs, which limits its long-term durability as an anti-tumor treatment strategy. This project will explore a novel mechanism by which resistance to ROS1-TKI emerges from an alternate signaling pathway and predict new resistant point mutations in ROS1 that confer resistance to the next generation of ROS1-TKI therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Increasingly sophisticated plaque modification methods (orbital atherectomy, intravascular lithotripsy etc.) are employed before vascular interventions like stenting to tackle complex atherosclerotic disease and yet, operator decisions are guided by personal experience with no established criteria as to which technology to use and when, what constitutes sufficient modification and how to balance benefits and risks. What is needed and what our team of academic and industrial scientists, engineers and clinicians aims to develop are mechanistic insight into the biology of modification, and tools for predicting function from imaging and validated criteria for treatment outcomes. We will relate alterations in lesion micro-morphology (calcium, lipid, fibrous, fibro-fatty content) to changes in spatial micro-mechanical (compliance, stress) and local drug delivery (uptake, retention) response, and correlate image-based quantification of lesion micro-morphology to interventional outcome, providing a framework to predict and optimize therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: This project will determine how microorganisms use phenotypic memory mechanisms and gene regulation to survive under fluctuating stresses, including periods of nutrient starvation and exposure to antibiotics. By applying biophysical models, the project will enable precise predictions of bacterial growth and survival in complex environments. Our quantitative analysis of how bacteria use gene regulation and memory to survive will enable improvements in the clinical use of antimicrobials, in understanding treatment outcomes, and in controlling and perturbing host-associated microbial communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arterial stiffness is a predictor of cardiovascular diseases; however, the underlying mechanism by which arterial stiffening promotes abnormal vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) function associated with neointima formation in the vessel wall is largely unknown. This proposed research explores the novel roles of survivin as a key regulator of stiffness-mediated VSMC phenotypes, neointima formation, and arterial stiffening. In addition, we employ in vitro porcine aorta decellularized extracellular matrix-based experimental systems, sophisticated single-cell-based analyses, and a mouse model system to examine the interactions between VSMCs and the pathological vascular environment and to identify potential new therapeutic targets for the treatment of cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Repeated low oxygen delivery (hypoxia) to the developing fetal brain during pregnancy frequently occurs due to maternal sleep apnea and carries significant risks for disturbances in brain maturation and life-long neurological disabilities. We will undertake fetal tissue oxygenation measurements, pathology and behavioral studies and high field MRI analysis to determine the responses of the fetal brain to repeated episodes of maternal hypoxia. We will define novel cellular and molecular mechanisms that disrupt the establishment of learning and memory circuitry during a critical window in brain development and will test potential new therapies to improve learning and memory disturbances caused by transient intermittent fetal hypoxia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it provides a novel therapeutic target for brain aneurysms, a condition that leads to a high rate of disability and death in stroke patients upon rupture. In particular, our work focuses on the role of a novel degradation pathway in the development of aneurysms and anti-degradation strategy may serve as a new therapy for the disease. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to reducing the burdens of illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative All blood cells arise from a common precursor called the hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) and HSC is able to differentiate into mature blood cells as well as to replenish the pool of HSCs. Clinically, HSCs are key for bone marrow transplantation for treating leukemia and other blood diseases. The overall goal of this project is to extend our understanding of how GSK3 regulates HSC function and improve HSC/bone marrow transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dementia diagnoses are projected to rise exponentially in the next several decades, with the vast majority of patients developing neuropsychiatric symptoms that are burdensome and difficult to treat. One of the most challenging aspects of identifying the biological substrates contributing to symptoms in dementia is that one dementia syndrome can be caused by different postmortem pathologies. This study will examine associations between anatomic distributions of pathology and neuropsychiatric symptoms in primary progressive aphasia— a language-based dementia caused by multiple pathologies—with the goal of uncovering the putative substrates of neurodegeneration that may enhance diagnostic accuracy, predictions of future decline, and treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The dissemination of antibiotic resistance and the drying-up of antibiotic discovery pipelines threaten to increase morbidity from routine medical procedures and worsen the spread of infectious diseases. The proposed research aims to apply physical modeling to develop a fundamental, mechanistic understanding of how known antibiotics kill bacterial cells, and to harness this understanding using machine learning to discover unprecedented classes of antibiotics. This work is relevant to NIH’s public health mission because it will inform the clinical treatment of bacterial infections and offer new platforms for antibiotic discovery.

PHR: Project Narrative: This discovery project will discover the physical forces dictating the native conformations of membrane proteins and their interactions with lipid bilayers. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although genome-wide association studies have been predominantly focused on European populations in recent years, understudied populations such as the Native Hawaiians may provide genetic insights due to their unique population history and different disease incidence rates. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative – Overall Osteoporosis is a major public health problem in our aging population. The over-arching goal of this center of research translation (CORT) is to understand how bone-building osteoporosis medications work in order to develop ‘next generation’ strategies to treat this disease. To accomplish this goal, we will apply cutting-edge methods to study the effects of such medications on key cell types in bone: stem cells and osteocytes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Hypertension is a major cause of global mortality and a primary modifiable risk factor for renal, cardiovascular and cerebrovascular disease. The present studies will address a significant knowledge gap by directly assessing the mechanisms whereby immune cells lead to salt-sensitive hypertension and kidney damage. Results of this work will transform the understanding of immune mechanisms in salt-sensitive hypertension by utilizing novel animal models and approaches, revealing new paradigms, and providing insight with the potential to transform clinical/therapeutic approaches for the treatment of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myotendinous junctions are susceptible to traumatic muscle injury and myotendinous rupture, and existing treatments for these injuries are not always effective. The proposed research directly addresses the major goal of the NIH: i.e. essential knowledge will be gained about specific injury conditions that will have an impact on the health of patients. The approaches developed here have direct relevance to treatment strategies, as iPSC-derived tissue implants are a real future possibility for these injury conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Independent of initial cause of injury, patients with acutely injured lungs are at increased risk of secondary bacterial lung infection, which prolongs recovery and increases mortality in these patients. We have developed a new approach for culturing bacteria in conditions which mimic the healthy and/or injured lung environment, providing an accurate and convenient way to investigate why the injured lung is more susceptible to secondary bacterial pneumonia. This project aims to determine which nutrients in injured lungs support the growth of pneumonia-associated bacteria, which will provide a scientific basis for the development of clinical interventions that prevent and treat lung infections and, ultimately, improve clinical outcomes for patients with acute lung injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative – Bioinformatics Core The goal of this Bioinformatics Core is to support statistical and bioinformatics analyses to study the effects of osteoporosis anabolic therapies on osteoblast progenitors as well as osteocytes in clinical and pre-clinical studies. To accomplish this goal, we will perform computational analysis on single-cell RNA-seq and bulk RNA-seq obtained from post-menopausal women and female mice treated with either sclerostin inhibitor or PTH. We will then prioritize genes regulating bone formation via human genetic variation association analyses; and knockout mice with deeply skeletal phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Circadian clocks provide an accurate internal representation of local time under a range of different physiological temperatures and cellular energy levels. However, the molecular mechanisms by which clocks compensate for such variations remain experimentally unresolved in any organism. Thus, the overall goal of this application is to fill these fundamentally important knowledge gaps and thereby significantly advance the field of chronobiology with a lasting impact.
